issueDTO.title: Lint for .clone().into_boxed_str()
issueDTO.description:
### What it does

Suggest turning `s.clone().into_boxed_str()` into `Box::from(s.as_str())`.

Possibly could be grouped together with other inefficient string conversions.

### Advantage

Removes a call to __rust_realloc

### Drawbacks

_No response_

### Example

```rust
fn foo(s: &String) -> Box<str> {
    s.clone().into_boxed_str()
}
```

Could be written as:

```rust
fn foo(s: &String) -> Box<str> {
    Box::from(s.as_str())
}
```


### Comparison with existing lints

`redundant_clone` generally doesn't consider the semantics of the 

### Additional Context

[A GitHub search](https://github.com/search?q=clone%28%29.into_boxed_str&type=code) shows this unoptimal pattern is actually used fairly often.

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_END -->
<!-- TRIAGEBOT_END -->
comments: Would probably name this something like `clones_into_boxed_slices`. This is definitely not `redundant_clone` since the clone is used and `__rustc_realloc` will never actually be called (the length and capacity or a clone are always equal).
kind of similar to #15373

@rustbot claim

I'll work on this, including the things mentioned in #15373.

issueDTO.title: feat: Implement functions using geos library
issueDTO.description:
Many functions involve complex algorithms, so we use a library like as [geos](https://github.com/georust/geos) to implement the logic for us. Most of these should be pretty straight forward and easy to implement, since it's just calling a library function. These implementations should go in the `c/sedona-geos/` directory ("c/" instead of "rust/" because the library is using bindings for a C library). Most of the geos geometry methods are shown in this [geometry.rs](https://github.com/georust/geos/blob/master/src/geometry.rs) file (e.g `is_valid()` can be used to implement Sedona's ST_IsValid). This issue lists functions that we can leverage the `geos` library to implement the logic. All of these functions have a method in `geos` that we can use to implement these functions directly. Each function should be implemented in its own PR. Feel free to ping if you need more guidance.

- [x] ST_IsValid
- [x] ST_IsValidReason
- [x] ST_IsRing
- [x] ST_IsSimple
- [x] ST_SimplifyPreserveTopology
- [x] ST_UnaryUnion
- [ ] ST_Boundary
- [x] ST_ConvexHull
- [ ] ST_ConcaveHull (in progress by someone at the moment)
- [ ] ST_Simplify (before starting, see https://github.com/apache/sedona-db/issues/244)
- [ ] ST_Snap
- [ ] ST_MakeValid
- [ ] ST_MinimumClearance
- [ ] ST_MinimumClearanceLine
- [ ] ~~ST_GeometryN~~ (actually pretty sure this can be done faster w/ existing `geo-traits` methods)
- [ ] ST_Polygonize

Update 11/8
- [ ] ST_NumInteriorRing
- [ ] ST_NumInteriorRings
- [ ] ST_NumRings
- [ ] ST_NumPoints
- [ ] ST_InteriorRingN
- [ ] ST_BuildArea
- [ ] ST_DelaunayTriangles
- [ ] ST_MinimumClearance
- [ ] ST_MinimumClearanceLine
- [ ] ST_Normalize
- [ ] ST_Project
- [ ] ST_PointOnSurface (point_on_surface)
- [ ] ST_ExteriorRing (get_exterior_ring)
- [x] ST_Reverse (reserved for someone)

... (there's more, but I'll keep the list short for now)
<!--- This is was created from me manually going reading down the the geometry.rs file I linked. --->

Here is an example commit: https://github.com/apache/sedona-db/commit/6ba858bb6ac1c28b6cb40a6e4eb4607bfcff8a67. It simply calls the `is_valid` method and returns the result as WKB.

https://github.com/apache/sedona-db/blob/9e3365f60cba629536c7ffda8764c6eabf441fde/c/sedona-geos/src/st_isvalid.rs#L69-L71
comments: @paleolimbot Let me know if you want to stick with this approach of focusing on `c/geos` for now, or if you would rather try implementing some in `rust/geo` directly. We do have the PostGIS integration tests set up now, so we can rely on those for correctness.

I???d prefer using rust/geo. We???ve been leveraging the geo-trait in rust/geo to minimize overhead, which leads to a significant reduction compared to using geos.

CC @Kontinuation

Yeah, that makes more sense to me. Dewey originally wanted me to focus on `geos` and not `rust/geo`. I think (but not 100% certain) it was because `geos` was "ground truth" in the cases where behavior differs, and we could implement `geo` later for performance. The thing is, we now have the integration tests to catch correctness issues, so I don't see a reason to duplicate work any more. If we're all good with prioritizing `geo` instead, then I'll close this and create a new one for `rust/geo`.

I think it is still productive to implement these with GEOS for any function that is a trivial wrapper around the GEOS operation (I think this list is a good characterization of those functions). This will give us passing tests and function coverage for very little investment while we prioritize the engineereing capacity required to make specific functions faster.
(In other words, I agree with Jia but that is a separate issue. We can't make functions faster that don't exist).

If a function **already** has an implementation in `rust/geo`'s [algorithm](https://github.com/georust/geo/tree/8940db79aa6aa4ec8820d6328c68a2ae08ac8fdc/geo/src/algorithm) package, shouldn't implementing `geo` instead be the **same amount** of time/effort? If it's the same amount of effort, why not make them exist in the faster library first, so we don't need to duplicate our efforts implementing them in `geos` too?

For example, we implemented ST_Centroid using `geo` in [this PR](https://github.com/apache/sedona-db/pull/33). And there seems to be [a lot more](https://github.com/georust/geo/tree/8940db79aa6aa4ec8820d6328c68a2ae08ac8fdc/geo/src/algorithm) that we can leverage (e.g concave_hull, simplify, etc).

Adopting the original `rust/geo` algorithms and GEOS is both easy. Leveraging the geo-trait in `rust/geo` requires porting existing geo algorithms to sedona-geo-generic-alg, which is a non-trivial amount of work.

We can onboard more functions by directly bridging `rust/geo` or GEOS, and optimize those functions that are frequently used, and leveraging geo-trait brings significant performance benefit.

I'm happy to review + merge PRs implementing either (although I am not sure with this level of discussion on the ticket we will get any contributions for these functions).

I still prefer having the GEOS functions + integration tests implemented first so that we can measure the relative performance of the geo algorithm when we implement it. Most geo algorithms are faster but there has been at least one case (prepared geometry) where the cost of creating the GEOS object still resulted in better performance. If we don't implement the GEOS version, we can't know.
Makes sense. I forgot `geo-traits` is different than the `geo` algorithms. Focusing on `geos` sounds good.

issueDTO.title: ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop
issueDTO.description:
Hi Everyone! 

I'm trying to get openevolve to run locally on an HPC cluster with GPU access. I noticed that embeddings are not supported by default so I've made the following relatively minor modifications to the basic example and how embeddings are called: 
```

iff --git a/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml b/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
index 42fb739..a153ec7 100644
--- a/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
+++ b/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
@@ -5,16 +5,17 @@ checkpoint_interval: 5
 # LLM configuration
 llm:
   # primary_model: "gemini-2.5-flash-lite"
-  primary_model: "gpt-5-mini"
+  #primary_model: "gpt-5-mini"
   # primary_model: "llama3.1-8b"
+  primary_model: "gemma3:27b"
   primary_model_weight: 0.8
   # secondary_model: "gemini-2.5-flash"
   # secondary_model: "llama-4-scout-17b-16e-instruct"
-  secondary_model: "gpt-5-nano"
+  secondary_model: "gemma3:27b"
   secondary_model_weight: 0.2
   # api_base: "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/openai/"
   # api_base: "https://api.cerebras.ai/v1"
-  api_base: "https://api.openai.com/v1"
+  api_base: "http://127.0.0.1:11434/v1"
   temperature: 0.7
   max_tokens: 16000
   timeout: 120
@@ -31,7 +32,7 @@ database:
   elite_selection_ratio: 0.2
   exploitation_ratio: 0.7

-  embedding_model: "text-embedding-3-small"
+  embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"
   similarity_threshold: 0.99

 # Evaluator configuration
@@ -42,4 +43,4 @@ evaluator:

 # Evolution settings
 diff_based_evolution: true
-max_code_length: 20000
\ No newline at end of file
+max_code_length: 20000
diff --git a/openevolve/embedding.py b/openevolve/embedding.py
index 74d3c57..a75ee3f 100644
--- a/openevolve/embedding.py
+++ b/openevolve/embedding.py
@@ -17,6 +17,10 @@ OPENAI_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
     "text-embedding-3-large",
 ]

+OLLAMA_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
+    "embeddinggemma:latest",
+]
+
 AZURE_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
     "azure-text-embedding-3-small",
     "azure-text-embedding-3-large",
@@ -50,6 +54,12 @@ class EmbeddingClient:
                 api_version=os.getenv("AZURE_API_VERSION"),
                 azure_endpoint=os.getenv("AZURE_API_ENDPOINT"),
             )
+        elif model_name in OLLAMA_EMBEDDING_MODELS:
+            client = openai.OpenAI(
+                base_url=os.getenv("OLLAMA_BASE_URL", "http://localhost:11434/v1/"),
+                api_key=os.getenv("OLLAMA_API_KEY", "ollama"),
+            )
+            model_to_use = model_name
         else:
             raise ValueError(f"Invalid embedding model: {model_name}")
```

However when running:

` python openevolve-run.py  examples/function_minimization/initial_program.py examples/function_minimization/evaluator.py --config examples/function_minimization/config.yaml --iterations 50`

I get the following error

`2025-11-06 17:23:16,806 - ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop
/cluster/work/danimarc/openevolve_testing/openevolve/openevolve/database.py:1018: RuntimeWarning: coroutine 'LLMEnsemble.generate_with_context' was never awaited
  logger.error(f"Error in novelty LLM check: {e}")`

and later 

`2025-11-06 17:32:54,927 - ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop`

I wonder if maybe this has something to do with running locally as opposed to making remote LLM calls. I'm very happy make my setup clearer if this can make debugging easier.

Best,

Daniel
comments: Forgot to mention: using the latest git commit `ba1ca44b468553da75404972089ca60101f718a8` and python3.10,

The error is coming from the novelty checking with embeddings. You can disable and try.

In your config.yaml, set the similarity threshold to 0 or remove the embedding model:

```
database:
  # ... other settings ...

  # Option A: Set threshold to 0 to disable novelty checking
  similarity_threshold: 0.0
  embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"

  # Option B: Comment out the embedding model entirely
  # embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"
  # similarity_threshold: 0.99
```

Yes this works! If I understand correctly this wasn't really an ollama bug (which I first thought it was) but rather an issue with the 'diversity' code, that would (probably) persist if I switched to using a pure openai embedding model? 

I quickly tried out the circle_packing example which seems to run fine. Is the diversity code relatively new?
Yes it was a new addition contributed recently - https://github.com/algorithmicsuperintelligence/openevolve/pull/287 you should able to use the system without it.

issueDTO.title: [Bug] Some component default wall thicknesses are 0
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

Default wall thickness of coupler and engine block, and (if a shoulder is added to a nose cone) shoulder diameter and thickness for nose cone are all 0.

### To Reproduce

1. Create a nose cone
2. Extend the shoulder 1 cm
3. Diameter and thickness are 0. It would be better if diameter was (nose cone diameter) - 2*(default body tube diameter), and thickness was (default body tube diameter)
4. Add a body tube
5. Add a coupler or engine block to the body tube. Their wall thicknesses are 0. Note this is particularly misleading for the engine block, since the length is non-zero and in side view it looks like there's something there.
...


### Screenshots / .ork file

#### Screenshot(s):
*(drag-and-drop the screenshot(s) here)*


#### .ork file:
*(drag-and-drop the file here as a .zip file)*


### OpenRocket version

22.02, 23.09, unstable

### What platform are you running on?

Linux

### Additional context

This is on the border between a bug report and a feature request. Either way, should be fixed.
comments:
> 3\. nose cone diameter) - 2*(default body tube diameter), and thickness was (default body tube diameter)

Shouldn't this be `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) - (nose cone thickness)` and `thickness = (nose cone thickness) / 2`? That way, the shoulder starts halfway the cone wall and ends at the inner wall. I'm not sure if that's the most common configuration in real life nose cones.

Yikes, what was I thinking? What I wrote up there is obvious nonsense. 

Looking at a low power nose cone from my parts box, there isn't any obvious internal "step", the thickness of the shoulder is the thickness of the nose cone minus the thickness of the matching body tube. So a PNC-50KA nose cone has a base diameter of 2.48cm and a wall thickness of .157cm; it mates with a BT-50A body tube with a .033cm wall thickness so the shoulder thickness should be .157-.033=.124mm. Unfortunately the shoulder thickness OR calculates for it is 0.

Hello, I am a french student and I would like to contribute to this issue.

Is it still open?

I would like to implement two cases:
* **sole nose cone:** implementing `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) /2 ` and `shoulder thickness = (nose cone diameter)/4` , this way by default the shoulder is filled and ends halfway through the nose cone diameter.

* **nose cone added as there is already a body present:** implementing `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) -  (body tube wall thickness)` and `shoulder thickness = (shoulder diameter) /2 `, this way the shoulder is again filled by default and ends where the inner wall of the body tube starts.

Regarding the engine block wall thickness, I do not really think of a specific value that would be particularly appropriate, but if you think there is, one can be implemented.

> Hello, I am a french student and I would like to contribute to this issue.
> 
> Is it still open?
> 
> I would like to implement two cases:
> 
>     * **sole nose cone:** implementing `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) /2 ` and `shoulder thickness = (nose cone diameter)/4` , this way by default the shoulder is filled and ends halfway through the nose cone diameter.
> 
>     * **nose cone added as there is already a body present:** implementing `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) -  (body tube wall thickness)` and `shoulder thickness = (shoulder diameter) /2 `, this way the shoulder is again filled by default and ends where the inner wall of the body tube starts.
> 
> 
> Regarding the engine block wall thickness, I do not really think of a specific value that would be particularly appropriate, but if you think there is, one can be implemented.

Hi, yes, it is, thank you for your interest!

I'm not sure if `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) /2` is a good default though. I would think `shoulder diameter = (nose cone diameter) - 2 * (nose cone wall thickness)` would be better. I would set the shoulder thickness the same thickness as the nose cone wall, but enable the `End capped` checkbox by default.

I'm not sure if it's useful to add a check whether there is a body tube present behind the nose cone. Most of the time, you first add the nose cone and then the body tube.

issueDTO.title: [TASK] Convert ContentBlock TypedDict into Union
issueDTO.description:
## Overview

The [ContentBlock](https://github.com/strands-agents/sdk-python/blob/main/src/strands/types/content.py) `TypedDict` is based on the Bedrock type, which is a Union that must include one member and only one member ([docs](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/APIReference/API_runtime_ContentBlock.html)). To highlight that further, if you call bedrock with an empty content block, you will receive the following error message:
```txt
Must set one of the following keys for tagged unionstructure messages[0].content[0]: text, image, document, video, toolUse, toolResult, guardContent, reasoningContent.
```
If you call with multiple members, you get:
```txt
Invalid number of parameters set for tagged union structure messages[0].content[0]. Can only set one of the following keys: text, image, document, video, toolUse, toolResult, guardContent, reasoningContent.
```

With all that said, we did not correctly define the type on our end. The correct type definition should actually be something like:
```Python
class ContentBlockDocument(TypedDict):
    document: DocumentContent

class ContentBlockGuardContent(TypedDict):
    guardContent: GuardContent

...

ContentBlock = Union[ContentBlockDocument, ContentBlockGuardContent, ...]
```
comments:
Hi! I'd like to take this up as my first contribution if it's still available.  
I'll start working on the TypedDict ??? Union refactor as described.  
Thanks!

repository.description: A model-driven approach to building AI agents in just a few lines of code.
repository.name: sdk-python

summary.validationOrRequirement: The type definition should include one of the following keys: text, image, document, video, toolUse, toolResult, guardContent, reasoningContent, and can only set one of these keys.
summary.attemptedFixes: The correct type definition should be a Union of different TypedDicts, such as ContentBlockDocument, ContentBlockGuardContent, etc.
summary.otherNotes: The ContentBlock TypedDict is based on the Bedrock type which must include one member and only one member. Calling bedrock with an empty content block results in an error message. Calling with multiple members also results in an error message.

issueDTO.title: [Refactor]: Improve usability of environment variables
issueDTO.description:
- currently, we use various of environment variables to set configurations but there is no consolidated place to look at list of variables a user can set
- additionally, accessing is done via a string based magic number which hinders readability and prone to error
- here are couple of examples:
   - https://github.com/vllm-project/tpu-inference/blob/aa58a9c2367947489ae4bf3b824bbcc9721b96c2/tpu_inference/layers/vllm/quantization/unquantized.py#L168
  - https://github.com/vllm-project/tpu-inference/blob/aa58a9c2367947489ae4bf3b824bbcc9721b96c2/tpu_inference/worker/tpu_worker_jax.py#L52
  - https://github.com/vllm-project/tpu-inference/blob/aa58a9c2367947489ae4bf3b824bbcc9721b96c2/tpu_inference/distributed/utils.py#L20
  - https://github.com/vllm-project/tpu-inference/blob/aa58a9c2367947489ae4bf3b824bbcc9721b96c2/tpu_inference/runner/tpu_jax_runner.py#L261
- ideally, we want to follow similar approach as vllm does
  - all the list of environment variables in a single file: https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/blob/main/vllm/envs.py
  - and accessing them are done as a member variable and not string based `os.getenv`: https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/blob/2d977a7a9ead3179fde9ed55d69393ef7b6cec47/vllm/model_executor/layers/fused_moe/layer.py#L1226
comments:
Following vLLM's example, which uses both [envs.py](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/blob/main/vllm/envs.py) and [env_override.py](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/blob/main/vllm/env_override.py), we should adopt a similar structure for tpu-inference. In vLLM, envs.py manages standard config values and provides features such as type safety, caching, and lazy evaluation to speed up imports. Meanwhile, env_override.py handles values that must be applied before any module imports occur.

It makes sense to create an `env.py` in our codebase for these same purposes. Below are the environment variables I identified in the current codebase:

- JAX_PLATFORMS
- TPU_ACCELERATOR_TYPE
- TPU_NAME
- TPU_WORKER_ID
- TPU_MULTIHOST_BACKEND
- PREFILL_SLICES
- DECODE_SLICES
- SKIP_JAX_PRECOMPILE
- NEW_MODEL_DESIGN
- PHASED_PROFILING_DIR
- JAX_RANDOM_WEIGHTS
- USE_MOE_EP_KERNEL
- MODEL_IMPL_TYPE.

repository.description: TPU inference for vLLM, with unified JAX and PyTorch support.
repository.name: tpu-inference

summary.main: Improve usability of environment variables by creating a consolidated place to look at the list of variables a user can set and accessing them as member variables instead of string based `os.getenv`.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Create an env.py in the codebase for standard config values and provide features such as type safety, caching, and lazy evaluation to speed up imports.
summary.attemptedFixes: Following vLLM's example, which uses both envs.py and env_override.py, it is suggested to adopt a similar structure for tpu-inference.
summary.otherNotes: Currently, environment variables are used to set configurations but there is no consolidated place to look at the list of variables a user can set. Additionally, accessing is done via a string based magic number which hinders readability and is prone to error.

issueDTO.title: Support BYPASS CACHE Semantics
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We have a multi-modal SlateDB instance that contains metadata and data in the same instance separated by different keys. Some metadata queries should not be cached as they're unlikely to happen again and shouldn't pollute the cache.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
```rs
pub struct ReadOptions {
    ...
    /// Specifies that the results of this query should not be put into
    /// the cache or evict any existing cache entries
    bypass_cache: bool,
}
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Possible that this isn't that valuable of an optimization and may just introduce complexity, so I'm open to not having it supported.

**Additional context**
This is available in Scylla as [`BYPASS CACHE`](https://docs.scylladb.com/manual/stable/cql/cql-extensions.html#bypass-cache-clause)
comments: Do you think it makes sense to include this for writes as well, now that we have write-through cache https://github.com/slatedb/slatedb/pull/747?

Interesting idea 🤔 I think bypassing cache on writes is probably less useful (c.f. `CLEAN_SLATE` minimizing configs). Given that the cache is block-based and you're likely to be writing a bunch of things in one flush, unless they all bypass the cache the block is going to be cached anyway making it a bit confusing of a flag.
Makes sense.

OTOH, I can see value for disabling the write-through cache behavior altogether for use cases that mostly read historical data (or just bloom filters, like a deduplicator use case).

EDIT: I see we already have a config for that (`cache_puts`)
@criccomini if we think this feature is valuable, we should mark this "good first issue" - I suspect it's not a crazy one to implement and I'm sure a newcomer would love to pick it up.

I'm not so sure-- I suspect there might be a gap in the API boundaries where the point at which we know its a "bypass_cache" call, we don't have the ability to bypass the `CachedObjectStore` (since it's a wrapper). I haven't dug in-depth. Either way, labeled it as a first issue. :)
Let's let Copilot take a crack at this 😆
The machines are here to take our jobs!!! 🥵 🤖 ???
Welp, copilot face planted. Gonna open this back up to humans. Looks like our jobs are safe! (for now).

issueDTO.title: Add effects for permanent stat increase
issueDTO.description:
Currently, only effects giving temporary stat increase as an alteration are present (such as `speed_up`, `strength_up` or `defense_up`).
Nothing for increasing the stats in a more "definitive" way.

It would be nice to add these kind of effects, and why not a few items making use of them.
These effects should not result in the creation of an Alteration (since it would not be temporary), but should rather directly modify the stats of the targeted entities.

Place to add implementation of the effects is `effect.py`.
Place for defining displayed names is in `text.py` (`effects` sub-dictionary in `TRANSLATIONS`).

No need to bother about translations to other languages than English right now, checking if the game is not crashing when using another language should be sufficient.
comments: Maybe instead of having to edit the effects in `effect.py`, you should think of making an array on the `character.py` that stores a tuple of the effect ID and the duration of the effect and have the `effect.py` just be a handler that takes that array and updates the character stats.

I'm not sure to get your point.
First, effects don't have any duration, it's alterations have one.

The idea behind effect/alteration distinction is that an **effect** is any kind of change an entity may be affected by, because they drank a potion, an item was thrown at them, a specific spell hit them etc., and an **alteration** is more like a change in status, that could be temporary with a hard turn limit (duration), or we could imagine it being more resilient and requiring to consume something (like an antidote) / go somewhere (like to a "medical center") to get rid of it.
An **alteration** is likely being caused by an **effect**.

An example from the code for the _stun_ effect: 

```py
# At instanciation of the effect
if self.name == "stun":
    alteration_root = etree.parse("data/alterations.xml").find(name)
    desc = get_localized_string(alteration_root.find("info")).strip()
    abbr = alteration_root.find("abbreviated_name").text.strip()
    effs_el = alteration_root.find("effects")
    durable_effects = (effs_el.text.strip().split(",") if effs_el is not None else [])
    self.alteration = Alteration(self.name, abbr, self.power, self.duration, desc, durable_effects)
```
```py
# When it's being applied to an entity
if self.name == "stun":
    entity.set_alteration(self.alteration)
    msg = f_ENTITY_HAS_BEEN_STUNNED_FOR_NUMBER_TURNS(entity, self.duration)
```

Stun is a kind of effect that apply the Stun alteration for X turns to an entity.

And I'm not sure if anything like the list of effects should be stored in Character entity... First because not only Characters could be affected, but also Foes, or other kind of entities. And also because I don't know, they don't look so closely related in my opinion. Effects should be kept rather close to the Effect class, so everything related to effect is around the same place.

But maybe I just misunderstood your idea.

So my point was having a hashmap containing effects and there duration and if an effect has a duration that is not 0 the effect will be applied, but if the duration is none the effect will stay forever, and then you have a the effect take the entity hit by the potion or the attack with effect, and trigger a applyEffectEvent in the entity code, then the entity's code detect that there is a change in the duration of an effect, and applies it to the stats.
I don't know much about the effect in your game so I'm going to make my own for an example:
```py
class Entity:
    # Just a draft of the initialization process from a effects only POV
    def __init__(self):
        self.effects = {'stun': 0, 'speed': 0, 'health_boost': 0, 'strength': 0}
        self.entityType = 'player'
        self.speed = 60
        self.strength = 50
        self.health = 100

    # Very rough, but you get the point
    def applyEffectEvent(self, effect, duration):
        if not effect in self.effects:
            return f"Effect doesn't apply on {self.entityType}"
        self.effects[effect] = duration
        self.updateState()
        return "Effect applied"
    

    # I wrote my updateState function to just handle effects
    # Normally it handles everything that needs to be updated
    def updateState(self):
        for effect in self.effects:
            if self.effects[effect] == 0:
                return
            
            if self.effects[effect] == None:
                match effect:
                    case "speed":
                        self.speed += 20
                    case "strength":
                        self.strength += 10
                    case "health_boost":
                        self.health += 50
                    case "stun":
                        self.speed -= 40
                return
            
            # Here you put how you usually apply your effects with a duration
            # Just use self.effects[effect] to get the duration in whatever unit
```

Ok to be really honest I'm still not sure to get you... It's just that I need to dig further on the subject maybe.

Having an hashmap (dict in Python) is an idea I like: maps/dict is always better than a sequence of if/else statements in my opinion, it's cleaner.

But I don't understand why effect logic should be in entity instead of in... Its own class. And I don't get what would be the pros of following this approach.

OK I'll explain further:

## Using a Hash Map to store the effects on the entity instead of on a separate class :
### Pros :
1. Assume you have multiple entity types, humanoids, goblins, elfs, animals... Having each class for these entities have its own Hash Map of effects is beneficial, because there might be some effects that should not work on that type, example:
- Blindness on a Goblin shouldn't work because they might already live in the dark, they can't see either way
- Strength on an Elf shouldn't work because Elfs usually are either ranged attack or magic attack types

2. Instead of having one class that goes through a lot of if-else statements, you have multiple entities, which can accept or deny the effect, and then apply the effect on an intensity suitable to that entity type, you could also have some built-in limit for an effect on each entity separately, which might be helpful to fix entities judged to be too _'OP'_.
> If you have some experience with coding video games, having a lot of if-else statements is a bad habit, you should know that even games made with languages with faster run times than python struggle with a big amount of if-else statements, (Yandere Simulator is an example)

3. Finally the class that used to handle the effect application, you could make it a base that contains how to trigger an effect appliance on the entity, and then make any object that can apply an effect inherit that part so you don't have to hard code it every time, you only inherit, initialize the effect information and function to the super class, it's easier this way.

### Cons :
1. The only downside is that you have to hard-code how each entity handles effects but that could be for the better



# PLEASE, If you don't get something let me know.

@IliyasDev sorry for the late answer, I was a bit busy working on other projects and needed to dig back in the code to be able to answer you correctly.

> Assume you have multiple entity types, humanoids, goblins, elfs, animals... Having each class for these entities have its own Hash Map of effects is beneficial, because there might be some effects that should not work on that type, example:

You are right, the actual effect on the entity may depends on their characteristics in a foreseeable, but it is not right now.
They could not really be a specific dict/map by character race because races are not reflected as distinct classes in code, because character races are not directly affecting the behavior of the character: an elf and a dwarf are still both living playable entities. 😄 
Class and race are only **attributes**.
To come back to the original point, tbh I didn't really think yet of the design for effects that may differ across Characters/Foes. It may be better maybe to just override the definition of `Movable.set_alteration` to verify if the given entity can be affected by the alteration according to its race, class or other criteria.

Also, different map for every possible race and classes in game seems to be too much code duplication to me, because in most cases, entities should be affected the same way by a given effect/alteration. It's only about exceptions.

> Instead of having one class that goes through a lot of if-else statements, you have multiple entities, which can accept or deny the effect, and then apply the effect on an intensity suitable to that entity type, you could also have some built-in limit for an effect on each entity separately, which might be helpful to fix entities judged to be too 'OP'.

I think you are trying to explain what is **polymorphism**. 
While I definitely agree with your point (this pattern should be followed as much as possible), I unfortunately don't think it's applicable to this situation, because of what I explained before: Goblins and Elfs are only different values for `Character.race` attribute, not different _in-code_ classes.
Also, I'm a bit skeptical about the if-statements Yandere story, I heard about it quite a lot of times, but at the end, I think the issue was more about the lack of consistent design and basic logic rules not followed correctly (i.e., same conditions were checked again and again in the same frames). But I'm not an expert on Yandere's game code.
I just don't think if-else statements are that bad, at least not for perfs. Performance issues are more about wrong architecture and logical ordering decisions ; it's mainly redundant / unnecessary condition checks that can have an impact.

> Finally the class that used to handle the effect application, you could make it a base that contains how to trigger an effect appliance on the entity, and then make any object that can apply an effect inherit that part so you don't have to hard code it every time, you only inherit, initialize the effect information and function to the super class, it's easier this way.

Not sure to get that part. Entities should not inherit from Effects.. Because they are not Effects.. Did you just mean that the application of an effect should be reversed? Like instead of having the method `Effect.apply_on_ent(entity)` there would be `Entity.apply_effect(effect)`? 

Anyway, I definitely agree about the different pieces needing some refactoring: the init method of `Effect` could be generify to avoid having if-else statements sharing all a similar logic, and instead use a kind of map access to the details of the effect from the XML file.
`Effect.apply_on_ent` method also needs to be refactored, and if-else statements should probably be removed as well.

Lastly, I think documentation for both `Alteration` and `Effect` classes should be improved, because after reading them back, I noticed they could be quite confusing.

_Please don't hesitate to argue more if you disagree with one of my point, I'm just sharing my personal feelings about it_

issueDTO.title: Define limited stock of money for shops
issueDTO.description:
Currently, Shops have infinite amount of money: you can sell them whatever amount of items you want and still get money from it.

My idea would be to define a limited amount of money for Shops, same as what is already the case for the players.

The amount of money owned by the seller should be display in the "Sell" view (and maybe in the "Buy" view as well?).

Selling items to the seller would decrease the money left according to the sell value of the item, and buying items from the seller should increase the money left.
If the seller does not have enough money for buying the item, then something should be happening between:

1. Forbid the sell (inform the player that seller cannot buy the item)
2. Allow the sell but only give to the player what the seller had left (0 if the seller already had no money anymore), and maybe ask confirmation to the player that the sell would be "at loss"

I don't have any strong opinion about which behaviour is the best.

Concerned places should be `shop.py`, `menu_creator_manager.py#create_shop_menu` (if anything should be updated in the menu) and `level_0/map.tmx`, `level_3/map.tmx` (for giving the new "money" property to the shops defined in these levels).

_N.B.: I don't know if this feature is a balanced one, I just think it may be funny to implement. Let see after experimenting if it's bringing some value or too boring_
comments: Hello, I am new to open source and would like to implement the following feature if it is available!

Hello @Sonny-Cao , sure, you can start working on it if you want!

Don't hesitate to ask me some questions (by e-mails, or by Discord) if you need help understanding something.
Hello, I am interested in working on this, has it already been done?

Hi @Elemperor1 , in fact someone else just started its implementation, I merged the change today: https://github.com/Grimmys/rpg_tactical_fantasy_game/pull/84/files

But there are still some things to be done :

- [ ] Default balance of any shop is hard-coded to 500, obviously not ideal. The default balance should be read from the level configuration (while parsing the shops entities). For this, TMX maps have to be modified (using [Tiled](https://www.mapeditor.org/)) and `src/services/load_from_tmx_manager.py` should be adapted to parse the information from the map.
- [ ] Updated balance of the shop should be persisted in the save file. For this,  `save` method in `shop.py` should be extended, and `src/services/load_from_xml_manager.py` as well to load the value from the save file.
- [ ] Shop balance should be shown on sell interface as well.

issueDTO.title: [Refactor] Use Builder pattern instead of constructors for Stats API classes
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

As a follow-up on https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/issues/18723, I noticed other stats related classes should also utilize Builder pattern to initialize stats objects.

For example IndexingStats currently has 2 constructors: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/shard/IndexingStats.java#L191-L246

Stats related classes are exposed as PublicApi, and stats are frequently (or maybe once in a while but need to be) incremented, which causes backward-compatibility to break. This makes it difficult to add new metrics and evolve the API without causing significant disruption for developers who have adopted it. Each new stat forces a major version bump and requires users to update their code, even if they don't need the new metric.

Using this issue to track all such metric/stats classes to adopt to builder pattern and mark the existing public constructors to be on deprecation path. 

Reference from SearchStats: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707

### Describe the solution you'd like

- List down all classes to be actioned from stats API / code dive deep
- Create builder pattern for those classes
- Mark existing constructors as deprecated

### Related component

Other

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_
comments: Hi @sandeshkr419 , can I work on this issue?
Thanks @pado0 for taking this, feel free to post any questions if you need help.
@sandeshkr419 Thanks for assigning this to me! I???ll reach out if I run into any difficulties. 👍

Hello, @sandeshkr419 I???m planning to work on this and would like to confirm a few details:

**First**  
I identified a few different patterns of how `Stats` classes are currently defined:  

1. **Pattern 1**: Using `Stats` as an inner class & exposed as Public API  
   - [`IndexStats`  ](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/action/admin/indices/stats/IndexStats.java)
   - [`RemoteTranslogTransferTracker` ](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/remote/RemoteTranslogTransferTracker.java) 

2. **Pattern 2**: Using `Stats` as an inner class & marked as internal API  
   - [`CpuUsageTracker`  ](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/search/backpressure/trackers/CpuUsageTracker.java)

3. **Pattern 3**: No inner `Stats` class, using constructor directly & exposed as Public API  
   - [`RefreshStats`  ](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/refresh/RefreshStats.java)

I plan to include these patterns in the scope of the builder refactor. Does that align with your expectation?
Or would you prefer that the scope only covers Pattern 1 and Pattern 2, and leaves out Pattern 3?

**Second**  
My plan is to list the target classes and define their `Builder` implementations first, and handle the actual constructor ??? builder migration in a follow-up step. Is this the right approach?


**Third**  
For deprecation comments, I???ll mark the existing constructors as ???will be removed in 4.0??? for consistency across all classes. Please confirm if that???s correct.


Let me know if this approach makes sense, and I???ll proceed accordingly.

@pado0 - I'd suggest pick up the individual classes as separate PRs and do the following:
1/ Create a builder pattern for the inner stats
2/ Mark the constructors as deprecated. 
3/ Migrate (refactor) any earlier usage of constructors to your newly created builder patterns in source/test code.

Having small isolated PRs makes the review quick and easier to merge.

Now coming to the stats classes you listed:

----

Pattern 1: Using Stats as an inner class & exposed as Public API

[IndexStats](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/action/admin/indices/stats/IndexStats.java) - This looks abstracted out nicely already with not exposing individual stats. We can leave this as it is for now.

[RemoteTranslogTransferTracker](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/remote/RemoteTranslogTransferTracker.java) - Its inner stats should actually use a builder pattern.

https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/shard/IndexingStats.java#L191-L246 - didn't see this in your comment but this could definitely use a builder pattern though.

-----

Pattern 2: Using Stats as an inner class & marked as internal API

[CpuUsageTracker](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/search/backpressure/trackers/CpuUsageTracker.java)

Given this class is not exposed as a public API, the inner stats using a constructor shouldn't be an issue and can be ignored as of now.

--------

Pattern 3: No inner Stats class, using constructor directly & exposed as Public API

[RefreshStats](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/refresh/RefreshStats.java)

This definitely needs a builder pattern as any new metrics would require a new constructor.

@sandeshkr419 Thanks for the comments!

I reviewed Cluster / Node / Shard / Indices stats (and other metrics) to see where a Stats class is present,
and grouped all stats-related classes into two patterns that are candidates for introducing the Builder pattern.
All of them are PublicAPI and expose public constructors.

For each class, I will:
1. introduce a Builder,
2. mark existing public constructors as @Deprecated, and
3. refactor usages (including tests) to the new Builder.

The list is sorted by priority, and I???ll open small, isolated PRs per class in that order.
If anything looks off, I???m happy to take feedback on the individual PRs and adjust accordingly.

And feedback at any time is very welcome :) Thank you!

### Pattern 1: Using Stats as an inner class & exposed as Public API

issueDTO.title: Make sure caption controls "dim out" when window loses NC focus (WM_NCACTIVATE?)
issueDTO.description:
### Windows Terminal version

1.13.10395.0

### Windows build number

10.0.19044

### Other Software

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open Windows Terminal
2. Click outside of window to lose focus and make the window inactive

### Expected Behavior

Current tab would go grey
Caption buttons would go grey

### Actual Behavior

Neither titlebar element go grey
comments:
Generally, I've been duping these to #4862. However, I totally missed the one other checkbox in #1625 about the caption button colors, so I'm gonna re-purpose this issue to track that element. Thanks!

> **Note**
> ## Walkthrough

To do this, we'd need to:
* Listen for a `WM_NCACTIVATE` in `IslandWindow` 
* Plumb that as an event up to `AppHost`
* Call a new method on `AppLogic`, which plumbs that down to `TerminalPage` to tell them that the window was activated/inactivated
* in `TerminalPage`, when `_settings.GlobalSettings().ShowTabsInTitlebar()` is true, call to `MinMaxCloseControl` in `TitlebarControl` to tell it the window is no longer active
* There, change the color of the buttons when the window is activated/deactivated. 

See also #10401, which never got finished.
I'm psyched to see that #4862 was implemented. Is this still being worked on?

> Is this still being worked on?

Not currently, but it seems fairly trivial these days. The plumbing in #4862 should make it trivial.

proposed "schema":

```js
captionButtons: {
  foreground: ThemeColor,
  background: ThemeColor (default: #00000000),
  unfocusedForeground: ThemeColor,
  unfocusedBackground: ThemeColor (default: #00000000),
}
```

I don't really think we need to have separate knobs for each of the buttons.
I may take a stab at this one if that is ok.
@jamespack Go for it!
is this issue still being worked on?

I actually never started. Missed Mikes go ahead. @techy4shri if you are interested go at it 👍🏻 If I can find some free time I may still take a look though its not high on my wish list. Terminal as is today pretty much checks all my boxes 💯 🥇
hmm it does, thanks @jamespack ! @zadjii-msft let me know if there's anything else I should know about :)
If this issue still not been resolved then I would like to work on it if you can assign it to me.

> If this issue still not been resolved then I would like to work on it if you can assign it to me.

@Abhii242004 they generally don't assign stuff. If it's still open it's up for grabs.

issueDTO.title: Replace static resolving of RabbitTemplate by dynamic resolving in SpringwolfAmqpProducer
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the feature request**
SpringWolf-UI allows to send messages via the frontend. 
Technically, the `SpringwolfAmqpProducer` sends the User's message via a `RabbitTemplate`. If there are mutliple `RabbitTemplates` beans, the logic takes the first one (without order criteria/guarantee).

I would like to have more control/customization possibilities of the `RabbitTemplate` resolve mechanism, e.g. taking the exchange-name and/or routing-key into account.

**Motivation**
My app uses multiple RabbitTemplates; one for each scenario/business uses case. The routing-key is pre-configured in the corresponding `RabbitTemplate` so that the business code has no awareness of routing key specific things.  When sending payloads via SpringWolf-UI I would like to publish the message via the corresponding RabbitTemplate and not any one.

**Technical details**
Some kind of `strategy` or `resolver` mechanism should suffice. The default implementation copies the current logic (taking 1st RabbitTemplate)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Currently, I have to overwrite/re-implement the whole `SpringwolfAmqpProducer#send(String channelName, Object payload)` method :-(
comments: anybody ?
Probably relates to https://github.com/springwolf/springwolf-core/issues/366

Sounds like a good addition to Springwolf. We will have a look into it once our tim allows it.

Feel free to look into it yourself and contribute it as a PR. 

---
Have you considered defining the exchange and routing key as part of the spec, the current implementation would then use both from the spec. Or do you need to connect to different brokers?
Can you please assign me the issue. I would like to work on this.

Hi @suryatejess ,
how is it going? Any progress or question?

(If there is no response by 2025-11-06, we might reassign the issue/open it up for contribution)

summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to https://github.com/springwolf/springwolf-core/issues/366, and the author is willing to contribute a PR. There are comments suggesting defining the exchange and routing key as part of the spec and connecting to different brokers.

issueDTO.title: [feature] Create `process.find("bin_path")`
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Users want list all processes running a specific binary. Currently this means lots of tomes have something like:
```python
res = []
for p in process.list():
  if p['bin_path'] == "bin_path":
    res.append(p)

return res
```
We can stream line this by just making it an eldritch function

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Write an eldritch function: `process.find("bin_path")`
It should return a list of process objects.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Na

Na

Right now the story regarding SQL documentation is a little fuzzy and I'm fine not requiring it until I fix that so as not to subject new contributors to any fuziness that we haven't worked out yet (e.g., I'm not sure exactly how the generation script is supposed to work or whose job it will be to run it yet).

issueDTO.title: [TODO] Replace `tests/gen_pickles.py` with a pytest plugin
issueDTO.description:
The idea is simple:
* [ ] Make a session-scoped fixture in `tests/conftest.py`
* [ ] Move the logic from `gen_pickles.py` there and generate the pickles in a `tmppath`-provided dir
* [ ] Integrate that into the pickling tests
* [ ] Delete `tests/gen_pickles.py` and the pickle files in the `tests/` dir
* [ ] _Bonus points_: keep pickles in-memory, so they don't hit the disk
* [ ] _Bonus 2_: check if a session fixture is needed and switch to the normal function scope, if not
comments:
I've raised a PR here (https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/pull/924). I think this addresses the ideas mentioned here. let me know if there's a better way to do this or if I'm barking up the wrong tree completely!
Thanks for all your help so far!
I'll have a number of comments in the review there.
Sounds good. Let me know!

Hello @vrdn-23 and @webknjaz,

I tried to fix #924 locally and after a few iterations of a simplification I realized that the [`test_load_from_file`](https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/blob/master/tests/test_pickle.py#L24-L38) test doesn't increase coverage since there's already the [`test_pickle`](https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/blob/master/tests/test_pickle.py#L9-L14) test that **does exactly the same**, but in a more elegant and easy to understand way. If I didn't miss something, it's implicitly parametrized enough to cover all the cases. The only difference is that the initial implementation of `test_load_from_file` checks whether data pickled with some previous version of the `multidict` library still can be unpickled and matched with the current version data, but _if you are going to eliminate the corresponding files_, it seems reasonable to drop the `test_load_from_file` completely and rely on the `test_pickle` instead.

```python
def test_pickle(any_multidict_class, pickle_protocol):
    d = any_multidict_class([("a", 1), ("a", 2)])
    pbytes = pickle.dumps(d, pickle_protocol)
    obj = pickle.loads(pbytes)
    assert d == obj
    assert isinstance(obj, any_multidict_class)
```

@webknjaz what do you think?

@vrdn-23, in case @webknjaz decide to keep this test, it would be better to use `io.BytesIO` in order to keep `pickle.dumps`/`pickle.loads` and not switch to `pickle.dump`/`pickle.load`, so the `test_load_from_file` would verify what its name suggests.
Feel free to submit an alternative PR.
I concluded that we should integrate one of pytest-harvest, pytest-datadir, python-pytest-cases or pytest-regressions instead. This needs some research.

Sorry, I object to removing pickle files stored on the disk.

These files were added intentionally to ensure that newer multidict versions still could read older pickles.
All this code was added during the bugfix for an accident with broken backward compatibility.

@webknjaz please feel free to reword the issue to keep pickle files and the generator. Honestly, I prefer keeping everything as is but moving `tests/gen_pickles.py` file to `tools` folder.
Using a proper pytest plugin will address this. Being so disorganized what was prompted the idea of removal since it wasn't obvious what the purpose was. Using a plugin will communicate that clearly.
I'm ok with a plugin if it keeps pickled files in the git tree.

Plugins to choose from:
* `pytest-harvest`:  https://smarie.github.io/python-pytest-harvest
* `syrupy`: https://til.simonwillison.net/pytest/syrupy / https://syrupy-project.github.io/syrupy
* `pytest-insta`: https://github.com/vberlier/pytest-insta
* `inline-snapshot`:  https://15r10nk.github.io/inline-snapshot

`syrupy` and `inline-snapshot` look quite active. But since I haven't played with them, I can't tell which one would feel more organic to use. Hence the need for some research.

> Plugins to choose from:
> 
> * `pytest-harvest`:  https://smarie.github.io/python-pytest-harvest
> * `syrupy`: https://til.simonwillison.net/pytest/syrupy / https://syrupy-project.github.io/syrupy
> * `pytest-insta`: https://github.com/vberlier/pytest-insta
> * `inline-snapshot`:  https://15r10nk.github.io/inline-snapshot
> 
> `syrupy` and `inline-snapshot` look quite active. But since I haven't played with them, I can't tell which one would feel more organic to use. Hence the need for some research.

I'll be sure to look into these over the next few days when I get the chance. Maybe I can find some time to work on these ones soon.

@Vizonex it would be helpful if you could make 4 PRs for comparison to demonstrate the difference to the maintainers. But if not, at least a comment with advantages/drawbacks/maintainability would be nice too. Upon this, we'll commit to using one plugin consistently and across projects.

issueDTO.title: add Prettier formatting to the project
issueDTO.description:
## Type of Change
Chore

## Summary
As new contributions are coming into the project, it would be good to formalize the formatting style and expectations for the project, and for that it would probably a good idea to add Prettier to the project.

There's an example we can follow from the Greenwood website that I implemented that we can follow
https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/www.greenwoodjs.dev

## Details
A couple notes regarding the above reference repo
- I opted to incorporate husky for managing pre-commit hooks, but I am OK if we just want to just have it so contributors manually run `prettier format` locally.
- Either way, we should still have `prettier format` run on CI as part of our GitHub Actions flow
- We should probably also upgrade to ESLint to the latest version and make sure it has any prettier overlapping rules disabled.  Here's that's project's [ESLint config](https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/www.greenwoodjs.dev/blob/main/eslint.config.js) for reference (we don't need the markdown configuration though)
- We should add a note to the [_CONTRIBUTING.md_](https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/wcc/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) with whatever workflow we end up with

----

As we have a few PRs and release in active development, my recommendation would be to wait until all those PRs land first, or just do it as the first change once we cut the v0.16.0 release
https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/wcc/issues?q=label%3A0.16.0+
comments:
@briangrider 
I know we had chatted about this one, so just mentioning you here in case you were interested in contributing the change.
Ok, great. Yes, definitely up for helping with this but agree that we can wait until we get all of the other good stuff we've been talking about in there
Looks like v0.16 is finished. Is this ready to be picked up?
sure!  feel free to review the Greenwood repo for our settings / implementation if you need a reference to get started.  👍

I'm thinking of doing this in three PRs:

1. Install prettier
2. Prettier format all files
3. Add CI check and maybe git hook

@KaiPrince it's fine to do this all in one PR 👍 

Don't forget to account for lint-staged / husky so these linting / formatting checks can be run on git commit.

Oh okay, I was mainly planning to split it because prettier is gonna format a whole bunch of files, and I know you're a guy who prefers keeping diffs lean in each PR. Anyhow I've added the rest into the one PR so it's ready for you to take a look.

Also I've run across an issue with self closing (void) tags, so I'll open a separate issue for that, which is gonna block this one.
See https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/wcc/issues/210

issueDTO.title: Hardcoded `TerrakubeRedisHostname` in API will fail installation if a different Helm release name is used
issueDTO.description:
The deployed Redis instance service name will have a dynamic name based on the Terrakube Helm release name, see
 - https://github.com/bitnami/charts/blob/e07d3319b61f49ddf6f431da3ed7ec0e0be3d5d0/bitnami/redis/templates/master/service.yaml#L10C19-L10C69
 - https://github.com/bitnami/charts/blob/e07d3319b61f49ddf6f431da3ed7ec0e0be3d5d0/bitnami/common/templates/_names.tpl#L21-L38

E.g. Terrakube Helm chart deployed with `terrakube-prod` Helm release name will lead to the default Redis instance service name being `terrakube-prod-redis-master`.

However Terrakube Helm API config is hardcoded to look for a Redis instance named `terrakube-redis-master`, see https://github.com/terrakube-io/terrakube-helm-chart/blob/8d0e24db9a89e36bb60377c650db5842de2dca69/charts/terrakube/templates/secrets-api.yaml#L27.

So in case Terrakube Helm chart gets deployed with a Helm release name different than `terrakube` then the installation will fail, as the Terrakube API component will look for a Redis instance name which will not exist.

Workaround:

```yaml
# Fix a hardcoded Redis hostname bug:
# The deployed Redis instance will have a dynamic name based on the Helm release name, see:
# - https://github.com/bitnami/charts/blob/e07d3319b61f49ddf6f431da3ed7ec0e0be3d5d0/bitnami/redis/templates/master/service.yaml#L10C19-L10C69
# - https://github.com/bitnami/charts/blob/e07d3319b61f49ddf6f431da3ed7ec0e0be3d5d0/bitnami/common/templates/_names.tpl#L21-L38
# But Terrakube's API config is hardcoded to look for a Redis instance named "terrakube-redis-master", see:
# - https://github.com/terrakube-io/terrakube-helm-chart/blob/8d0e24db9a89e36bb60377c650db5842de2dca69/charts/terrakube/templates/secrets-api.yaml#L27
# Therefore override the deployed Redis instance name to the expected hardcoded name
# This issue is tracked here: https://github.com/terrakube-io/terrakube-helm-chart/issues/225
redis:
  fullnameOverride: "terrakube-redis"
```

Proposed fix:
- In the generated Terrakube Helm chart `terrakube-api-secrets` secret, `TerrakubeRedisHostname` should be set dynamically to the actual Redis instance name (that gets generated inside the Bitnami Redis Helm chart dependency) instead of being hardcoded to `terrakube-redis-master`.
- Or at least document that no other Helm release name than `terrakube` is supported
comments:
Hello @julian-waibel I guess using .Values.name should fix that issue because it will take the value from the helm release

Like this:

https://github.com/terrakube-io/terrakube-helm-chart/blob/8d0e24db9a89e36bb60377c650db5842de2dca69/charts/terrakube/templates/ingress-api.yaml#L6

issueDTO.title: Move logic from `conf_int` method to `confidence_intervals.py`
issueDTO.description: Logic in the [confint method ](https://github.com/py-econometrics/pyfixest/blob/ef1d0449e5af4b1e697c5edb6d496a1e07d456d5/pyfixest/estimation/feols_.py#L2086) should be moved to `confidence_intervals.py`
comments:
I can pick this up.

Any more info beyond what is in the title?

This is a very simple PR - basically I would like to move some logic from the Feols class to standalone scripts. So the idea here is to move everything related to confidence intervals to a separate script.
