issueDTO.title: [Template] Create an Information Architecture: Sitemap template
issueDTO.description:
### Current Behavior
Currently for new users we do not have enough starter templates that they can use as introductory material.

### Desired Behavior
We want to create an Sitemap template to allow new users to understand how they can create an Sitemap diagram with Kanvas. So we'd want contributors to not just create a design template but also add tips or notes they think a new user would need if they are starting out with little to no context of the capabilities Kanvas offers.

### Implementation
Make sure you use [Kanvas](https://kanvas.new/extension/meshmap) to create this template and keep the template private.

- [ ] Provide a brief overview of what this template does and can help with, maybe highlight a usecase
- [ ]  Add a template that can be directly copied and used instantaneously
- [ ]  Add a step by step process to create this template
- [ ] Once the design is completed, publish it and share the private link with our team, or tag us in the comment component to receive feedback.

### Acceptance Tests
- Template has been submitted for publishing to the catalog and accepted; is published and available in the Meshery Catalog.
- We are in need of well annotated and described templates like [this](https://playground.meshery.io/extension/meshmap?mode=design&design=09150cb4-b6a2-4eff-87cd-8a35ba94787a) one.


### Mockups
This [FigJam](https://www.figma.com/community/file/1342789621942744845) template can be used for recreating the Sitemap Template

### Perks
By contributing to this task, your efforts will have a lasting impact! Once published, your design will be cloned and used by countless users as a go-to starting point for creating Sitemaps in Kanvas. You'll not only help newcomers understand the platform but also see your work adopted widely by the community. Plus, as a token of appreciation, you'll receive a special shoutout, recognising your valuable contribution. Your effort won???t go unnoticed???you're directly helping shape the experience for future users!

---
### Contributor [Guides](https://docs.meshery.io/project/contributing) and [Handbook](https://layer5.io/community/handbook)
- 🛠 [Meshery Build & Release Strategy](https://docs.meshery.io/project/contributing/build-and-release)
- 📚 [Instructions for contributing to documentation](https://github.com/meshery/meshery/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#documentation-contribution-flow)
   - Meshery documentation [site](https://docs.meshery.io/) and [source](https://github.com/meshery/meshery/tree/master/docs)
- 🎨 Wireframes and designs for Meshery UI in [Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/SMP3zxOjZztdOLtgN4dS2W/Meshery-UI)
- 🙋🏾🙋🏼 Questions: [Discussion Forum](http://discuss.meshery.io) and [Community Slack](https://slack.meshery.io)

issueDTO.title: [devrel-program] Add Dark/Light Mode Support with Toggle (DevRel Website)
issueDTO.description:
(preferably after #3065 is resolved)
The DevRel Program website (devrel.keploy.io) currently does not support a dark/light mode, which is now a standard expectation for accessibility and modern web experiences. Implementing a theme toggle will improve usability, especially for users who prefer dark interfaces, and align the site with Keploy???s branding consistency.

**Expectations & Considerations:**

- Implement dark/light mode using Tailwind CSS dark variants (dark: utilities).
- Add a theme toggle button (preferably in the Navbar for easy access).
- Ensure the theme persists across sessions (e.g., localStorage or next-themes).
- Integrate UI libraries (shadcn/ui, Radix UI, Magic UI, etc.) for a clean and accessible toggle component.
- Ensure both modes follow Keploy???s design language while maintaining contrast ratios for readability.
- Apply theme compatibility across all pages and sections (home, program details, components like modals/footers).
- Respect user???s system preference (prefers-color-scheme).

**Acceptance Criteria:**

- Toggle button is accessible and works across all devices.
- Dark and light modes apply consistently across all pages and components.
- Theme preference persists after page reloads and navigation.
- Navbar, footer, modals, and other UI components adapt correctly in both themes.

**Links:**
- DevRel Program Website: https://devrel.keploy.io/
- Tailwind Dark Mode Docs: https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode
- Example UI Component: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/switch

**Notes:**

- Ensure that the global layout (layout.tsx) handles theme switching cleanly.
- Reusable components (buttons, cards, headings) should support both light and dark variants.
- Toggle should feel consistent with the Keploy main website experience.

### Issue Description

If a DataFrame has its flags set with `allows_duplicate_labels=False` then `set_axis()` and `rename_axis()` raise due to intenal use of `inplace=True`.

### Expected Behavior

```
df.set_axis(labels=["a"])
   0
a  1

df.rename_axis("a")
   0
a   
0  1
```

https://github.com/wenyi5608/openvino.genai/blob/fcadd455b485db5ce1330e487077c99283bb3638/llm/chatglm_cpp/chatglm.cpp#L387

When the disk is full, the ov::serialize fails and file size is smaller than expected. However, it does not show any error message for that.

### What needs to be done?

To prepare proper error message to inform user about a problem

@mishra-18 I propose the problem is that `std::ofstream` doesn't throw exceptions by default, so `try/catch` won't help. summary.otherNotes: The ChatGLM application tries to write modified model into disk. When the disk is full, the ov::serialize fails and file size is smaller than expected. However, it does not show any error message for that.

issueDTO.title: Add support for TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE types to Presto functions
issueDTO.description:
### Description

The following are the UDF's that use TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE (Issue : #14633  ) . Quite a lot of these are simple and straightforward and great as beginner tasks. 


Functions that use TIME
-------------------------
1- date_trunc
2 - cast timestamp to time
3 - date_add
4 - date_diff
5 - millisecond
6 - second
7 - minute
8 - hour
9 - timePlusIntervalDayToSecond
10 - intervalDayToSecondPlusTime
11 - timePlusIntervalYearToMonth
12 - intervalYearToMonthPlusTime
13 - timeMinusIntervalDayToSecond
14 - timeMinusIntervalYearToMonth
15 - subtract
16 - equal
17 - notEqual, lessThan, lessThanOrEqual, greaterThan, greaterthanorEqual, between
18 - castToTimeWithTimeZone
19 - castToTimestamp
20 - castToBigint
21 - castToTimestampWithTimeZone
22 - hashCode
23 - xxHash64
24 - castToTime



Functions that use TIME WITH TIMEZONE
--------------------------------------

1. currentime
2. timeAtTimeZone
3. truncateTimeWithTimeZone
4. date_add
5. date_diff
6. millisecond
7. second
8. minute
9. hour
10. timeWithTimeZonePlusIntervalDayToSecond
11. timeWithTimeZonePlusIntervalYearToMonth
12. intervalDayToSecondPlusTimeWithTimeZone
13. intervalYearToMonthPlusTimeWithTimeZone
14. timeWithTimeZoneMinusIntervalDayToSecond
15. subtract
16. eq,neq, gt, gte, between etc
17. castToTime
18. castToTimestamp
19. castToTimestampWithTimeZone
20. hashCode
21. xxHash64
comments: cc: @anandamideShakyan @aditi-pandit @czentgr @mbasmanova @amitkdutta @majetideepak

cc: @peterenescu 

@mbasmanova  

I believe the simple ones are : 

1.  millisecond
2. second
3. minute
4. hour
5. eq , neq, lt , gt etc (for time, since time is stored as millisutc)
6. castToBigint
7. xxHash64

The timePlusInterval require you to be a little more careful , but doing one of those udf's should allow you to do all the rest of the them. 
The other thing to note is that the cast* functions have a little bit of departure from usual presto semantics (esp TIME with TIMEZONE) as per this issue : https://github.com/prestodb/presto/issues/25957

Working on: 
---
~~- [cast(time to bigint)](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14975) - landed
- Remove TIME Type from fuzzer - investigating where in fuzzer is trying to cast x to TIME
- 24 - castToTime - ip

BLOCKING:
    - [Add TimeIntermediateTypeTransform](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/issues/14969) - ip

---
Above blocking all the udf support for TIME due to fuzzer unsupported type TIME thus failing the fuzzer test, see discussion: https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967#issuecomment-3336801782
5 - [millisecond](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967) - blocked
6 - second  
7 - minute  
8 - hour  
3 - date_add  
4 - date_diff  
1- date_trunc  
2 - cast timestamp to time
15 - subtract  
16 - equal  
17 - notEqual, lessThan, lessThanOrEqual, greaterThan, greaterthanorEqual, between~~  
18 - castToTimeWithTimeZone  
19 - castToTimestamp  
~~20 - castToBigint~~
21 - castToTimestampWithTimeZone  
22 - hashCode  
23 - xxHash64  
etc.
cc @singcha

Working on adding support for

- ~timePlusIntervalDayToSecond~
- ~intervalDayToSecondPlusTime~
- ~timePlusIntervalYearToMonth~
- ~intervalYearToMonthPlusTime~
- ~timeMinusIntervalDayToSecond~
- ~timeMinusIntervalYearToMonth~

Additional Functions we may need to support:

*  `localtime`
*  `is_distinct_from`
*   `timezone_hour`
*   `timezone_minute`

cc: @kgpai

Hi @kgpai @mbasmanova @han-yan01 @pratikpugalia, I was away due to work and study, but would like to re-engage. 

I opened PR #15003 for scaffolding the TIME ??? TIME WITH TIME ZONE cast. I can rebase and move this into `CastExpr::castFromTime` if it???s still open. If it???s already taken, I???ll pick a smaller related item from #14939. 

I would appreciate staying aligned with the ongoing work.

repository.description: A composable and fully extensible C++ execution engine library for data management systems.
repository.name: velox

summary.main: Add support for TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE types to Presto functions
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires adding support for TIME and TIME WITH TIMEZONE types to Presto functions, and also requires working on the fuzzer test.
summary.attemptedFixes: The blocking issue is [Add TimeIntermediateTypeTransform](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/issues/14969). Some UDFs are blocked, such as [millisecond](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [second](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [minute](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [hour](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [date_add](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [date_diff](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [date_trunc](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [cast timestamp to time](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [subtract](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [equal](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [notEqual, lessThan, lessThanOrEqual, greaterThan, greaterthanorEqual, between](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [castToTimeWithTimeZone](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [castToTimestamp](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [castToBigint](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [castToTimestampWithTimeZone](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [hashCode](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), [xxHash64](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/14967), etc.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is blocked due to fuzzer unsupported type TIME. Some UDFs are simple and straightforward, such as millisecond, second, minute, hour, eq, neq, lt, gt, etc. The cast* functions have a little bit of departure from usual Presto semantics (esp TIME with TIMEZONE) as per this issue: https://github.com/prestodb/presto/issues/25957. Additional functions that may need to be supported include `localtime`, `is_distinct_from`, `timezone_hour`, and `timezone_minute`.

issueDTO.title: [X86][Clang] VectorExprEvaluator::VisitCallExpr / InterpretBuiltin - allow AVX512 kmov intrinsics to be used in constexp
issueDTO.description:
These wrap the __builtin_ia32_kmov* builtins, which are just NOPs used to create mask predicates
```
unsigned int _cvtmask16_u32 (__mmask16 a)
unsigned int _cvtmask32_u32 (__mmask32 a)
unsigned __int64 _cvtmask64_u64 (__mmask64 a)
unsigned int _cvtmask8_u32 (__mmask8 a)

__mmask64 _cvtu64_mask64 (unsigned __int64 a)
__mmask16 _cvtu32_mask16 (unsigned int a)
__mmask32 _cvtu32_mask32 (unsigned int a)
__mmask8 _cvtu32_mask8 (unsigned int a)
```
We still need very basic test coverage just to prove they work in constexpr
comments:
Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

issueDTO.title: strange box shows up on devuan

comments: if i press it dino dies.

I can reproduce seeing this box consistently on master on a clean Dino instance on **Linux Mint 22.2 x86_64** After setting up an account, if I receive or send a invite request I can see the empty reaction/reply box hovering just behind the input text box: Clicking it don't result in a crash in my case. It disappears after clicking out of it.

My guess is it's the `message_menu_box` constructor in [main/src/ui/conversation_content_view/conversation_view.vala](https://github.com/dino/dino/blob/e67b0807d4afd283bcab1acfcb083b3b0e111dd8/main/src/ui/conversation_content_view/conversation_view.vala#L66-L76).

issueDTO.title: Don't repeat already visible status text in tooltip
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Issue description -->

In the right sidebar user tooltips, we should show the status text only if one of the following is true:

1. The user list is displayed in the "Compact" style (i.e., the status text is hidden).
2. The status text is too long to fit and is abbreviated in the right sidebar.

<!-- Link to a message in the chat.zulip.org discussion. Message links will still work even if the topic is renamed or resolved. Link back to this issue from the chat.zulip.org thread. -->

CZO thread: [#feedback > buddy list click targets are unclear @ 💬](https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/channel/137-feedback/topic/buddy.20list.20click.20targets.20are.20unclear/near/2219185)

repository.description: Zulip server and web application. Open-source team chat that helps teams stay productive and focused.
repository.name: zulip

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to conditionally show status text in user tooltips in the right sidebar based on whether the user list is in 'Compact' style or the status text is too long to fit and is abbreviated in the right sidebar.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires implementing a conditional logic in the tooltip rendering to show status text only when the user list is in 'Compact' style or the status text is too long to fit and is abbreviated in the right sidebar.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue description mentions a plan to add logic to detect the current user list style setting, implement text truncation detection for status messages, update the tooltip rendering to conditionally include status text, and add appropriate tests for the new behavior.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about not repeating already visible status text in tooltips in the right sidebar. It should be shown only if the user list is in 'Compact' style or the status text is too long to fit and is abbreviated in the right sidebar. The issue has been claimed by @alya and others have also shown interest in working on it.

issueDTO.title: docs: add tutorial / how-to-guide for embedding time-series data, e.g., using causalCNNs
issueDTO.description:
We now have a bunch of new embedding nets to process sequential data, e.g., the CausalCNN or the TransformerEmbedding (see also #1499 #1494 #1512 )

It would be great to add a short how-to-guide for using these embeddings, e.g., using a well-known time-series model like the SIR or Lotka-Volterra. 

See also https://github.com/sbi-dev/sbi/pull/1499#issuecomment-2743020418 for inspiration.
comments: Hello! Can I work on this please !!

Hello @satwiksps , thanks for offering to work on this 🙏 

To get started, please have a look at our existing how-to-guides here: https://sbi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to_guide.html

and at the extended (quite long) tutorial here https://sbi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced_tutorials/04_embedding_networks.html

the how-to-guide should give a short explanation and actionable code so that user can move on quickly. Let's discuss here how the guide for the embedding nets could look like. 

Please have a look at our contribution workflow as well, it's here: https://sbi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html

let me know if you have any questions :)

Thanks, @janfb 

I have gone through the existing SBI documentation and tutorials, including the How-to guides, Advanced tutorial on embedding networks and the Contributing guide, to understand the structure, tone, and technical workflow of the docs.

Here???s my plan for this how-to guide:

I???ll add a new Jupyter notebook under docs/how_to_guide/ titled ???20_time_series_embedding.ipynb??? The goal is to provide a short, runnable example showing how to handle sequential simulator outputs with the new embedding networks introduced in PRs #1499 (CausalCNNEmbedding) and #1494 (TransformerEmbedding).

The notebook will:
- Use a simple SIR time-series simulator as the example.
- Demonstrate how to instantiate and use both CausalCNNEmbedding and TransformerEmbedding for sequential data.
- Integrate the chosen embedding into an NPE workflow (posterior_nn, simulate_for_sbi, train, and build_posterior).
- Briefly discuss when to prefer each embedding type (e.g., CNN for local patterns, Transformer for long-range dependencies).
- Follow the concise, example-oriented style of the existing how-to guides and link to the advanced embedding tutorial for deeper explanation.

I plan to include both embeddings in the same notebook, since they share the same workflow and purpose, and presenting them side-by-side will make it easier for users to compare their usage without repeating setup code. Once the notebook is complete, I???ll add it to the How-to guide index (index.rst) and verify that the docs build correctly with Sphinx.

If you approve I will be happy to continue with this work.

Hi all!

1) Unless there is a really good reason to do it, I would _not_ use the SIR simulator for a how-to guide (it is to much boilerplate code). I would prefer to just use `torch.randn`.
2) Keep the discussion to "when to prefer which embedding type) in the tutorials.

Thanks!
Michael

thanks for summary and plan @satwiksps, sounds good! 

Good point by @michaeldeistler , given that the how-to-guide should be quite concise, we shouldn't use the SIR here. We could really just use a simulator that returns `torch.randn(100)` or so, to mimic the format of a time series. 

We should also note that depending on the dimensionality of the data and the resulting dimensionality of the CNN or Transformer architectures, a GPU could be useful here. 

and the other point by Michael about the discussion of what to use when - yes, lets not do this in the how-to-guide to keep them concise.

Thanks, @janfb and @michaeldeistler for guiding me.

I will proceed with those adjustments:

- I will replace the SIR simulator with a simple function that returns synthetic time series data using `torch.randn()` to keep the guide minimal and focused on the embedding workflow.
- The notebook will demonstrate both CausalCNNEmbedding and TransformerEmbedding, showing how to integrate them with posterior_nn and NPE.
- I will remove the discussion about when to use which embedding type to keep it concise.

The notebook will demonstrate both CausalCNNEmbedding and TransformerEmbedding, and will be added to the How-to guide index and verified that the docs build correctly with Sphinx.

A GPU could be useful depending on the dimensionality of the data and the resulting dimensionality of the CNN or Transformer architectures.

issueDTO.title: CALM Copilot Chat - Voice Mode
issueDTO.description:
## Feature Proposal

### Target Project:
**CALM Copilot (Chat Mode)** ??? part of the **Architecture-as-Code** monorepo.

---

### Description of Feature:
Enable **voice interaction** for CALM Copilot Chat Mode by leveraging the **VS Code Speech** extension (`ms-vscode.vscode-speech`).  
This enhancement would allow architects to **speak** their CALM queries and receive **spoken responses**, extending the existing natural language capabilities of CALM Copilot Chat Mode into a true multimodal experience.

The goal is to **experiment with voice command usability** and produce a **user guide** explaining how to set up, use, and troubleshoot voice features within CALM.

---

### User Stories:
- **As an architect**, I want to speak to CALM Copilot so that I can query architectural models hands-free during design or review sessions.  
- **As a contributor**, I want to document the steps for enabling and configuring VS Code Speech with CALM Copilot so that users can easily adopt the feature.  
- **As a user**, I want CALM to optionally read responses aloud so that I can continue working without needing to monitor the chat window.

---

### Current Limitations:
CALM Copilot Chat Mode currently supports **text-based interaction only** within VS Code???s Copilot Chat interface.  
There is no mechanism for audio input (speech-to-text) or audio output (text-to-speech), limiting accessibility and hands-free use.

---

### Proposed Implementation:
- **Approach:**  
  Integrate **VS Code Speech** (published by Microsoft) into the CALM workflow. The extension provides both **speech-to-text** and **text-to-speech** features natively inside VS Code and is already compatible with **Copilot Chat**.  
  Users can activate the microphone directly in the chat input, or use push-to-talk commands to dictate queries to CALM.

- **Setup & Interaction Flow:**  
  1. User installs the **VS Code Speech** extension (`ms-vscode.vscode-speech`).  
  2. User configures their repository for [CALM Copilot Chat](https://github.com/finos/architecture-as-code/tree/main/cli#calm-copilot-chatmode)
  3. In CALM Copilot Chat mode, a **microphone icon** appears in the chat input.  
  4. The user can:       - Click the mic icon or press **Ctrl+I** / **Cmd+I** to start speaking.  
     - Dictate their command (e.g., ???Show me dependencies between the Kubernetes services???).  
     - CALM receives the transcribed text as a normal chat prompt.  
  4. Optionally, enable **text-to-speech** for CALM responses via VS Code settings.  

- **Technical Design Considerations:**  
  - No changes required to CALM APIs or chat infrastructure.  

- **Dependencies:**  
  - VS Code Speech extension (`ms-vscode.vscode-speech`)  
  - GitHub Copilot Chat integration  
  - VS Code 1.94 or later  

---

### Alternatives Considered:
1. **Custom VS Code extension** using Whisper, Azure Speech, or Google Cloud STT:  
   - More control, but increases maintenance complexity and external dependencies.  
2. **Browser-based speech APIs** (`SpeechRecognition`):  
   - Not viable; CALM runs inside VS Code, not the browser.  
3. **OS-level dictation (Win+H, macOS Dictation):**  
   - Works but lacks CALM-specific UX and integration.  

The VS Code Speech extension provides the most direct, maintainable solution ??? officially supported, local, and Copilot-compatible.

---

### Testing Strategy:
- **Functional Tests:**  
  - Confirm mic icon appears in Copilot Chat when CALM is active.  
  - Verify that speech input is transcribed correctly into chat.  
  - Validate that text-to-speech reads CALM responses aloud when enabled.  
- **Environment Tests:**  
  - Windows and macOS
  - Permissions: ensure microphone access prompt appears and works.  
- **Usability Tests:**  
  - Measure accuracy and latency of transcription.  
  - Test typical architecture-related queries to evaluate voice input effectiveness.  
- **Accessibility Tests:**  
  - Validate that voice interaction works with screen readers and standard accessibility settings.

---

### Documentation Requirements:
Create a new guide for using CALM Copilot in text and voice mode.

Include:
- Prerequisites (VS Code, Copilot Chat, VS Code Speech extension)  
- Enabling and configuring voice input/output  
- Example spoken commands and use cases  
- Keybindings reference (`Ctrl+I`, `Cmd+I`, etc.)  
- Troubleshooting:
  - Microphone permissions
  - Linux audio dependencies (`libasound`)
  - Keybinding conflicts  
- Optional settings (`accessibility.voice.*`)  

---

### Implementation Checklist:
- [ ] Review and approve design  
- [ ] Validate compatibility with CALM Copilot Chat Mode  
- [ ] Write and test usage guide  
- [ ] Publish documentation in `/docs`  
- [ ] Confirm performance and accessibility impact  
- [ ] Announce feature availability in release notes

---

### Additional Context:
- VS Code Speech Extension: [https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.vscode-speech](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.vscode-speech)  
- GitHub Copilot Chat Documentation
comments: @rocketstack-matt - I'll have a look at this. I have been trying out the Chatmode and will try out the Voice option too.
Thanks @gkaria feel free to assign this issue to yourself to avoid duplication.

> Thanks [@gkaria](https://github.com/gkaria) feel free to assign this issue to yourself to avoid duplication.

Looks like I don't have permissions to assign the issue.
Done

issueDTO.title: VCS webhook handler fails with 'No permissions provided for action delete' when processing GitHub events
issueDTO.description:
I had the described issue and asked Claude Code to fix it. 
It works now and I told him to summarize what he did in a issue. 
Please be advised that I did not review this. The preview builds now work though and I hope this is helpful to you guys. Thanks. 


## Bug Description

GitHub webhook events (PR opened, push, etc.) fail to trigger builds because the VCS controller's cleanup operations lack proper authorization context. The endpoint throws "No permissions provided for action 'delete'" errors when trying to delete `vcsCommentLocks` documents.

## Version
- **Appwrite Version:** 1.8.0
- **Affected Component:** Sites/VCS Integration (`app/controllers/api/vcs.php`)

## Impact
- **Severity:** Critical
- **Affected Feature:** Appwrite Sites preview deployments from GitHub PRs
- Builds never start when PRs are opened or updated
- Users see "Waiting for build to start..." indefinitely
- This breaks the entire Sites CI/CD workflow for GitHub integrations

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Set up Appwrite 1.8.0 with GitHub App integration
2. Connect a repository to an Appwrite Site
3. Open a pull request or push to a branch
4. GitHub sends webhook to `/v1/vcs/github/events`
5. Check Docker logs: `docker logs appwrite`

## Expected Behavior
- Webhook processes successfully
- Lock documents are created and cleaned up
- Build job is queued
- Preview deployment starts

## Actual Behavior
- Webhook processing fails with error:
```
[Error] Method: POST
[Error] URL: /v1/vcs/github/events
[Error] Type: Appwrite\Extend\Exception
[Error] Message: No permissions provided for action 'delete'
[Error] File: /usr/src/code/app/controllers/api/vcs.php
[Error] Line: 505
```
- Builds never start
- Preview deployments remain in "waiting" state

## Root Cause Analysis

**File:** `/usr/src/code/app/controllers/api/vcs.php`

The `/v1/vcs/github/events` endpoint has:
```php
->label('scope', 'public')
```

This means webhooks run without authenticated user context. However, the cleanup code in `finally` blocks attempts to delete `vcsCommentLocks` documents without bypassing authorization:

**Lines 169, 240, and 461:**
```php
} finally {
    $dbForPlatform->deleteDocument('vcsCommentLocks', $latestCommentId);
}
```

These should use `Authorization::skip()` like other administrative operations in the same file (e.g., lines 1375-1379 where installations and repositories are deleted).

## Proposed Fix

Wrap all three `deleteDocument('vcsCommentLocks', ...)` calls with `Authorization::skip()`:

```php
} finally {
    Authorization::skip(fn () => $dbForPlatform->deleteDocument('vcsCommentLocks', $latestCommentId));
}
```

**Affected Lines:**
- Line 169 (in PR comment update block)
- Line 240 (in branch comment update block)  
- Line 461 (in preview URL comment update block)

## Verification
After applying the patch and restarting the container, webhooks process successfully and builds start as expected.

## Additional Context
- The bug exists because the cleanup operations were not given the same authorization bypass as other administrative operations in the VCS controller
- The `vcsCommentLocks` collection is used for concurrency control to prevent race conditions when updating GitHub comments
- These are purely internal housekeeping operations that should always succeed regardless of user context

## Workaround
Manually patch the file in the running container:
```bash
docker exec appwrite sh -c "sed -i 's|\$dbForPlatform->deleteDocument('\''vcsCommentLocks'\''', \$latestCommentId);|Authorization::skip(fn () => \$dbForPlatform->deleteDocument('\''vcsCommentLocks'\''', \$latestCommentId));|g' /usr/src/code/app/controllers/api/vcs.php"
docker restart appwrite
```

**Root Cause:**

**Fixed Code:**

} finally {

issueDTO.title: Support multiple accelerators
issueDTO.description:
Qemu supports specifying several accelerators, in precedence order, so that one can specify a list of accelerators to use, and let qemu decide which is the one that can apply to the current context.
One such use-case would be for example templates that can be invoked in different contexts.

If using windows, we'd want to use WHPX, on Linux we'd want KVM, and something else (probably TCG) on other platforms.
Right now, the best way to support this would be to set the accelerator as an input variable, or to read it from the environment, then invoke Packer with the template, and use the appropriate accelerator for the platform.

What this issue suggests is adding a list of accelerators, in addition to the `accelerator` attribute we already have, in order to specify this list once, and have qemu pick which one applies to the current environment.

# Example configuration

```hcl
source "qemu" "test" {
  accelerators = ["whpx", "kvm", "tcg"]
}
[...]
```

This would yield a command such as `qemu-system-x86_64  -accel "whpx" -accel "kvm" -accel "tcg" [...]`, which in turn would lead to `qemu` trying each accelerator in succession, and picking the first one it supports in the current environment.

For example on a Linux x86_64 system:

```
qemu-system-x86_64: -accel whpx: invalid accelerator whpx
qemu-system-x86_64: falling back to KVM
[...]
```

Discussed in PR #119
comments:
FYI, you don't need to use a variable at all. Set `accelerator` to `none` and set all accelerators using `qemuargs`:

```
qemuargs = [
  ["-accel", "whpx"],
  ["-accel", "hvf"], 
  ["-accel", "kvm"],
  ["-accel", "tcg"],
]
```

QEMU will automatically pick the best/first option available.

repository.description: Packer plugin for QEMU Builder
repository.name: packer-plugin-qemu

summary.main: Support multiple accelerators for Qemu, allowing users to specify a list of accelerators to use and let Qemu decide which one applies to the current context.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Qemu supports specifying several accelerators, in precedence order. The accelerators should be specified in a list and QEMU will automatically pick the best/first option available.
summary.attemptedFixes: Using the `qemuargs` variable and setting all accelerators using `qemuargs`, or setting `accelerator` to `none` and setting all accelerators using `qemuargs`.
summary.otherNotes: Qemu supports specifying several accelerators, in precedence order. One such use-case would be for example templates that can be invoked in different contexts. QEMU will automatically pick the best/first option available.

issueDTO.title: [Tracker] Implement all `scipy.*` APIs in CuPy
issueDTO.description:
Implement GPU version of `scipy.*` functions in `cupyx.scipy.*` namespace.

This is a tracker issue that summarizes the implementation status of each SciPy public module in CuPy. See the [comparison table](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/reference/comparison.html#scipy-cupy-apis) for details.

## Legends

* 🥚 Module not yet available in CuPy.
* 🐥 Module available in CuPy but coverage needs improvement.
* :shipit: Module available in CuPy and major features are implemented (may still have a few unimplemented APIs).
* ??? Out of scope.

## List of Modules

- 🥚 Clustering package (`scipy.cluster`)
    - 🥚 K-means clustering and vector quantization (`scipy.cluster.vq`) (#5947)
    - 🥚 Hierarchical clustering (`scipy.cluster.hierarchy`) (#3434)
- 🥚 Constants (`scipy.constants`)
- :shipit: Discrete Fourier transforms (`scipy.fft`)
- :shipit: Legacy discrete Fourier transforms (`scipy.fftpack`) (note: deprecated, no further development planned)
- 🥚 Integration and ODEs (`scipy.integrate`) (#7019)
- :shipit: Interpolation (`scipy.interpolate`) (#7186)
- 🥚 Input and output (`scipy.io`)
    - 🥚 `scipy.io.arff`
    - 🥚 `scipy.io.matlab`
    - 🥚 `scipy.io.wavfile`
- 🐥 Linear algebra (`scipy.linalg`)
    - 🥚 Low-level BLAS functions (`scipy.linalg.blas`)
    - ??? `scipy.linalg.cython_blas`
    - 🥚 Low-level LAPACK functions (`scipy.linalg.lapack`) c.f. [`cupyx.lapack`](https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/main/cupyx/lapack.py)
    - ??? `scipy.linalg.cython_lapack`
    - 🥚 Interpolative matrix decomposition (`scipy.linalg.interpolative`)
- :shipit: Multidimensional image processing (`scipy.ndimage`)
- 🥚 Orthogonal distance regression (`scipy.odr`)
- 🥚 Optimization and root finding (`scipy.optimize`) (#6112)
- :shipit: Signal processing (`scipy.signal`) (#7403)
    - :shipit: `scipy.signal.windows` (#7404)
- :shipit: Sparse matrices (`scipy.sparse`)
    - :shipit: Sparse linear algebra (`scipy.sparse.linalg`)
    - 🐥 Compressed sparse graph routines (`scipy.sparse.csgraph`) (#2431)
- :shipit: Spatial algorithms and data structures (`scipy.spatial`) (#5946)
    - 🐥 Distance computations (`scipy.spatial.distance`) (#5946)
    - 🥚 Spatial transformations (`scipy.spatial.transform`)
- 🐥 Special functions (`scipy.special`) (note: planned to be backed by SciPy in future #8163)
- 🐥 Statistical functions (`scipy.stats`)
    - 🥚 Contingency table functions (`scipy.stats.contingency`) (note: RAFT could be used)
    - 🥚 `scipy.stats.distributions`
    - 🥚 Statistical functions for masked arrays (`scipy.stats.mstats`) (note: masked arrays unsupported in CuPy)
    - 🥚 Quasi-Monte Carlo submodule (`scipy.stats.qmc`)
    - 🥚 Random Number Generators (`scipy.stats.sampling`) (note: RAFT could be used)

**Note:** [Several modules in SciPy](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/dev/api-dev/array_api.html#currently-supported-functionality) such as `scipy.cluster.hierarchy` accepts CuPy ndarrays as inputs through the Array API standard.

### Starter Task

If you are new to CuPy and wondering where to start, here are some good first things to try. They are relatively simple and independent.

* APIs under [Statistical Functions](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/reference/comparison.html#statistical-functions) (`scipy.stats`)
* `scipy.sparse.block_diag` (#7058)
* `scipy.sparse.load_npz`
* `scipy.sparse.save_npz`
* `scipy.constants.*` (hint: most things except for methods can just be borrowed from SciPy)

## Steps to Contribute

1. Fork and star :star: the CuPy repository :wink:

1. Pick a function you want to work on from any of the modules listed above. You can find the function in the [SciPy API Reference](https://scipy.github.io/devdocs/reference/index.html) to understand what should be implemented. If you want to work on new modules (🥚), first discuss with us on this issue.

1. Implement a function in your branch. If you need help, join [Gitter](https://gitter.im/cupy/community) or just ask for help in this issue.

1. Don't forget to write a test code!

1. Build CuPy and run tests to confirm that the function runs fine:
  `pip install -e . && pytest tests/cupyx_tests/scipy_tests/PATH_TO_YOUR_TEST`
   See the [Contribution Guide](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/contribution.html#unit-testing) for details.

1. Submit a pull-request to the `main` branch.

Note that you will need a GPU environment to develop CuPy.

See also: NumPy API Tracker Issue #6078

This is brilliant and interesting! I am Pranav, developer @lfortran, we are trying to compile scipy using LFortran, we are very close, almost got `scipy.special.specfun` working. I wish to ask, if we (cupy contributors) are translating fortran implementation present in SciPy to make it use `cupy` apis, right?

Hi @Pranavchiku! Yes, we are rewriting SciPy code into CUDA C/C++. You'll get the idea by exploring our code base under `cupyx/scipy`: 
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/tree/main/cupyx/scipy/special

> Note that you will need a GPU environment to develop CuPy.

Do we need explicit GPU environment, or integrated GPUs work? By integrated I mean Apple GPU that is available with mac m1, m2, etc. chips.

Discrete GPUs are required, currently we support CUDA and HIP (for AMD).
https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/overview.html

Hey, I need non-batched BLAS functions for what I'm working on, so I will be working on implementing those in the near future. Just wondering if there are any thoughts on a best-practices for implementing these.

<details>
  <summary>Roughly how I imagine using these functions (collapsible code section):</summary>
  
  ```py
@jit.rawkernel(device=True)
def square(a):
    matrix2 = cupyx.jit.local_memory(float, (2, 2)) #I'll also try implementing multi-dimensional local/shared arrays
    matrix2[0][0] = a
    matrix2[1][1] = a
    return cupyx.scipy.linalg.det(matrix2) #can be used in device functions

@jit.rawkernel()
def elementwise_2_x_squared(x, size): #computes 2*x^2, toy example which uses linalg functions
    tid = jit.grid(1)
    ntid = jit.gridsize(1)

    matrix = cupyx.jit.local_memory(float, (2, 2))

    for i in range(tid, size, ntid):
        stored_val = x[i]
        x[i] = square(stored_val)
        matrix[0][0] = stored_val
        matrix[1][1] = stored_val
        x[i] += cupyx.scipy.linalg.det(matrix) #can be used inside raw kernel

c = cp.array([1., 2.])
elementwise_2_x_squared((256,), (256,), (c, 2))
print(c) #should return [2., 8.]
  ```
</details>

The main use case I have is roughly: I have a large array of scalar values (could be hundreds of millions). For each value, I need to generate a (potentially not small) matrix, solve it, and then use the result to compute a scalar output value. For batched code, I would need to store these matrices altogether (potentially hundreds of GB memory - not feasible), while for non-batched, dynamically generated matrices, the memory requirements would just be the scalar values.

Hey all, I was always willing to contribute here and I have my first PR https://github.com/cupy/cupy/pull/8305 opened that ports `scipy.stats.kstat`. I do not have access to GPUs hence have not tested locally, I followed `boxcox_llf` and it was fun and easy :)

> It seems possible to mark `scipy.interpolate`, `scipy.signal` and `scipy.signal.windows` as :shipit: now?

Good catch! Updated the list :shipit:

> Also, I wonder if the comparison table (super-useful BTW!) , https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/comparison.html#scipy-cupy-apis is updated automatically on a release, or is it manual?

[`latest`](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/reference/comparison.html#scipy-cupy-apis) page is updated automatically for each commit merged into main branch. [`stable`](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/comparison.html#scipy-cupy-apis) page is updated automatically for each stable (v13.*) release.

> Would be great to remove SciPy deprecated items (signal.cmplx_sort, windows from scipy.signal namespace, linalg.tri{l,u} etc)

The page is generated with this tool. Deprecated items are currently listed in `footnotes` section to describe why we don't implement them.
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/1aa70f0de8c78afcfa503837d9baee3d80af4bc8/docs/source/_comparison_generator.py#L206-L207

> Hey all, I was always willing to contribute here and I have my first PR #8305 opened that ports `scipy.stats.kstat`. I do not have access to GPUs hence have not tested locally, I followed `boxcox_llf` and it was fun and easy :)

Hi @Pranavchiku, thank you for your interest in contributing! We, however, would like to kindly ask all contributors to build and test the branch before submitting a pull request. I understand that there are situations where access to GPUs is difficult but in that case please consider using offerings such as Google Colab.

Thanks @kmaehashi A couple of comments, now that I looked at this tracker a bit more:

- With `KDTree` and `Delaunay` implemented, maybe `scipy.spatial` is fair to be marked as :shipit:, too. Submodules (`spatial.transform` and `spatial.distance` might be a separate story, don't have an opinion)
- `scipy.linalg.{blas, lapack}` are unlikely to be implemented at all, correct? 
- even more so for `scipy.linalg.cython_{blas,lapack}`. Maybe even add an "out of scope" type symbol, ??? or some such?
- `scipy.io` --- is there an appetite for ever adding functionality for reading from matlab to CuPy? I suppose using scipy.io followed by `cupy.asarray` is the way, is it?
- Several SciPy subpackages support CuPy array inputs via Array API, e.g. `scipy.cluster`. It might be nice to show these too here?

Thanks for the suggestions @ev-br!

> * With `KDTree` and `Delaunay` implemented, maybe `scipy.spatial` is fair to be marked as :shipit:, too. Submodules (`spatial.transform` and `spatial.distance` might be a separate story, don't have an opinion)

Absolutely, marked :shipit:!

> * `scipy.linalg.{blas, lapack}` are unlikely to be implemented at all, correct?

Can't really say they are unlikely at all, as we have non-public (undocumented) [`cupyx.lapack`](https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/main/cupyx/lapack.py) module. I think we can say they're considered low-priority, though.

> * even more so for `scipy.linalg.cython_{blas,lapack}`. Maybe even add an "out of scope" type symbol, ??? or some such?

Sounds great, marked ???.

> * `scipy.io` --- is there an appetite for ever adding functionality for reading from matlab to CuPy? I suppose using scipy.io followed by `cupy.asarray` is the way, is it?

I began to wonder if I could delete it from the list, as the audience is very limited compared to NumPy's I/O routines (e.g., `cupy.load` which we implemented by wrapping `numpy.load`).

> * Several SciPy subpackages support CuPy array inputs via Array API, e.g. `scipy.cluster`. It might be nice to show these too here?

Nice, added a link to the Array API support docs!

@kmaehashi hi, first time contributor here.  I've just implemented a vectorized version of scipy.optimize.bvls (bounded value least squares, called through scipy.optimize.leastsq with method='bvls') for an astronomical data pipeline.  `lsq_linear` solves the least squares problem
```        
        minimize 0.5 * ||A x - b||**2
        subject to lb <= x <= ub
```
Where A has dimensions (i,j); b has dimension (i) and x has dimension (j).  My implementation vectorizes this to solve N identical shape matrices by making A => (N,i,j); b => (N, i) and x => (N, j) where a speed gain is obtained for larger N of at least a few hundred.

I would love to contribute this to CuPy but wanted to check first since you don't seem to have a `cupyx.scipy.optimize` module which is where I think it should go to mirror scipy.  Note I have not implemented the `trf` or `lsmr` algorithms within `lsq_linear` so these return currently a `NotImplementedError` and only BVLS is implemented.  Cheers!
There is some discussion about `cupyx.scipy.optimize` in issue: https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/6112

So... CuPy may be the wrong solution for my needs, but I have an array floats of len ~ 500,000 with a variable number (0.00001% to 10%) of 'affected' vs. 'normal' samples (about 10k of them). I want to run the permutation test on this large array, and it's taking minutes for as few as 1k permutations... I get the feeling I should rather sub-sample the normals and then permute them, but how many sub-samples do I take, etc....

Long story short, I'd like to implement [scipy.stats.permutation_test](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.permutation_test.html) in CuPy! Since you said to ask here first... here I am ;-)

Perhaps I can get away with just using CuPy arrays and passing 'native' scipy.stats.permutation_test a cupy function as the callable statistic? e.g. [cupy.ndarray.mean](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/generated/cupy.ndarray.html#cupy.ndarray.mean)?

I guess I should try that first 😂

Several mentions of [RAFT](https://github.com/rapidsai/raft) above. I can't figure out if that's useful for me or not.

Most SciPy stats functions are being made array API compatible, so CuPy does not need to re-implement them. There are a few that we might ask for CuPy to implement because they cannot be implemented in terms of array API operations and common special functions, but `permutation_test` is probably not one of them.

> Perhaps I can get away with just using CuPy arrays and passing 'native' scipy.stats.permutation_test a cupy function as the callable statistic

You'll need to wrap it so it returns a NumPy array, but yes - if computing the statistic function is the bottleneck, that will probably speed things up.

> > Perhaps I can get away with just using CuPy arrays and passing 'native' scipy.stats.permutation_test a cupy function as the callable statistic
> 
> You'll need to wrap it so it returns a NumPy array, but yes - if computing the statistic function is the bottleneck, that will probably speed things up.

Maybe I misunderstood what you mean't by 'wrap'... If I try to pass cupy arrays into permutation test, it immediately complains:

    TypeError: Implicit conversion to a NumPy array is not allowed. Please use `.get()` to construct a NumPy array explicitly.

Seems there is no speed improvement over numpy on simple 'wrapped' statistics:

```python

def compare_ttest_permu(rp_scores_np: np.ndarray, rn_scores_np: np.ndarray) -> None:
    for n_resamples in [10, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000, 5000, 10000]:
        print(f"PERM : {n_resamples}")

        res = permutation_test(
            (rp_scores_np, rn_scores_np),
            statistic=mean_ind_cp,
            permutation_type="independent",
            n_resamples=n_resamples,
            alternative="two-sided",
            vectorized=True,
        )

def mean_ind_cp(x: cp.ndarray, y: cp.ndarray, axis=0):
    cp_x = cp.array(x)
    cp_y = cp.array(y)

    return cp.mean(cp_x, axis=axis) - cp.mean(cp_y, axis=axis)
```

I am wondering how straightforward it would be to implement the modified Bessel function from scipy analogous to what was done for the standard Bessel function here? https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/3ce2a11076db8ec26bd2a9ec617d0a1806b69951/cupyx/scipy/special/_bessel.py

It seems like this may involve a relatively straightforward port to get scipy.special.iv for real-valued inputs? This would be helpful for some work I am doing involving Poisson processes and von Mises distributions. 

I guess the most difficult bit is that the AMOS zbesi routines are in forchan?

Oops, I missed [this ](https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/6324#issuecomment-2387020800) @dbolser.

> Seems there is no speed improvement over numpy on simple 'wrapped' statistics:

I wrote "if computing the statistic function is the bottleneck, that will probably speed things up.". It looks like computing the statistic function was not the bottleneck.

>  If I try to pass cupy arrays into permutation test, it immediately complains:

`permutation_test` hasn't been made CuPy-compatible yet; I was suggesting wrapping the statistic as a possibility that might help in the meantime. 

But functions that have been made fully-compatible do show a speedup. For instance, see 15~50x speedup in `stats.monte_carlo_test` in scipy/scipy#20604. 

The difficulty with `permutation_test` and some other functions is random number generation (e.g. see scipy/scipy#20549). It's easy to make it work with CuPy, but we're waiting until there is an answer that works for several array API libraries. I'm going to let others figure this out (e.g. data-apis/array-api-extra/#308), but once we have a common interface, it shouldn't be too long before the other resampling methods are array API compatible.

@njwfish It will be straightforward when array libraries start to use https://github.com/scipy/xsf for their special functions. The idea is that SciPy and other libraries can all rely on the same code, which will work on both CPU and GPU.

Okay that is helpful to understand, thank you! If I just need to implement iv in cupy for a project can I do that using xsf? Just so I am not bottlenecked on more general integration? It seems the relevant implementations are ported over in the AMOS dir?

> > If I just need to implement iv in cupy for a project can I do that using xsf?
> 
> [@steppi](https://github.com/steppi) can you take this one? Is XSF ready for use in CuPy? Would the best thing be for the user to open a PR on CuPy, or can they just take from XSF?
> 
> I see [gh-8140](https://github.com/cupy/cupy/pull/8140), but I image you'd want to add XSF as a submodule/subpackage and use those files directly?

`xsf` has landed as a submodule here, https://github.com/cupy/cupy/pull/9159. We don't have a GPU friendly `iv` implementation yet though, but it's something I've wanted to work on.

Oh, congratulations! That's a milestone!
Is making the `iv` implementation GPU-friendly a mechanical procedure, or would it require quite a bit of rework?

> Oh, congratulations! That's a milestone! Is making the `iv` implementation GPU-friendly a mechanical procedure, or would it require quite a bit of rework?

It would be nontrivial. The AMOS implementation relies on keeping track of state to evaluate unstable recurrences with a backwards algorithm. There are papers about GPU efficient implementations. If I had time to devote to research, developing GPU efficient special function implementations would probably be what I'd want to be working on right now.

I also miss `scipy.linalg.solve()` with the options to give information about the matrix properties (Symmetric, Positive Definite, Triangular, Banded, etc...).

Could that be added or should I add a specific issue?

Re: https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/6324#issuecomment-2355662005, scipy/scipy#23772 just merged, adding support for CuPy and other arrays to `permutation_test`.

A fair amount of what we can reasonably translate to array API in `scipy.stats` is done or is in the works; see scipy/scipy#20544 for progress.

Resolving gh-3849 would be a huge help towards this effort. There are a lot of functions that don't/won't work with CuPy arrays because of that.

issueDTO.title: feat: change the return result for PageRank from GraphFrame to DataFrame
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
At the moment all the algorithms from `lib` return `DataFrame` and only `PageRank` returns a new `GraphFrame` where `vertices` has an additional column.

**Describe the solution you would like**
1. Add an argument to PySpark wrappers like `legacy_mode: bool` that is true by default to avoid breaking changes
2. Based on this argument, if legacy mode we are returning from PageRank a `GraphFrame`, but if it is false only a DataFrame of scores
3. Raise a deprecation warning if the `legacy_mode` is true with a messages that in future version PageRank will return only DataFrame with scores
4. Add the same argument to scala parts

**Component**

<!-- If you do not know what components is it leave empty -->

- [x] Scala Core Internal
- [x] Scala API
- [x] Spark Connect Plugin
- [ ] Infrastructure
- [x] PySpark Classic
- [x] PySpark Connect

**Additional context**

We can plan it for the future 1.0 release to follow a semantic versioning. Feel free to ask me about details.

**Are you planning on creating a PR?**

- [x] I'm willing to make a pull-request

issueDTO.title: Firefox CPU energy measurements missing from detailed page results
issueDTO.description:
### Feature/improvement

issueDTO.title: Support for PostgreSQL schema in @voltagent/postgres
issueDTO.description:
## Feature Request

The `@voltagent/postgres` library currently does not support configuring or interacting with PostgreSQL schemas. Supporting schema features would allow users to organize their tables more effectively and integrate with existing PostgreSQL setups that utilize multiple schemas.

### Expected behavior
- Ability to specify a schema for queries and table creation.
- Functions for managing tables within a specific schema.
- Configuration options to set the default schema.

### Benefit
Adding schema support would make the library more adaptable for advanced PostgreSQL applications and accommodate more complex database organization strategies.

My original meaning is that these tables are managed by an independent schema. Instead of using the default public.

issueDTO.title: MudDatePicker allows entering dates outside Min/MaxDate range when Editable is true
issueDTO.description:
### Bug type

Component

### Component name

MudDatePicker

### What happened?

Currently MudDatePicker with `Editable="true"` and with one of the following properties set: `MinDate` / `MaxDate` / `FixYear` / `FixMonth` / `FixDay` allows to enter incorrect values using keyboard.

I believe that it is a bug for `MinDate` and `MaxDate` properties, because for example `MudNumericField.Min/Max` obviously don't allow incorrect values. This is why I am reporting an error.

I don't know if it is a bug for `FixYear`, `FixMonth`, and `FixDay` properties.

Note: Currently I categorized `FixYear`, `FixMonth`, and `FixDay` properties to the "Picker behavior" group. If it is a bug, then after it is fixed, the `FixYear`, `FixMonth`, and `FixDay` properties can be categorized to the "Validation" group. I categorized `MinDate`, and `MaxDate` to the "Validation" group. See https://github.com/MudBlazor/MudBlazor/pull/3413 pull request.

### Expected behavior

The `MinDate` and `MaxDate` properties don't allow to enter incorrect values by keyboard.

### Reproduction link

https://try.mudblazor.com/snippet/caQFlPGjqkazvvIW

### Reproduction steps

1. Open https://try.mudblazor.com/snippet/caQFlPGjqkazvvIW
2. Enter an incorrect value using a keyboard
3. The incorrect value is stored in `date1` or `date2` field.


### Relevant log output

_No response_

### Version (bug)

6.0.2

### Version (working)

_No response_

### What browsers are you seeing the problem on?

Chrome

### On what operating system are you experiencing the issue?

Windows

- [ ] I would like to do a Pull Request

- [X] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Change external notification defaults
issueDTO.description:
### Platform

Cross-Platform

### Description

Only alert for bells by default and not on regular messages, change the alert duration to only 5 seconds instead of the excruciatingly long 60s.
comments: Or maybe just disable it for everything but dms

https://github.com/meshtastic/protobufs/pull/727

Protobuf exists, needs firmware implementation
My vote is disable entirely except for DMs
5 seconds, DMs
Started implementing this, i'm limited in my skills but i adjusted the default nag time: [Pull request here](https://github.com/meshtastic/firmware/pull/7946)

> [meshtastic/protobufs#727](https://github.com/meshtastic/protobufs/pull/727)
> 
> Protobuf exists, needs firmware implementation

I struggle to fully understand the difference between buzzer_mode and the external notification settings.
It would make more sense to me, if there is an additional button in external notification, where you can check "Alert DMs" (or a toggle between all messages and DMs).
So you could separately switch off messages, bells and DMs.

---

> Buzzer is enabled only for direct messages and alerts
> https://github.com/meshtastic/protobufs/pull/727

I am not sure if "alerts" here mean the alarm bell? There seem to be different names for the bell in the source code, sometimes it is called bell (`containsBell`), sometimes it is alert (`isAlert`)? I implemented this as if alert means bell (though in my tests this fells on the bell character, not sure yet why, not changed any code there. I tested only with the iOS bell character/alert button though).

---

I implemented it this way:
If `buzzer_mode == 4` (`DIRECT_MSG_ONLY`) and `alert_messages_buzzer` is on - then only buzz on DMs.
Is this the way you wanted it to be? Then I could create a pull request for it.

Btw: The only menu I found to change the buzzer_mode is in baseUI, neither in webclient nor in iOS I could find the option. I tested my changes with meshtastic-cli (`meshtastic --set device.buzzer_mode 4`).
This issue has not had any comment or update in the last month. If it is still relevant, please post update comments. If no comments are made, this issue will be closed automagically in 7 days.

summary.attemptedFixes: The author implemented a solution where if buzzer_mode is set to DIRECT_MSG_ONLY and alert_messages_buzzer is on, it will only buzz on DMs. They tested this with meshtastic-cli.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to external notification defaults, specifically changing the default alert duration to 5 seconds and only alerting for DMs. There is also a discussion about the difference between buzzer_mode and external notification settings. The author implemented a solution and is asking for feedback before creating a pull request.

issueDTO.title: Use f-string and `{var_name=}` instead of `.format` and `var_name={var_name}`
issueDTO.description:
> [!NOTE]
> Please also take a look at the other good-first issues as well:
> - https://github.com/optuna/optuna/issues/4508
> - https://github.com/optuna/optuna/issues/6029

### Motivation

Now that Optuna does not support Python 3.8 anymore, we can use the `{var_name}=` syntax.
Since it is cleaner, I recommend using it instead of the good old style.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> To promote more contributions from a wide range of developers, please address only one file per PR:)

### Suggestion

Please fix one of the files below:
- https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aoptuna%2Foptuna+%22.format&type=code&p=2

Example:

```python
## Current
message = "The `value` argument is of type '{}' but supposed to be a float.".format(
    type(value).__name__
)

## Preferred
message = f"The `value` argument is of type '{type(value).__name__}' but supposed to be a float."

## Current
if reduction_factor < 2:
    raise ValueError("`reduction_factor >= 2` must hold but got reduction_factor={}.".format(reduction_factor))

## Preferred
if reduction_factor < 2:
    raise ValueError(f"`reduction_factor >= 2` must hold but got {reduction_factor=}.")
```

### Additional context (optional)

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Implement Shift+Arrow to select cell range
issueDTO.description:
With a cell selected in a sheet, try the following keyboard shortcuts:

- <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Up</kbd>
- <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Down</kbd>
- <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Left</kbd>
- <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Right</kbd>

These keyboard shortcuts should grow/shrink a cell selection range. But they don't yet work.

In your browser console, notice a log message like this:

> Sheet selection resizing is not yet implemented

I had previously set up the event handlers for this shortcut but not finished implementing the selection mutation. This should be a pretty straightforward task for someone to pick up from here.

At the bottom of `SheetSelection.ts`, you can find the code location for this log statement. Finish implementing the `resized` method, as described in the comment. Play with Google Sheets to get a good understanding of how <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Arrow</kbd> keys work. Pay particular attention to the (literal!) edge cases when the selection has reached the edge of the sheet.
comments: Is is it possible to assign me this issue i want to work on it.
Hi @radheshpai87 we don't formally assign issues but you are welcome to start working on this!

I've implemented this feature and submitted a pull request: #4962 
Please review when convenient, and let me know if further changes are needed!

issueDTO.title: Help test alpha, beta, and rc builds!
issueDTO.description:
Testing new software builds is one of the easiest ways to get started helping CircuitPython development.

First, find an existing project of yours that works with [the latest stable release of CircuitPython](https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython/releases/latest). Verify that it all still works as you've set it up.

Next, load a cutting edge build from [here](https://adafruit-circuit-python.s3.amazonaws.com/index.html).

Now, see if your project works as it did before.  If it doesn't work, then look and see if there are [open issues](https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython/issues) related to it. If there is, its likely that it intentionally doesn't work now. If there are no unrelated issues, then [please file one](https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython/issues/new)!

In the new issue please include a list of all components you are using and the code that you are trying to run on the new version. Someone else will respond with whether its expected or whether it is in fact a bug.

summary.otherNotes: Testing new software builds is one of the easiest ways to get started helping CircuitPython development. Verify existing projects work with the latest stable release and load cutting edge builds to test compatibility. If issues arise, file a new issue with component list and code.

issueDTO.title: Help answer questions!
issueDTO.description:
Although you consider yourself a CircuitPython beginner, its likely you already know something that other folks do not! Please share that knowledge!

There are a few places where people post questions and could use a helpful answer.

* [Adafruit CircuitPython Forums](https://forums.adafruit.com/viewforum.php?f=60)
* [Adafruit Discord](https://adafru.it/discord)
* [GitHub issues](https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython/issues)

If you cannot answer a question yourself and its been a few days since its been asked, then please join [Discord](https://adafru.it/discord) and mention `@circuitpython helpers` with a link to the question so someone else can help answer it.
comments: Is there a difference in use or audience between the forums and the discord instance?
In my experience, discord is far more interactive and depending on time of day there are several people willing and able to help.

@larsks Discord can certainly be more interactive. One of the major differences between Discord and the forums is that Discord is primarily community driven and the forums have official Adafruit Support people available to answer questions. There is a little overlap with some of those people, but not much. We consider Discord to be faster, but with potentially less applicable responses, and the forums to be slower but with consistently more applicable responses. As well, in the event that you have an actual hardware issue requiring a replacement, your issue must go through the forums to reach that conclusion.

issueDTO.title: Firefox 115.29.0esr rendering broken
issueDTO.description: Started happening today, most likely a regression from https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues/1752 Firefox 115.29.0esr on MacOS 10.14.6 (old HW).
comments:
There's a [note at the top](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/blob/42b2030f59e7277060f994d0eb60133704c559d3/app/assets/stylesheets/application.css#L3-L8) of our `application.css` saying `Lobsters doesn't use CSS features until the "Widely available" Baseline standard`. Because our audience is programmers who love running odd devices or even developing their own browsers, we try to be conservative about what browser features we depend on. It looks like [Popover is Baseline 2025](https://caniuse.com/wf-popover), not "Widely Available".

I checked and misread this. I thought the JS API was too recent but the HTML attributes met our standards. We'll have to change our approach. @fedemp, I'm sorry I didn't catch this when you suggested popover to avoid wasting your time.

Secondarily, we should look into whether there's a linter we can use to programmatically catch these. It's a well-worn joke that programmers don't read docs, but a comment at the top of the file isn't effective.

summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is related to the 'Widely available' Baseline standard, and the requirement is to be conservative about what browser features are used.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author, tomek82, has tried to install ESR 115 and found a possible solution to remove support for caches in some browsers, which involves hiding all dropdowns and then reverting the display for browsers that understand the :open selector.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about rendering broken in Firefox 115.29.0esr on MacOS 10.14.6 (old HW), possibly due to a regression from https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues/1752. The author, tomek82, has tried to install ESR 115 and found a possible solution to remove support for caches in some browsers.

issueDTO.title: [Clang] Explain satisfaction failure for more type traits
issueDTO.description:
Last week, we added the scaffolding for clang to explain _why_ a standard type trait is not satisfied - when used either in a `static_assert` or as atomic constraint, in `Sema::DiagnoseTypeTraitDetails` (#141238)

https://gcc.godbolt.org/z/xb7PcxzTx

So far, this has only been done for `std::is_trivially_relocatable`.

There are plenty of type traits that could benefit from additional diagnostics
https://eel.is/c++draft/type.traits#meta.type.synop 

I figure adding support for more type traits (one at a time!) could be a good first issue, and it's always nice to improve our diagnostics.
comments:
Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

@llvm/issue-subscribers-clang-frontend

Author: cor3ntin (cor3ntin)

<details>
Last week, we added the scaffolding for clang to explain _why_ a standard type trait is not satisfied - when used either in a `static_assert` or as atomic constraint, in `Sema::DiagnoseTypeTraitDetails` (#<!-- -->141238)

https://gcc.godbolt.org/z/xb7PcxzTx

So far, this has only been done for `std::is_trivially_relocatable`.

There are plenty of type traits that could benefit from additional diagnostics
https://eel.is/c++draft/type.traits#meta.type.synop 

I figure adding support for more type traits (one at a time!) could be a good first issue, and it's always nice to improve our diagnostics. 
</details>

issueDTO.title: Support customized entry types in BibliographyConsistencyCheck
issueDTO.description:
(This is a follow-up to #13584)

We have a library consistency check for checking whether fields in a set of entries are set/unset consistently. Currently, this is aware of the difference of BibTeX and BibLaTeX, but not [Custom Entry Types](https://docs.jabref.org/setup/customentrytypes) 

??? This is a good excercise to learn test-driven development and using a data model. This issue cannot be solved with an AI. You really have to think though BibTeX and BibLaTeX for yourself! Take this issue only if you are willing to invest significant time. ???

Example entry - from https://dblp.org/rec/journals/sqj/IftikharBAK25.html

```bibtex
@article{DBLP:journals/sqj/IftikharBAK25,
  author       = {Umar Iftikhar and
                  J{\"{u}}rgen B{\"{o}}rstler and
                  Nauman Bin Ali and
                  Oliver Kopp},
  title        = {Supporting the identification of prevalent quality issues in code
                  changes by analyzing reviewers' feedback},
  journal      = {Softw. Qual. J.},
  volume       = {33},
  number       = {2},
  pages        = {22},
  year         = {2025},
  url          = {https://doi.org/10.1007/s11219-025-09720-9},
  doi          = {10.1007/S11219-025-09720-9},
  timestamp    = {Mon, 12 May 2025 21:02:32 +0200},
  biburl       = {https://dblp.org/rec/journals/sqj/IftikharBAK25.bib},
  bibsource    = {dblp computer science bibliography, https://dblp.org}
}
```

It contains `bibourl` and `bibsource`

One could make these two fields required.

```bibtex
@article{withBibSource,
  journal      = {Softw. Qual. J.},
  bibsource = {2025}
}

@article{withoutBibSource,
  journal      = {Softw. Qual. J.},
}
```

With the existing consistency check, `bibsource` is reported as `unknown`. If the entry type `article` is modified to have this as optional field, it is reported as optional.

## Task

- Modify `org.jabref.logic.quality.consistency.BibliographyConsistencyCheck` to use `org.jabref.model.entry.BibEntryTypesManager` instead of org.jabref.model.entry.types.BiblatexEntryTypeDefinitions#ALL

## Hints

- Do test-driven development. Start at`org.jabref.logic.quality.consistency.BibliographyConsistencyCheckTest`. Do not modify existing tests; add new ones.
- Look into `org.jabref.model.entry.BibEntryTypesManagerTest` for how to mock `BibEntryTypesManager`.
- Do not get confused with "library" and "database". User-facing we talk about "library", inside the code, we use "database", but mean "library".

Hello @koppor , I'm reviewing both `org.jabref.logic.quality.consistency.BibliographyConsistencyCheck.java` and its corresponding test file. I have a question regarding the usage behind `requiredFields` which is declared in the method `check`: https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/main/jablib/src/main/java/org/jabref/logic/quality/consistency/BibliographyConsistencyCheck.java#L105

The method javadoc says that it "does not check whether all required fields are present..." but the usage of the `requiredFields` variable seems to attempt this anyways. Even then, it doesn't seem to check it properly. It seems overly strict, requiring that all subfields of an `OrFields` should be present for an entry to be considered consistent. It does this by flattening the `OrFields` on line 143, and then filtering a filter operation using `requiredFields` on line 80.

From my understanding, at least one (not all) subfield(s) of an `OrFields` type should be present for that field's requirement to be satisfied.

I'm asking this question to confirm and improve my understanding of the class and how I can modify it for this PR

### Describe the solution you'd like

Move logic of `CoalesceAsyncExecInput` into `CoalesceBatches` and delete `CoalesceAsyncExecInput`

### Describe alternatives you've considered

If not possible then don't do this approach

### Additional context

_No response_

issueDTO.title: [2.0] Deprecate `array()` method of `p5.Vector`
issueDTO.description:
### Deprecate `array()` method of `p5.Vector`

Since p5.js 2.0 will offer a new way of getting and setting an array containing the components of a vector, `array()` may be deprecated. Note that this method has [instance](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/blob/39ea296ec08ddee96b88c3c65f8f31c95d6ef6d9/src/math/p5.Vector.js#L2956) and [static](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/blob/39ea296ec08ddee96b88c3c65f8f31c95d6ef6d9/src/math/p5.Vector.js#L3791) versions.

issueDTO.title: Add Your Profile on DevDisplay.
issueDTO.description:
Add Your Profile On DevDisplay

Steps to Add Your Profile

1. **Fork the repository:** To create a copy of the repository in your GitHub account, click on the "Fork" button in the top right corner of the project repository page. 2. **Navigate** to the **`public/data`** folder in your project directory. 3. **Create a new JSON file** named **`your_github_username.json`** (replace your_github_username with your actual GitHub username). Open the file you just created. 4. **Add** the following JSON object, replacing the placeholder values with your own details: ```json { "name": "Your Name", "location": "Your Location", "bio": "Your Bio should be 20-30 words not more than that", "avatar": "https://github.com/your-github-username.png", "portfolio": "Your Portfolio URL or Github URL", "skills": ["Your Skill 1", "Your Skill 2", "..."], "social": { "GitHub": "https://github.com/your-github-username", "Twitter": "https://twitter.com/your-twitter-username", "LinkedIn": "https://www.linkedin.com/in/your-linkedin-username", "Instagram": "https://www.instagram.com/your-instgram-username", "Email": "your-email-id", "Discord": "https://discord.com/users/your-discord-id", "LeetCode": "https://leetcode.com/your-leetcode-username", "Codeforces": "https://codeforces.com/profile/your-codeforces-username", "HackerRank": "https://www.hackerrank.com/your-hackerrank-username", "StackOverflow": "https://stackoverflow.com/users/your-stackoverflow-id", "YouTube": "https://www.youtube.com/c/your-youtube-channel", "DevTo": "https://dev.to/your-dev-profile", "Hashnode": "https://hashnode.com/@your-hashnode-username", "Behance": "https://www.behance.net/your-behance-profile", "Dribbble": "https://dribbble.com/your-dribbble-profile", "Figma": "https://www.figma.com/@your-figma-profile", "Replit": "https://replit.com/@your-replit-username", "BuyMeACoffee": "https://www.buymeacoffee.com/your-coffee-profile", "ProductHunt": "https://www.producthunt.com/@your-producthunt-profile", "Medium": "https://medium.com/@your-medium-profile", "Reddit": "https://www.reddit.com/user/your-reddit-username", "Unstop": "https://unstop.com/@your-unstop-username" } } ``` 5. **Save** the **`your_github_username.json`** file. 6. **Navigate** to the **`src`** folder in your project directory. Open the **`ProfilesList.json`** file. 7. **Add your JSON filename** (your_github_username.json) to the array of filenames in the ProfileList.json file, like this: ```json ["filename1.json", "filename2.json", "filename3.json", "your_github_username.json"] ``` 8. **Save** the **`ProfileLists.json`** file. 9. **Create Pull Request to contribute** 10. **Wait for review and merge:** Wait for the project maintainers to review and merge your PR. 11. **Need help?** You can take help from the video tutorial here: 📹 [How to Add Your Profile on DevDisplay](https://youtu.be/DAjartal2kQ)

Once your changes are merged Your profile will be displayed on the project's website and you will receive a personalized appreciation post through mail by DevDisplay Team.

---

Verify Your Developer Profile

Follow this step to get a blue tick on your developer profile



Add your minimum 5 projects
Add your Portfolio

Once these both are completed and reviewed ???
Your profile will be verified and proudly display a blue checkmark on DevDisplay!
