issueDTO.title: Project Idea Submission & Voting System 💌
issueDTO.description:
Add Idea Submission Features on the 👇🏻 https://www.devdisplay.org/IdeaSubmission

# **Description** Add the Project Idea Submission and Voting System to DevDisplay can make it a hub for innovation and collaboration. This feature allows users to submit ideas, vote on their favorites, and actively participate in bringing top-voted ideas to life through collaborative development. Here's a detailed overview of the feature, enhanced with functionalities to ensure engagement and utility. --- ## **Feature Workflow Overview** 1. **Idea Submission Window (First Week of Every Month):** - Allow users to submit their project ideas within the first week of every month. - Display a countdown timer on the homepage indicating the time left to submit ideas. - Ideas are displayed publicly for voting immediately after submission. 2. **Voting Phase (Throughout the Month):** - Users can like or upvote their favorite ideas to boost their ranking. - A **"Trending Now" Section** highlights the top-voted ideas dynamically. 3. **End-of-Month Selection (Final Week):** - At the end of the month, the top **1 most-voted idea** is selected for community implementation. - Recognize contributors with badges like **"Innovator of the Month"** for the selected idea. 4. **Community Collaboration (Next Month):** - The selected idea is moved to a **???Project Development Hub???** where the community collaborates to implement it. - Users can join specific tasks like design, development, testing, or documentation. --- ## **Detailed Features** ### **1. Idea Submission** - **Submission Form:** - **Title:** A short, engaging title for the idea. - **Description:** Provide details about the project, its purpose, and potential use cases. - **Tags:** Keywords for categorization (e.g., #AI, #Frontend, #OpenSource). - **Resources Needed:** Option to list the skills or tools required for implementation. - **Optional Media Uploads:** Attach images, mockups, or concept diagrams. - **Validation:** Ensure users can only submit one idea per month. ### **2. Voting System** - **Likes and Upvotes:** - Each idea has a like button and an upvote counter displayed prominently. - Limit each user to one vote per idea to ensure fair participation. - **Real-Time Leaderboard:** - Display top 5 trending ideas on the homepage dynamically. - Add a **"Voting Closes In"** timer to create urgency for participation. ### **3. Collaboration Hub for Top Ideas** Once an idea is selected: - **Task Board:** Break the project into smaller tasks (design, code, testing, etc.) and allow users to claim tasks based on their expertise. - **Role-Based Contributions:** Assign roles like Project Lead, Developer, Designer, Tester, etc., to contributors. - **Community Chatroom:** Add a real-time chat or discussion board for seamless collaboration. - **Progress Tracker:** Use a Kanban-style board to show progress and keep the community updated. ### **4. Rewards & Recognition** - **Innovator of the Month:** Recognize the user whose idea is selected with a badge and showcase them on the homepage. - **Contributor Highlights:** Display names of all contributors to the implemented project. - **Portfolio Integration:** Allow contributors to link their involvement to their profiles as achievements. ### **5. User-Friendly Discovery** - **Browse Ideas by Category:** Filter ideas by tags or categories (e.g., Web Development, Machine Learning). - **Search and Sort:** Allow sorting by trending, newest, or highest-voted ideas. - **Idea History:** Maintain an archive of past submitted ideas for inspiration. ### **6. Notifications** - Notify users about: - The start of the submission phase. - Voting deadlines and reminders. - Announcement of the selected idea. - Updates about the implementation phase. --- ## **Benefits for the Community** 1. **Encourages Innovation:** - Opens up a platform for users to pitch and develop creative ideas. 2. **Crowdsourced Validation:** - Community voting ensures the best ideas rise to the top. 3. **Skill Building:** - Participants gain hands-on experience in collaborative development. 4. **Community Recognition:** - Motivates users with badges, leaderboard rankings, and project credits. 5. **Stronger Collaboration:** - Encourages teamwork within the community, fostering connections and learning opportunities. --- ### 📬 Want to contribute? Comment below to get assigned! If you're picking this up, make sure to follow the contribution guidelines in the repository. **💡 Before diving in, make sure to:** ??? Add your profile to DevDisplay. ??? Star the repository to show your support and stay updated with new features! **🚨 This is the first & mandatory step in becoming a contributor.** --- #### **For More Details and Help** - **Join DevDisplay Discord Community**: [Discord Community](https://discord.gg/chyt2UgTv5) - Connect with other developers and collaborate on exciting projects. - **Reach Out to the Team**: - Company Email: team@devdisplay.org - Creator's Email: hellow.ashutosh@gmail.com - **Connect on Social Media**: - **GitHub Organization**: https://github.com/devdisplay - **LinkedIn**: https://www.linkedin.com/company/devdisplay/ - **Twitter**: https://x.com/devdisplay_ - **Instagram**: https://www.instagram.com/devdisplay/ --- ### **Thanks and Best Regards** The **DevDisplay Team** 💌 ---

issueDTO.title: Prefer display() over to_string_lossy() when showing paths
issueDTO.description:
Per the discussion in PR #5195, we inconsistently use `to_string_lossy()` or `display()` when showing paths to the user. As I understand it, we should use `display()` whenever showing paths to the user and `to_string_lossy()` when providing to APIs or saving to a datastore/logs.  

Discussion that seems relevant: https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/i-think-the-name-path-display-should-be-replaced-with-path-display-lossy/20713/10

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Document go.schedule.duration metric emitted by NewProducer in package documentation
issueDTO.description:
### Component

Instrumentation: runtime

### Problem Statement

https://pkg.go.dev/go.opentelemetry.io/contrib/instrumentation/runtime does not document `go.schedule.duration` emitted via `NewProducer`

### Proposed Solution

Document in https://pkg.go.dev/go.opentelemetry.io/contrib/instrumentation/runtime metrics emitted via both `Start` and `NewProducer`. Maybe it would be better to document those on function docs level instead of package level so that the reader is aware what metrics are produced by which functionality.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Prior Art

_No response_

### Additional Context

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Add command for archiving files (e.g. manifest)
issueDTO.description:
This would be a command for users to be able to (for example) update the manifest without completely overwriting it. 

The command would be a wrapper around [`nipoppy.utils.save_df_with_backup`](https://github.com/neurodatascience/nipoppy/blob/72e841a7ae7f459e076dfb6fc256f185094f2235/nipoppy_cli/nipoppy/utils.py#L254), which creates a hidden directory (e.g. `.manifests`) and copies the file in it (renamed with a timestamp), then possibly creates a symlink from the original path to the timestamped archived file, or delete the original file.

Since this is more of a utility (does not even need `--dataset-root` parameter), I wonder if it would make more sense to move this to another CLI (`nipoppy-utils`?).

issueDTO.title: Enable `clippy::unwrap_used` to better handle panics
issueDTO.description:
I think these restrictions should improve our code quality - i.e. we shouldn't panic (unless its a test).  To enable, modify root `Cargo.toml` and add these lines, and `just clippy` it...

```diff
 [workspace.lints.clippy]
 # Restrictions
 panic_in_result_fn = "warn"
 todo = "warn"
+unwrap_used = "warn"
 # Pedantics without being too noisy
 pedantic = { level = "warn", priority = -1 }
```

issueDTO.title: [Feature request] Support for multiple MVs (2DMV/3DMV) and corresponding full-length audio versions
issueDTO.description:
**Motivation.**
The current database structure does not fully support songs that have multiple music video (MV) types (e.g., 2DMV and 3DMV) and the display of the music video option is fully depend on whether there is a virtual singer version mv. This also leads to inaccuracies in tracking the corresponding full-length audio, as different MVs can have different full-length audio tracks, and the database currently only seems to track one "long version" per song.

**Related issue (if applicable)**
<!-- Is this request related to an issue or problem? -->

**Suggested Implementation**
1.  **Music Videos:** A single song version should be able to link to multiple distinct MV assets (e.g., one 3DMV and one 2DMV). Currently, the viewer often only displays one or none, even when both exist.
2.  **Music Audio:** The "long version" audio needs to be associated with its specific MV. Instead of a single "long version" track, the database should be able to store the full-length audio corresponding to the 3DMV and the full-length audio corresponding to the 2DMV.

**Additional context**
Example of this problem would be the song **????????? (Star) by Leo/need**: `https://sekai.best/music/570`
* For the **Sekai version**, this song has both a 3DMV and a 2DMV.
* The "long version" audio file currently in the database corresponds to the 3DMV.
* The 2DMV has its own unique, full-length audio track which is significantly longer than the 3DMV's "long version," but both its audio track and the mv is not currently represented in the database.
comments: May I know how the JSON files in sekai-master-db-diff are generated? I noticed that some contents seem to be missing, and there are some inconsistencies. And also I guess the missing of 3D MV is due to 3D MV feature is not done yet? I don???t really know whether we want playback of the official 3D MV or real-time rendering with custom clothing and people. @dnaroma

The master db is decoded from game data and should be complete. You can compare it with other sources. If there is really something missing or inconsistent please let me know. Sekai Viewer does not plan to support any 3D content. So 3D models are not extracted.

Alright, since the database is fully from the game, it seems there is no error with the data. I???m not sure whether it is necessary to add the official full-length 2D MV and official 3D MV on the music detail page, as it currently looks like some contents are missing. If adding them is not necessary, then this issue might be meaningless.
It is okay to support full length 2dmv since assets are extracted. 3dmv won't be added.

The problem is that the 2D MV extracted from the game is shortened, because it needs to correspond to the length of the chart. So if we want the "actual" full-length of the 2D MV than additional ytb link or other external source will be required to add to the database.

repository.description: Web Database Viewer of Project Sekai
repository.name: sekai-viewer

summary.main: Support for multiple MVs (2DMV/3DMV) and corresponding full-length audio versions
summary.validationOrRequirement: A single song version should be able to link to multiple distinct MV assets (e.g., one 3DMV and one 2DMV). The "long version" audio needs to be associated with its specific MV. Instead of a single "long version" track, the database should be able to store the full-length audio corresponding to the 3DMV and the full-length audio corresponding to the 2DMV.
summary.attemptedFixes: The 2D MV extracted from the game is shortened, because it needs to correspond to the length of the chart. So if we want the "actual" full-length of the 2D MV than additional ytb link or other external source will be required to add to the database.
summary.otherNotes: The current database structure does not fully support songs with multiple music video types (e.g., 2DMV and 3DMV) and the display of the music video option is fully depend on whether there is a virtual singer version mv. The database currently only seems to track one "long version" per song.

issueDTO.title: `load_indices` should include index config
issueDTO.description:
Ideally the output from `load_indices` would allow to both know

 * Whether the index is an IvfPq index or a Btree index
 * What parameters were used to train the index

Today I can kind of guess the first one based on the type of column but once we add more vector index types this will no longer be possible.

I have no way today of getting the parameters.  This can be very useful because users may forget these things and want to examine them (e.g. because they've learned more about vector indices and now they want to know if they need to rebuild their index or not).
comments:
I thought the parameters were in `dataset.stats.index_stats`?

```python
(Pdb) from pprint import pprint
(Pdb) pprint(dataset.stats.index_stats(index_name))
```

```
{'index_type': 'IVF',
 'indices': [{'centroids': [[0.5594622492790222,
                             ...,
                             0.5300236940383911,
                             0.5513307452201843]],
              'index_type': 'IVF',
              'metric_type': 'l2',
              'num_partitions': 2,
              'partitions': [{'size': 238}, {'size': 274}],
              'sub_index': {'dimension': 32,
                            'index_type': 'PQ',
                            'metric_type': 'l2',
                            'nbits': 8,
                            'num_sub_vectors': 1},
              'uri': '/private/var/folders/09/h28jzzv164n6bn4ldrhhm73m0000gn/T/pytest-of-willjones/pytest-27/test_count_index_rows0/test/_indices/ef525f0b-4c87-42d9-9ace-3e2437b10c71/index.idx',
              'uuid': 'ef525f0b-4c87-42d9-9ace-3e2437b10c71'}],
 'name': 'a_idx',
 'num_indexed_fragments': 1,
 'num_indexed_rows': 512,
 'num_indices': 1,
 'num_unindexed_fragments': 0,
 'num_unindexed_rows': 0}
```

> I thought the parameters were in dataset.stats.index_stats?

@wjones127 

They are but the statistics are experimental / unstable.  Since index parameters are stable, we should have a stable way of retrieving them.

I'm mainly filing this because I want to be able to load the index config in LanceDb and I'm not sure we want to expose raw stats in LanceDb.
I hope we can make them more stable soon. IIRC the main impetus for exposing them is making it so users can retrieve and re-use the IVF centroids.
We also have some use cases where we need to check the metric_type. Agreed, would be nice to have a stable way of getting it.

repository.description: Modern columnar data format for ML and LLMs implemented in Rust. Convert from parquet in 2 lines of code for 100x faster random access, vector index, and data versioning. Compatible with Pandas, DuckDB, Polars, Pyarrow, and PyTorch with more integrations coming..
repository.name: lance

summary.main: The `load_indices` function should include index config, allowing users to know whether the index is an IvfPq index or a Btree index, and what parameters were used to train the index.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The index config should include index parameters, specifically index type and metric type.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the issue description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The parameters are available in `dataset.stats.index_stats` but are experimental/unstable. The goal is to have a stable way of retrieving index parameters.

issueDTO.title: Support non-trivial lambdas in Scala-style rendering format
issueDTO.description:
In current implementation of `LightTypeTag#scalaStyledName` it's impossible to distinguish `[A, B] =>> Either[A, B]` and `[A, B] =>> Either[B, A]` lambdas since they both end up printed as `Either[_, _]`.

To fix this, we should add a check for whether it's correct to use `_`-placeholders when printing a lambda - it's only correct when all lambda parameters are applied and in the same order as they were declared. If not, we should print a long lambda form such as `[A, B] =>> Either[A, B]`.

/cc @Ivoyaa

issueDTO.title: Tick styling inconsistent in `st.bokeh_chart()` vs `streamlit_bokeh()` for caliber theme
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [x] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues.
- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue.

### Summary

`streamlit_bokeh` fails to generate correct axes using the caliber theme after setting the plot background and border colors.  The tick styling fails to output ticks of the requested color.  Legacy `st.bokeh_chart()` renders the ticks as expected.


### Reproducible Code Example

```Python
# See: https://github.com/pr3d4t0r/SSScoring/blob/master/LICENSE.txtl

# Streamlit Bokeh bug report runner


import bokeh.models as bm
import bokeh.plotting as bp
import streamlit as st

backgroundColorName='#2c2c2c'
colorName = 'lightsteelblue'
THEME='caliber'
x = [ x for x in range(1,6) ]
y = [ 6, 7, 6, 4, 5, ]


def BUG_st_bokeh():
    # REQUIRES: pip install streamlit_bokeh
    from streamlit_bokeh import streamlit_bokeh

    plot = bp.figure(
                title='TICK MARKS MISSING - theme: %s' % THEME,
                width=500,
                height=300,
                background_fill_color=backgroundColorName,
                border_fill_color=backgroundColorName,
    )
    plot.title.text_font = 'Arial'
    plot.title.text_color = 'red'
    plot.xaxis.axis_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.major_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.axis_line_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.major_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.minor_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.axis_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.major_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.axis_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.major_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.minor_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.line(x, y, line_color='orange')
    linearAxis = bm.LinearAxis(
            axis_label_text_color = colorName,
            axis_line_color = colorName,
            major_label_text_color = colorName,
            axis_label = 'Foo',
            major_tick_line_color='yellow',
            minor_tick_line_color='yellow',
            y_range_name = 'Bar'
    )
    plot.extra_y_ranges = { 'Bar': bm.Range1d(start = 0, end = 10) }
    plot.add_layout(linearAxis, 'left')
    streamlit_bokeh(plot, use_container_width=False, theme=THEME)


def WORKS_st_bokeh_chart():
    # REQUIRES: pip install bokeh==2.4.3
    import bokeh.io as bi

    bi.curdoc.theme = THEME
    plot = bp.figure(
                title='TICK MARKS SHOW - theme: %s' % THEME,
                width=500,
                height=300,
                background_fill_color=backgroundColorName,
                border_fill_color=backgroundColorName,
    )
    plot.title.text_font = 'Arial'
    plot.title.text_color = colorName
    plot.xaxis.axis_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.major_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.axis_line_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.major_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.xaxis.minor_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.axis_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.major_label_text_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.axis_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.major_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.yaxis.minor_tick_line_color=colorName
    plot.line(x, y, line_color='orange')
    linearAxis = bm.LinearAxis(
            axis_label_text_color = colorName,
            axis_line_color = colorName,
            major_label_text_color = colorName,
            axis_label = 'Foo',
            major_tick_line_color='yellow',
            minor_tick_line_color='yellow',
            y_range_name = 'Bar'
    )
    plot.extra_y_ranges = { 'Bar': bm.Range1d(start = 0, end = 10) }
    plot.add_layout(linearAxis, 'left')
    st.bokeh_chart(plot, use_container_width=False)


if '__main__' == __name__:
    WORKS_st_bokeh_chart()
    # BUG_st_bokeh()
```

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Save the reproducible code example as buggy.py
2. Ensure that `bokeh==2.4.3` is installed and that `streamlit_bokeh` is not present in the current environment
3. `streamlit run buggy.py` - This code uses `st.bokeh_chart()` and renders the ticks for the x, y, and extra y axes/ranges
4. Close the browser and `Ctrl-C` to exit `streamlit`
5. Go to line 95 of the reproducible example and comment out `# WORKS_st_bokeh_chart()`
6. Go to line 96 of the reproducible example and enable `BUG_st_bokeh()`
7. Install `streamlit_bokeh` and its dependencies
8. `streamlit run buggy.py` - This code uses `streamlit_bokeh()` and fails to render ticks for the x, y, and extra y axes/ranges.  Inspecting the output shows that the ticks are present in a dark grey color, unaffected by rendeding settings in `bm.LinearAxis` construction and `bp.plot` instance configuration.

The implementations of `WORKS_st_bokeh_chart()` and `BUG_st_bokeh()` are identical (check with `diff -y` if needed).

### Expected Behavior

Plots rendered using the caliber theme feature tick marks along the axes.  When using `st.bokeh_chart()` and Bokeh 2.4.3 (legacy) the plots render the tick marks for the main axes and for any extra X or Y ranges and axes.


### Current Behavior

`streamlit_bokeh` fails to generate correct axes using the caliber theme after setting the plot background and border colors.  The tick styling fails to output ticks of the requested color.  Legacy `st.bokeh_chart()` renders the ticks as expected.

Compare the output from both function calls (legacy `st.bokeh_chart()` vs `streamlit_bokeh()` generated by identical code.  This must be executed to experience the differences.

### Is this a regression?

- [x] Yes, this used to work in a previous version.

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.45.1
- Python version: 3.13.3, others prior
- Operating System: macOS 15.4.1
- Browser: Firefox, Safari, LibreWolf, Brave

All browsers run at their latest available GA version.

### Additional Information

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Container object custom metadata
issueDTO.description:
Objects in the Swift API can have arbitrary metadata attached.

However, [the function](https://github.com/gophercloud/gophercloud/blob/4f6d1451acac9260a6901451e146b2bee4742bb5/openstack/objectstorage/v1/containers/results.go#L116) in charge of parsing the metadata of a container object doesn't parse them.

Container object properties [are returned in headers starting with `X-Container-Meta-<name>`](https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/#objects) where `<name>` is the name of the metadata item.

---

Note to the implementer: given that properties are passed as HTTP headers, they are subject to the rules of the HTTP headers. Besides being case-insensitive, header field parameters cannot carry characters outside the [ISO-8859-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO/IEC_8859-1) character set [by default](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5987).

repository.description: Gophercloud: an OpenStack SDK for Go
repository.name: gophercloud

summary.main: Implement a function to parse metadata properties of a container object and replace ISO-8859-1/UTF-8 non-printable characters with '?' according to HTTP header rules.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The function should parse metadata properties correctly, and replace ISO-8859-1/UTF-8 non-printable characters with '?' according to HTTP header rules.
summary.attemptedFixes: A proposed function, `FilterHTTPHeader`, is suggested to replace ISO-8859-1/UTF-8 non-printable characters with '?'.
summary.otherNotes: Objects in Swift API can have arbitrary metadata attached, but the function in charge of parsing metadata of a container object doesn't parse them. Metadata properties are passed as HTTP headers starting with `X-Container-Meta-<name>` where `<name>` is the name of the metadata item. Note that properties are subject to HTTP header rules, being case-insensitive and not allowing characters outside the ISO-8859-1 character set by default.

issueDTO.title: Make picture size returned by camera_input consistent via parameter
issueDTO.description:
st. camera_input returns a picture. The dimensions of that picture depend on the camera widget size as displayed in the browser. 

### Problem

Getting randomly sized pictures from the camera_input widget is not exactly defined behaviour.
The documentation doesn't list any setting to request a certain dimension.

```
import streamlit as st
from PIL import Image
import numpy as np

imgbuffer = st.camera_input('cam')

if imgbuffer:
    img = Image.open(imgbuffer)
    imgnp = np.array(img)
    st.write(imgnp.shape)
```

1. run snippet
2. take picture
3. resize browser window so that the widget is also resized
4. take another picture

### Solution

**MVP:** No idea

**Preferred solution:** Add a parameter to request a defined size, maybe a second one to set what to do if that size is not available from the device (upscaling, cropping, downscaling.). Add missing documentation if such a parameter already exists.

---

Community voting on feature requests enables the Streamlit team to understand which features are most important to our users.

**If you'd like the Streamlit team to prioritize this feature request, please use the 👍 (thumbs up emoji) reaction in response to the initial post.**

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-4320)
comments:
Depending on the page / column width, the returned image can be oddly sized.

I suggest that the default behavior be to request an image of a useful consistent size. I'm not sure what the default should be, but 480p, 720p, or 1080p seem like broadly supported and useful resolutions. See https://webrtchacks.github.io/WebRTC-Camera-Resolution/

For those desiring more control, why not adopt the web platform standard for video resolution constraints: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaDevices/getUserMedia#parameters

issueDTO.title: FEATURE REQUEST: Undo Save State and Undo Load State
issueDTO.description:
Should be pretty easy and I'm sure Striker already knows how to do it
It's pretty simple
(I don't know how to add a label so I typed in the label in caps lock)
comments:
Basically, keep a history of save states on every slot. Push and pop states from the back. Keep only the latest N states (maybe 10 by default; adjustable).

When persisting to disk, append the history index to the filename (1 = second to last, 2 onwards for successively older entries), except for the latest state to maintain compatibility with old versions of Ymir.

Wow, that's actually a lot more complex and elaborate than what I had in mind. Very impressive. 

All emulators with undo state that I've seen until now simply saved a state in the background once you click to load one, so if you need to undo it, clicking undo will just load that state that was saved in the background when you clicked load. And if you click to undo save, it will delete the accidental state and replace it with the previous one.
If you do that, Ymir will be the most advanced emulator when it comes to save states
I could go a step further and make a history tree that automatically forks if you create a new save state after going back in time, very similar to how Git works.

That's actually awesome. Only concern would be it getting too confusing to use since it's so elaborate, but I'm probably overthinking. 99,9% of the cases it will just be the usual "oh no I pressed Load when I meant to press save/pressed save when I meant to press load" situation, but it's good to have all those functions you brought up because they could be useful for games where you want to test a bunch of different situations, like visual novels, games with branching paths such as resident evil.
Also useful for testing/finding bugs and glitches in games that could be used for speedruns.
I'd say it would a very good addition to Ymir if states were expanded to have all those features.

issueDTO.title: Streamlit not detecting changes to multipage apps in WSL2
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

Streamlit isn???t detecting file changes in multi-page apps when I run it in WSL2 (Ubuntu 20.04).

I noticed that while it DOES detect changes to the main page, e.g. Home.py, it isn???t detecting changes to nested pages (e.g. a page in the pages directory), nor is it detecting changes to python modules that exist in the same parent directory (I confirmed that my python path includes the parent directory).

### Steps to reproduce

I created a minimal example [here](https://github.com/jonstrutz11/streamlit-minimal-wsl2-bug). You can follow the steps in the README.

I ran this example both in Windows (where changes to all pages and module were detected successfully) and in WSL2 (where changes to only Home.py were detected).

### Is this a regression?
not for me, but I just started using streamlit recently

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.11.0
- Python version: 3.10.4
- Using Conda + pip
- OS version: Windows 10 (Using WSL2 with ubuntu 20.04)
- Browser version: Chrome 104.0.5112.81

### Additional info
Copying from [forums here](https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/streamlit-not-detecting-changes-to-multipage-apps-in-wsl2/29248)
comments:
Hey @jonstrutz11 , thanks for reporting this issue. 

Could I ask you to try to install `watchdog` via `pip install watchdog` in your python WSL env. 
Is the issue still there?
@kajarenc just installed watchdog as requested and ran the app again. Unfortunately, I got the same results.

Hi @jonstrutz11, thanks for reporting this!

I'll see if I can get around to investigating sometime this week as I have a machine running windows + WSL available to do some testing one. 

Unfortunately, there may be a chance that this is unsolvable on our end as I vaguely remember running into issues having to do with file watchers on directories being problematic on WSL/Windows due to OS-related restrictions. If this is the same problem that I'm remembering, then that would explain why it's an issue specifically with the `pages` directory for a multipage app but not the main script file.

I'll get back to you sometime in the next few days after I'm able to spend some time investigating.

Hey @jonstrutz11,

I had some time to do some digging on this and believe I was able to find the WSL issues that I only vaguely remembered before: https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4581, https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4739, https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4064 (there are also a bunch of other related issues linked from those three).

The summary of what I've been able to find is that WSL2 doesn't support inotify except in certain situations (I believe it's possible to get things to work on ext4 filesystems, but as far as I can tell there isn't any way to fix things on ntfs or other common Windows filesystem formats), and without inotify we're unable to watch for changes to directories.

I'm going to close this as I don't believe there's much we can do on our end to fix this, but let me know if I'm missing something here.

Update: it looks like this is going to require some more investigation, as it turns out that I actually didn't have any issues running the minimal example on my windows machine 😬 (Whoops, sorry for jumping to conclusions on finding a few WSL bugs that I thought explained the behavior.)

One thing to try in the meantime would be setting the `server.fileWatcherType` config option to `"poll"` since, if one suspected reason for file watchers not always working is that inotify is having issues, then using that file watcher type should circumvent the problem entirely.
@vdonato setting `server.fileWatcherType` to `"poll"` is working for now - thank you!

I have a similar situation, struggling for months now. I'm importing a python script from a subfolder in app.py, which is a multi-page app. All the pages are in the root folder, so hot-reloading works fine. It does not though for the other script in a subfolder.
```
.
?????????app.py
?????????page1.py
?????????page2.py
????????? subfolder
        ????????? __init__.py
????      ????????? script.py
```
In `app.py` I have `from subfolder.script import Class`.

I added `server.fileWatcherType` to `"poll"`. When I change `script.py` the app correctly recognizes the change and notifies to reload. But upon reloading the changes in `script.py` are not reflected. Changes in any script in the root folder are correctly reloaded.

I tried adding `subfolder` to PYTHONPATH [(doc)](https://docs.streamlit.io/knowledge-base/using-streamlit/streamlit-watch-changes-other-modules-importing-app) and importing without `from` (#358).

I'm using WSL2 and the files are on NTFS filesystem (not on WSL2 fs). I'm using Streamlit v1.9.2.

EDIT: I might have just found the source of this error. Since the `script.py` is only referenced in `app.py` it gets reloaded only if I fully reload the page in browser. Could this be it?

FWIW since this Github has been silent a while, noting same issue on Mac i7 Ventura 13.4 with Firefox 113.0.1 which mitigates with running with the `--server.fileWatcherType=poll` flag. (This has been strange to problem box, so I appreciate y'all already finding it 🙏🏼!) 

```
$ tree
.
????????? helpers.py
????????? home.py
????????? ui
    ????????? __init__.py
    ????????? base.py

$ pip3 --version
pip 23.1.2 from /usr/local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/pip (python 3.11)

$ pip3 list | grep -Ei "pip|watchdog|streamlit"
pip                   23.1.2
streamlit             1.21.0
streamlit-option-menu 0.3.2
watchdog              3.0.0
```

I have the same issue. I am using WSL2, my project is stored in the Ubuntu FS (not Windows) and I change code in Pycharm. Streamlit only reloads the code changes after 1 change. All subsequent changes are ignored. When I start the app with `--server.fileWatcherType=poll` settings, it works. I am also using poetry in my project, not sure how relevant it is.

issueDTO.title: Server shutdown fails to exit while processing infinite loop
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

Python process does not exit when shutting down the server while processing an infinite loop in a script

### Steps to reproduce

Code snippet: (using a recent SessionState prototype, before I fixed the implementation)

```
import streamlit as st

state = st.get_state()
st.write("printed something")
st.write("foobar" in state) # this line infinite looped before I fixed the implementation
```

If applicable, please provide the steps we should take to reproduce the bug:

1. Run the above snippet against the [previous state prototype](https://github.com/AnOctopus/streamlit/tree/c17d119aef34ae1f15f0e7dff5051469d8bb745d) (I ran the react server as a separate process from the dev install of that commit, rather than running them together via a wheel, don't know if that affects this)
2. C-c in the shell running the python server

**Expected behavior:**

Python server stops, process exits and control returns to my shell

**Actual behavior:**

Logs indicate server goes into the STOPPING state and then almost immediately the STOPPED state, but after 20 seconds it still has not exited the process. Sending SIGTERM repeatedly afterwards fails to cause the process to exit, and SIGKILL was required to regain control.

### Is this a regression?

Unknown

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: Session state prototype, as linked above, development install
- Python version: 3.8.6
- Using Conda? PipEnv? PyEnv? Pex?: Pipenv
- OS version: Arch Linux
- Shell version: Zsh 5.8
comments: Interesting. I wonder if the ScriptRunner is closing the thread when it receives the stop signal @AnOctopus

AFAICT this is working as expected.

When you ctrl-c out of Streamlit (and at some other points, like when you click "stop" in the UI) we need to kill running thread(s), but Python doesn't actually have a way to kill threads. 

So what we do is:
1. Set a boolean when we want to kill a thread
2. Before every st.foo command, we check if the thread running that command has the boolean set to True
3. If True, raise a special exception. (Because exceptions kill threads)
    _So the thread is now stopped ??? yay!_
4. Handle the exception at the parent thread if needed

This works well any script where the interpreter often encounters an st.foo command. And it doesn't work at all when you have a loop that has no st.foo command. 

In this case, the loop has no st command, so it runs forever.

Is there a graceful way of shutting down a streamlit app without killing the terminal?

![Screenshot 2021-06-23 at 10 34 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11792905/123073872-ba96ae80-d40e-11eb-9eb9-d907c2b03b41.png)

Hey @robertmartin8 I've been doing a bunch of spinning up and shutting down servers in the terminal it's usually pretty speedy. My only wonder is if something is long-running in the script that's failing to shut down. Are you doing anything special with threads or anything? Any code would be appreciated.

The structure of the app (also raised in #3230) is as follows:

```python
import time
import streamlit as st
from streamlit import caching
from binance import Client
client = Client()

@st.cache(ttl=310, allow_output_mutation=True)
def get_data(timestamp=None)
    client.get(...)
    return df
    
table = st.empty()

while True:
     # update every 5 mins
     caching.clear_cache()  # not sure if needed
     timestamp = dt.utcnow()
     table.dataframe(get_data(timestamp))
     time.sleep(300)  
```

It's possible @robertmartin8 that we can make the thread created to run the script a [daemon](https://docs.python.org/3/library/threading.html#threading.Thread.daemon) thread.

There is a note however.

> Note Daemon threads are abruptly stopped at shutdown. Their resources (such as open files, database transactions, etc.) may not be released properly. If you want your threads to stop gracefully, make them non-daemonic and use a suitable signalling mechanism such as an Event.

We would need to investigate the implications of this. We expect more people to be connecting to databases etc than creating infinite loops in their code.

That's fair, though I do feel that continuously polling a REST API and displaying results is a pretty good use case?

If there's a better pattern for this, I'm all ears

@robertmartin8 I've been thinking about this, and I came up with an idea on my personal time that might help. Essentially, I implemented a custom component that auto re-runs the app. This avoids the need of an infinite loop in the script. This improves the developer experience (shutting down while an infinite loop is running) while easing resources on the server with a tiny tradeoff from the user.

https://github.com/kmcgrady/streamlit-autorefresh

Here's a trivial example.

```python
import streamlit as st
from streamlit_autorefresh import st_autorefresh

# Run the autorefresh about every 2000 milliseconds (2 seconds) and stop
# after it's been refreshed 100 times.
count = st_autorefresh(interval=2000, limit=100, key="fizzbuzzcounter")

# The function returns a counter for number of refreshes. This allows the
# ability to make special requests at different intervals based on the count
if count == 0:
    st.write("Count is zero")
elif count % 3 == 0 and count % 5 == 0:
    st.write("FizzBuzz")
elif count % 3 == 0:
    st.write("Fizz")
elif count % 5 == 0:
    st.write("Buzz")
else:
    st.write(f"Count: {count}")
```

Your use case suggests this could work and may even simplify your work. Given the code structure, the new script would be:

```python
import streamlit as st
from streamlit_autorefresh import st_autorefresh
from streamlit import caching
from binance import Client
client = Client()

# update every 5 mins
st_autorefresh(interval=5 * 60 * 1000, key="dataframerefresh")

@st.cache(ttl=310, allow_output_mutation=True)
def get_data(timestamp=None)
    client.get(...)
    return df

caching.clear_cache()  # not sure if needed
timestamp = dt.utcnow()    
st.dataframe(get_data(timestamp))
```


The only use case that I think this would hurt is one with complex UI implemented _before_ the infinite loop. That being said, proper caching could solve that challenge.

Let me know if it helps or not. It's a simple component so feedback is appreciated.
Awesome! Will try that for my next proj :)
This bug makes working with Kafka(-like) data sources tricky. The only workaround I've found so far was to add `st.empty` statements in loops.

We create a branch, where we are solved this, inside streamlit
https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/compare/develop...FloWide:force_exit_st
What do you think @kmcgrady ?

This daemon thread sends a `SystemExit` exception after a config timeout through python interpreter to all 'hanged' thread. 
So when a 'hanged' thread runs a python code,  the python interpreter throws a `SystemExit`.

Sometimes when python hangs in OS call (`sleep`, `select`, `poll`, etc...) this not works, then we use forced signal killing after a longer configurable time.

When no hanged thread, this has no effect.
@schaumb That approach seems promising. Could you open a PR for it?
I've stumbled upon the same problem in #8181 (and #8182), but due to long running DWH SQL requests. Would be nice to be able to terminate threads in some way, including server stopping.

**If this issue affects you, please react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

issueDTO.title: Returning data from plot interactions doesn't work with Plotly Treemaps
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues.
- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue.

### Summary

I have played around with the [new capabilities to retrieve data from interactions in plotly figures](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/455), but noticed that it doesn't seem to work for Plotly Treemaps. The returned event dict remains empty despite furious clicking and dragging in the figure. 

### Reproducible Code Example

[![Open in Streamlit Cloud](https://static.streamlit.io/badges/streamlit_badge_black_white.svg)](https://issues.streamlitapp.com/?issue=gh-9001)

```Python
import streamlit as st
import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.gapminder().query("year == 2007")

fig = px.treemap(
    df,
    path=["continent", "country"],
    values="pop",
)

event_dict = st.plotly_chart(fig, on_select="rerun")

st.write(event_dict)
```


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Click around in the plot
2. Notice that nothing changes in the displayed empty dictionary below the plot.

### Expected Behavior

The displayed `event_dict` should get populated with some values when interacting with the plot.

### Current Behavior

The displayed `event_dict` remains empty:

```
{
    "selection": {
        "points": [],
        "point_indices": [],
        "box": [],
        "lasso": []
    }
}
```

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this used to work in a previous version.

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.36.0
- Python version: 3.11.5
- Operating System: MacOS 14.5 (23F79)
- Browser: Firefox, Safari


### Additional Information

_No response_
comments:
**If this issue affects you, please react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-9001)
@shkarlsson Thanks for reporting this issue! I was able to reproduce it [here](https://issues.streamlit.app/?issue=gh-9001).

Additionally it also does not work with scatter_3d. Potentially this feature only works with selected plotly chart types? This is the example from https://docs.streamlit.io/develop/api-reference/charts/st.plotly_chart#plotlyselectionstate expanded for the 3rd dimension and using ` px.scatter_3d` instead of `px.scatter` .

```import streamlit as st
import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.iris()
fig = px.scatter_3d(
    df,
    x="sepal_width",
    y="sepal_length",
    z="petal_length",
    color="species",
    size="petal_length",
    hover_data=["petal_width"],
)

event = st.plotly_chart(fig, key="iris", on_select="rerun")

event.selection

This doesn't work with plotly Sunburst chart either. I am guessing it doesn't work with *any* plotly chart?

```
         fig = go.Figure()
         
         # https://plotly.com/javascript/reference/sunburst/#sunburst
         fig.add_trace(go.Sunburst(
            ids=list(sunburst_data.Name),
            labels=list(sunburst_data.Name),
            parents=list(sunburst_data.Parent),
            values=list(sunburst_data.Value),
            branchvalues="total",
            hoverinfo="text",
            hovertext=list(sunburst_data.HoverInfo),
            sort=False, # to make sure colorway matches
         ))

         fig.update_layout(
            margin = dict(t=0, l=0, r=0, b=0),
            height=800,
            colorway=list(sunburst_data[sunburst_data["Parent"] == "root"]["Color"]),
            # extendsunburstcolorway=True,
         )

         event_dict = st.plotly_chart(fig, on_select="rerun")
         print(event_dict)
```
Doesn't work with heatmaps either.
Running into this as well. Any updates? Is this a regression about to be fixed, or fundamentally not supported for the charts listed here?

With a little JavaScript executed in the browser-console, I managed to forward the plotly_click event to the plotly_selected event and made the reproducible code example work:

```
element = document.querySelector('.stPlotlyChart .js-plotly-plot')
element.on('plotly_click', function(e) {
    console.log('click', e)
    element.emit('plotly_selected', { points: e.points })
})
```

Unfortunately, I have not yet found how to auto-run this JS-code-snippet at the end of the streamlit page. I've tried `st.components.v1.html`, but it doesn't work because this is added in an iframe:

```
import streamlit as st
import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.gapminder().query("year == 2007")

fig = px.treemap(
    df,
    path=["continent", "country"],
    values="pop",
)
event_dict = st.plotly_chart(fig, on_select="rerun")
st.write(event_dict)

# Doesn't work because this is added in an iframe, have to manually evaluate code in console at the moment
st.components.v1.html("""<script>
    element = document.querySelector('.stPlotlyChart .js-plotly-plot')
    element.on('plotly_click', function(e) {
        console.log('click', e)
        element.emit('plotly_selected', { points: e.points })
    })
</script>""")
```

issueDTO.title: [FEATURE] <Social Sharing Buttons on Blogs>
issueDTO.description:
### Why do we need this improvement?

Currently, the website lacks a mechanism for users to easily share blog posts on social media platforms. This limits the reach and visibility of the content, making it harder for readers to promote the blogs organically to a broader audience.

### How will this change help?

This change will ease the sharing of blog amongst social platforms.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### How could it be implemented/designed?

Add social sharing buttons to each blog post. These buttons should allow users to share the post on popular platforms such as:

    Twitter
    LinkedIn

Each button should generate a pre-filled sharing link, including the blog post title, URL, and possibly hashtags. For example:

```Twitter: https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Check+out+this+blog!&url=https://www.asyncapi.com/blog/2024-annual-summary#social-media```

The buttons should be visually appealing, lightweight, and non-intrusive. They can be displayed at the top or bottom of each blog post.

### 🚧 Breaking changes

Yes

issueDTO.title: Generate Framework Folder Structure Dynamically for Prompts
issueDTO.description:
## Task: Generate Framework Folder Structure Dynamically for Prompts

**Description:**
- Build a component that inspects the generated framework on disk and produces a concise, standardized folder/file tree to embed in LLM prompts.
- Support filtering, depth limits, and size-aware truncation to keep prompt context within budget while preserving the most relevant structure.

**Why This Matters:**
- Gives the agent accurate project context

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] Generate a folder/file tree from a given root (e.g., the framework output path) with deterministic ordering.
- [ ] Include/exclude rules (e.g., ignore `node_modules`, `dist`, `logs`, dotfiles by default).
- [ ] Depth limit and file count limit to constrain output size.
- [ ] Output in the optimal machine-readable format, optimizing token usage
- [ ] Unit tests covering filtering, limits, determinism, and format correctness.

issueDTO.title: [docs] suggestion: add stable/unstable/experimental badges to utils
issueDTO.description:
Given the more ad-hoc/additive nature of this library I think it would be nice to have some kind of indicator of stableness for each util.

For example having just added `signalSlice` I might give it an "experimental" or "unstable" badge if there is potential for breaking changes. We could decide on a consistent convention that is used throughout the library, e.g:

* [stable] - API is stable/supported
* [preview] - API is likely stable but may change
* [experimental] - API is likely to change/utility may be removed entirely

This badge could be displayed at the top of the documentation for each util.

I'm happy to add these in if desired
comments:
You can display it next to the title. 

But not inside the table of content, having too much badge there will make the menu unreadable

My thoughts based on a statistic, the current breakdown of badges

From 47 utils, I searched the (English) docs folder. 

- `badge: stable`: 44
- `badge: preview`: 0
- `badge: experimental`: 2
- `badge: deprecated`: 1

The ES folder has 25 entries and all are stable ones.

These numbers will change over time, and I imagine the non "stable" categories will technically grow a little bit over time. 

---

I think maybe having a badge or `!` or emoji in the table template for "preview" and "experimental"  would be what I would do to in my opinion. It would give those a bit more caution without impacting readability for the most part. 

Bonus item related to this:

For inspiration, both the angular.io and angular.dev domains put more emphasis on developer preview, with colored banners at the top of the page for developer preview, while also linking to the definition of Developer Preview. The old site lumps all developer preview features in one side table header, and the new site doesn't give distinctions in the table except, but both have that banner. I think that is a good practice, so I would also think perhaps at least different color for non "stable" features would also be a nice bit of emphasis and styling for this project. Additionally, I think a standalone page or page section for the definitions this issue hopes to establish would be good to link to from the in utility page badge.

(checking in from my work account)

Adjacent to this issue, I found something cool in the docs today that I wanted to use, but it did not have a badge. Looks like it (`injectRouteData`) hasn't been formally released from what I can tell from the notes or looking at the bundle from v2.1. I think there should be a fallback case in the UI denoting this, or perhaps a doc page should not show up if it isn't given a badge.

issueDTO.title: Migrate unit tests from unittest to pytest
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 Describe the new functionality needed

I???d like to propose converting the existing test suite from unittest to pytest. pytest offers simpler, more Pythonic syntax and reduces boilerplate (no need for TestCase classes, setUp/tearDown). Most of the codebase uses pytest already.

```
tests/unit/models/test_prompt_adapter.py:import unittest
tests/unit/models/test_system_prompts.py:import unittest
tests/unit/providers/nvidia/test_datastore.py:import unittest
tests/unit/providers/nvidia/test_eval.py:import unittest
tests/unit/providers/nvidia/test_parameters.py:import unittest

issueDTO.title: Implement geolocation flow for ARO map
issueDTO.description:
## Background
Currently, the ARO map has some issues with location permissions that need to be resolved. The default location is set to be the user's location, but there's no fallback if the user does not have permissions enabled. We need to handle these cases safely while also storing a preferred default location in the user config.

The priority should be similar to the following:
1. User-defined starting location (from user data)
2. Geolocation if enabled
3. Hardcoded default location like a UW building or the CSDC

## Requirements
- [ ] Create the geolocation flow for the map
- [ ] Add preferred latlong to user settings (optional for now, see below)

## Important Information
We don't auth set up yet, so you may need to skip the user config for now and leave it as an outstanding change, or wait until we have some groundwork.

issueDTO.title: Design a new music puzzle
issueDTO.description:
Play through the music puzzle by selecting the Musician Lore Quest via the Elder on the left side of the loom. Also play through the first round of the "Placeholder" LoreQuest from the same Elder. These are two variations on the theme of the same puzzle.

Create and attach a document to this issue with design for a new variation on the music puzzle. This could be four new patterns, or new variations on the way that the puzzle works. For example:

- Remove the ability to interact with the hint sign to hear the melody (perhaps for the last round of the puzzle), forcing the player to use visual or conversational hints to work out the correct melody.
- Combine the puzzle with other mechanics in the game
- Place the fifth rock behind a door that is opened by solving the first round of the puzzle


Ideally the design includes: 

- Written description of the new elements introduced into the game/puzzle

- Steps for completing the puzzle/game
- a list of tasks needed to complete the creation of this puzzle (ex. art assets, audio assets, game functionality)

issueDTO.title: Run mypy against several pip and Python versions
issueDTO.description:
It might be useful to run mypy against several pip and Python versions (like min + max). Just the last one isn't going to cover a lot of stuff..

_Originally posted by @webknjaz in https://github.com/jazzband/pip-tools/issues/1927#issuecomment-1645054788_
comments: I guess we could use https://github.com/ansible-community/sphinx_ansible_theme/commit/e86ef32f9ecec272dc958c56726620adcf7be815 as a reference.
That should do.
cc @sirosen we should look into this eventually.

Yes, it's on my radar. I think we actually are a little out of sync in how we'd like to approach this, so we need to get to a point of agreement in order to proceed.

I think it's easier to manage type checking as part of the testing process (not linting), so I want to setup `mypy` to run under `tox`. That also simplifies getting the package dependencies installed.
IMO the desirable outcome would be to be able to run `tox r -m typing` and have that expand to, for example, `tox r -e mypy-py3.8,mypy-py3.13,pyright-py3.8,pyright-py3.13` (don't hold me to that expansion, just an example).

I think you had voiced a preference for keeping `mypy` in `pre-commit` before; am I remembering correctly? Can you speak to why that's better than running it in `tox`?

Mostly because I have it set up that way everywhere and it's easier for me to sync it across projects. Changes to the pattern usually cause a lot of burden to scale that across other places. But also being able to have it next to the other linters and have the results in pre-commit.ci.
Though, now that we have in-memory env generation fixed in tox API, I'd be curious to try writing a plugin that would ship a standard mypy invocation. Syncing something like `pip install tox-mypy` would definitely be easier.

issueDTO.title: fix(sources): Add New Proxy Sources
issueDTO.description:
### Adding New Proxy Sources

The core of this project is the collection of proxy sources. We are always looking for new, reliable sources of free proxies.

**How it works:**

The application reads files from the `/sources` directory. Each file in this directory (e.g., `http.txt`, `vless.txt`) corresponds to a proxy protocol. The content of these files are URLs, with each URL pointing to a list of proxies.

**Steps to add a source:**

1.  **Find a proxy source URL.** This should be a raw text URL that provides a list of proxies.
2.  **Identify the correct file.** In the `/sources` directory, find the file that matches the protocol of your source list (e.g., for a list of HTTP proxies, use `http.txt`). If a file for that protocol doesn't exist, you can create one.
3.  **Add the URL.** Add the URL to a new line in the appropriate file.

for more details, please check the [full guide](https://github.com/gfpcom/free-proxy-list/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#adding-new-proxy-sources)

issueDTO.title: Refactor base.html to remove inline styles and move CSS to SCSS file
issueDTO.description:
Refactor base.html to remove inline styles and move CSS to SCSS file

# Description:

The `base.html` template currently contains a large `<style>` block with form styling directly in the HTML file. To improve maintainability and keep styles organized, we should move these styles into the appropriate `.scss` file and remove the inline style block from the HTML.

This is a fast follow from this [PR](https://github.com/Techtonica/techtonica.org/pull/615#pullrequestreview-2711350658)

# Tasks:

- [x] Move all `<style> `block content from `templates/base.html` into the SCSS file
- [x] Remove the entire `<style>` block from the HTML file once verified
- [ ] Extract shared styles across application forms into reusable mixins or partials
- [x] Test to make sure no styles have changed
- [ ] Move form styles to a new partial `_form.scss` file

# Out of Scope:
- Refactoring javascript to its own file
- Refactoring styles of other forms
- Style changes or updates - all styles should be visually unchanged

issueDTO.title: container definition needs to recognize credentialSpecs
issueDTO.description:
## Is your request related to a new offering from AWS?
Is this functionality available in the [AWS provider for Terraform] Yes

## Is your request related to a problem? Please describe.
In order for windows gmsa to work in AWS, it needs to have credentialSpecs in the container definition.

Documented here: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/windows-gmsa.html

## Describe the solution you'd like.
Use credentialSpecs if provided in containerDefinition object.
In `modules/container-definition/main.tf` around line 41:
```
credentialSpecs  = var.credentialSpecs
```
Will need corresponding entry in `modules/service/main.tf` around line 816:
```
credentialSpecs  = each.value.credentialSpecs
```

## Describe alternatives you've considered.
To make this work, would have to revert to not using this module and use the standard terraform aws resource
comments: credentialSpecs is also talked about here in spec: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task_definition_parameters_ec2.html

Potential Patch:
```
diff --git a/modules/container-definition/main.tf b/modules/container-definition/main.tf
index cf73471..7d4ceb4 100644
--- a/modules/container-definition/main.tf
+++ b/modules/container-definition/main.tf
@@ -39,6 +39,7 @@ locals {
   definition = {
     command                = var.command
     cpu                    = var.cpu
+    credentialSpecs        = var.credentialSpecs
     dependsOn              = var.dependsOn
     disableNetworking      = local.is_not_windows ? var.disableNetworking : null
     dnsSearchDomains       = local.is_not_windows ? var.dnsSearchDomains : null
diff --git a/modules/container-definition/variables.tf b/modules/container-definition/variables.tf
index 0c7d229..5519918 100644
--- a/modules/container-definition/variables.tf
+++ b/modules/container-definition/variables.tf
@@ -34,6 +34,12 @@ variable "cpu" {
   default     = null
 }
 
+variable "credentialSpecs" {
+  description = "Specs for Credentials"
+  type        = list(string)
+  default     = []
+}
+
 # tflint-ignore: terraform_naming_convention
 variable "dependsOn" {
   description = "The dependencies defined for container startup and shutdown. A container can contain multiple dependencies. When a dependency is defined for container startup, for container shutdown it is reversed. The condition can be one of START, COMPLETE, SUCCESS or HEALTHY"
diff --git a/modules/service/main.tf b/modules/service/main.tf
index f467f56..70b04ba 100644
--- a/modules/service/main.tf
+++ b/modules/service/main.tf
@@ -814,6 +814,7 @@ module "container_definition" {
   # Container Definition
   command                = each.value.command
   cpu                    = each.value.cpu
+  credentialSpecs        = each.value.credentialSpecs
   dependsOn              = each.value.dependsOn

issueDTO.title: BUG: Assigning extension array value to series of dtype object fails if element type is array-like
issueDTO.description:
- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the latest version of pandas.

- [X] (optional) I have confirmed this bug exists on the master branch of pandas.

---

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example

```python
import pandas as pd
from pandas.api.extensions import ExtensionArray, ExtensionDtype

class StubDtype(ExtensionDtype):
    """Extension dtype whose elements are something that numpy.asarray() 
    will turn into an array (in this case a tuple)"""
    def __init__(self):
        pass
    
    @property
    def type(self):
        return tuple
    
    @property
    def name(self) -> str:
        return "StubDtype"
        
    @classmethod
    def construct_array_type(cls):
        return StubExtensionArray()

class StubExtensionArray(ExtensionArray):
    """Just enough of an extension array to run the four lines of code 
    that follow."""
    @property
    def dtype(self):
        return StubDtype()
    
    def copy(self):
        return StubExtensionArray()
    
    def __len__(self):
        return 5
    
    def __getitem__(self, key):
        # Every position in the array has the tuple (1, 2, 3)
        return (1, 2, 3)
    
    

data = StubExtensionArray()
series1 = pd.Series(data, name="data")
series2 = pd.Series(index=series1.index, dtype=object, name="data")
series2.loc[series1.index] = data
```

Output:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-168-cfd127e7fa55> in <module>
     41 series1 = pd.Series(data, name="data")
     42 series2 = pd.Series(index=series1.index, dtype=object, name="data")
---> 43 series2.loc[series1.index] = data

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py in __setitem__(self, key, value)
    721 
    722         iloc = self if self.name == "iloc" else self.obj.iloc
--> 723         iloc._setitem_with_indexer(indexer, value, self.name)
    724 
    725     def _validate_key(self, key, axis: int):

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py in _setitem_with_indexer(self, indexer, value, name)
   1730             self._setitem_with_indexer_split_path(indexer, value, name)
   1731         else:
-> 1732             self._setitem_single_block(indexer, value, name)
   1733 
   1734     def _setitem_with_indexer_split_path(self, indexer, value, name: str):

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py in _setitem_single_block(self, indexer, value, name)
   1966 
   1967         # actually do the set
-> 1968         self.obj._mgr = self.obj._mgr.setitem(indexer=indexer, value=value)
   1969         self.obj._maybe_update_cacher(clear=True)
   1970 

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/internals/managers.py in setitem(self, indexer, value)
    353 
    354     def setitem(self: T, indexer, value) -> T:
--> 355         return self.apply("setitem", indexer=indexer, value=value)
    356 
    357     def putmask(self, mask, new, align: bool = True):

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/internals/managers.py in apply(self, f, align_keys, ignore_failures, **kwargs)
    325                     applied = b.apply(f, **kwargs)
    326                 else:
--> 327                     applied = getattr(b, f)(**kwargs)
    328             except (TypeError, NotImplementedError):
    329                 if not ignore_failures:

~/opt/miniconda3/envs/pd/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/core/internals/blocks.py in setitem(self, indexer, value)
    965                 values[indexer] = value.to_numpy(value.dtype.numpy_dtype)
    966             else:
--> 967                 values[indexer] = np.asarray(value)
    968 
    969         # if we are an exact match (ex-broadcasting),

ValueError: shape mismatch: value array of shape (5,3) could not be broadcast to indexing result of shape (5,)
```

#### Problem description

If the user creates a Series of dtype `object` and attempts to set the value of that Series with an extension array, the block manager will first pass the extension array through `np.asarray()` and then assign the block's values to the ndarray returned by `np.asarray()` (See code [here](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/0a9cfcf8da8d64aeca2574aa5d7caa9dcd3f1779/pandas/core/internals/blocks.py#L967)). 

This logic assumes that `np.asarray()` will always return a 1D array. However, `np.asarray()` is not guaranteed to return a 1D array; if the items of the argument to `np.asarray()` are array-like, `np.asarray()` will iterate over them and generate an array with 2 or more dimensions. This 2- or-more-dimensional array can't be assigned to the series, and Pandas throws the error "ValueError: shape mismatch...".

This problem is affecting the TensorArray extension type in [Text Extensions for Pandas](https://github.com/CODAIT/text-extensions-for-pandas), because the elements of a TensorArray are tensors. The example code above shows a simpler case where the items of the extension array are Python tuples. In general, any item type that `np.asarray()` converts to an array of one or more dimensions will have this problem.

#### Expected Output

The above code should fill `series2` with the individual objects at each of the positions in the extension array. In the case of the example code above, that means that each element of `series2` should contain the Python tuple `(1, 2, 3)`.

comments:
code sample worked in 1.2.5

first bad commit: [527c7893b8f56f5efe7c182ede5b7a26af4ce702] API/BUG: always try to operate inplace when setting with loc/iloc[foo, bar] (#39163)

cc @jbrockmendel

Somewhere in there it is calling np.array on your EA, and that produces a 2D ndarray.  If add to your example

```
    def __array__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        arr = np.empty(5, dtype=object)
        for i in range(5):
            arr[i] = (1, 2, 3)
        return arr
```

then the code snippet works

@jbrockmendel if I'm reading your comment correctly, there's a (currently undocumented) requirement for Pandas extension types to implement the NumPy callback `__array__()`. If that's the case, then perhaps the `ExtensionArray` class should have an implementation of `__array__()` that calls `self.to_numpy()`?

>  If that's the case, then perhaps the ExtensionArray class should have an implementation of __array__() that calls self.to_numpy()?

Huh, I thought that was already there as the default implementation, but apparently not.  PR would be welcome.

The default implementation of `to_numpy()` starts with doing a `result = np.asarray(self, dtype=dtype)` so adding something like ...

```
    def __array__(self, dtype: npt.DTypeLike| None = None) -> np.ndarray:
        """
        Correctly construct numpy arrays when passed to `np.asarray()`.
        """
        return self.to_numpy(dtype=dtype)
```

to the base class would raise `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded`

> Huh, I thought that was already there as the default implementation, but apparently not. PR would be welcome.

moving to 1.3.4
changing milestone to 1.3.5
this is good to fix but not necessary for 1.3.x
moving off 1.3.x milestone
This works on main, could ue a test
take
Will add tests as appropriate

issueDTO.title: [DOCS]: Translation of README.md into Arabic
issueDTO.description:
Requesting a contributor to translate the project's README.md file into Arabic (ar).

A version in Arabic will significantly boost the project's accessibility and foster greater engagement with Arabic-speaking contributors and users worldwide. This translation is especially valuable as Arabic is a Right-to-Left (RTL) language, requiring specific layout considerations that enhance the reading experience. 🌍

Goal Language: Arabic Language Code: ar (ISO 639-1 standard)

Tasks
Create a new file named README.ar.md.

Translate all sections including the project description, installation steps, usage examples, and contribution guidelines.

Implement Right-to-Left (RTL) layout support where necessary within the markdown (e.g., using HTML in the markdown for blocks of text or lists).

Add a prominent link to the new translation in the language-selection section (or at the top) of the main README.md.

Proofread the translation for technical accuracy, linguistic clarity, and appropriate tone.

issueDTO.title: Display SVGs with `st.image` without needing to set a `width` value
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues.
- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue.

### Summary

I noticed that Streamlit cannot display some SVG - While others work fine.

Here's a sample SVG file that cannot be displayed:

`![bad](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/092dddd3-fc63-44a6-8585-a5ce13e6bac0)`

SVG file however shows correctly in the browser

### Reproducible Code Example

```Python
import streamlit as st

st.image("bad.svg")
```

comments:
**If this issue affects you, please react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-9098)

Hi @emerzon 👋 Thanks for reporting this issue -- it does seem like expected behavior from the [`st.image`](https://docs.streamlit.io/develop/api-reference/media/st.image) docstring for `width`: As SVGs do not have a default width, you must pass a value for width to st.image: ```py st.image("bad.svg", width=702) ``` ![svg-width](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bc71eb54-28bc-4743-93a3-fef852f4d915) So unless you explicitly specify a width in st.image or the SVG file itself sets width and height values to match those in `viewBox`, it can result in unexpected scaling behavior, including rendering the SVG with a size of 0x0
Hi @snehankekre Thank you for the clarification. I though it was a weird behavior because some other SVG are displayed without setting the width value and also I can get it displayed by using raw `

> some other SVG are displayed without setting the width value I've observed that when the SVG file explicitly states the width and if the width matches that specified in the viewBox, then st.image displays it correctly without passing `width`. E.g. ```svg In my case, these SVG are generated dynamically by kroki.io therefore it's not possible to known the width in advance. The only workarounds I can think of are to a) explicitly set an arbitrary width or b) download and parse the SVG contents, get the width from the `viewBox` attribute, and explicitly set that `width` value in `st.image`. > Do you think it would be possible to somehow mimic the same behavior of the browser for 'guessing' the width? It's not possible with how `st.image` is implemented today. So I'll mark this issue as a feature request 👍

**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Visits](https://hits.seeyoufarm.com/api/count/incr/badge.svg?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fstreamlit%2Fstreamlit%2Fissues%2F9098&title=visits&edge_flat=false)
@snehankekre, thank you for digging into this, makes perfect sense!
Agree we should make SVG images take the full container width when `width` isn't set. Feel free to submit a PR if anyone wants to work on this!

issueDTO.title: Unclear error if line-length goes beyond u16 boundaries

repository.description: An extremely fast Python linter and code formatter, written in Rust.
repository.name: ruff

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the unclear error when the line-length setting in the ruff.toml file exceeds the u16 boundaries, and to provide a clear error message or validation for such cases.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The line-length value in the ruff.toml file should be within the range of 1 to 320, and should be a u16 integer.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the issue description or comments
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the line-length setting in the ruff.toml file, specifically the value of 99_999 being considered invalid. The TOML spec states that integers should be accepted and handled losslessly, but ruff fails to parse the configuration due to the value exceeding the u16 range. The issue also includes tests with values 65535 and 65536, which also fail due to the same reason.
