issueDTO.title: Alasql cli docker / pipe issues
issueDTO.description:
Hi! I???m currently working on building a Docker image for AlaSQL and I???ve run into an issue where commands passed to the container aren???t being executed as expected.

From what I???ve investigated so far, it seems that Docker doesn???t attach a TTY by default when running commands through ENTRYPOINT, which changes how the CLI behaves. I tried updating the logic in [alasql-cli.js](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/develop/bin/alasql-cli.js), but I think there may be another underlying issue as well.

Specifically, when piping data into a query, the input is being treated as a SQL statement rather than as data. I can reproduce this behavior both inside and outside of Docker, so it doesn???t appear to be container-specific. Looking at the code in [alasql-cli.js](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/develop/bin/alasql-cli.js), it seems to try to read input directly, whereas I had expected file or stream reading to be handled by the standard FROM helpers such as [alasql.from.TXT](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/0d5c9816659bde946c01a2d6ebb8d062161a1976/src/84from.js#L185), which ultimately call [alasql.utils.loadFile](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/0d5c9816659bde946c01a2d6ebb8d062161a1976/src/15utility.js#L306).

I may be misunderstanding the intended behavior ??? but it seems like the CLI is handling input differently than the query engine???s built-in file readers. I???d really appreciate any clarification on this, or advice on how best to approach making AlaSQL run reliably inside Docker. Thanks!

## Steps to replicate docker issue:

1. Check out [my fork of the repo](https://github.com/ammeek/alasql)
2. Run the following command to build the alasql docker image:
``` cmd
docker build -t alasql-test .
```
3. run the following command to replicate the issue:
``` cmd
docker run alasql-test "SELECT 1 + 1"
```

Expected output:
``` json
[
  {
    "1 + 1": 2
  }
]
```

Actual output:
```
No SQL to process

AlaSQL command-line utility (version 4.6.6)

Usage: alasql [options] [sql] [params]

Options:
  -v, --version  Echo AlaSQL version                                   [boolean]
  -m, --minify   Minify json output                                    [boolean]
  -f, --file     Load SQL from file                                     [string]
      --ast      Print AST instead of result                            [string]
  -h, --help     Show help                                             [boolean]

Examples:
  alasql "sql-statement"                    Run SQL statement and output result
                                            as JSON

  alasql 'value of select 2+?' 40           Outputs 42

  alasql 'select count(*) from txt()' <     Count lines in city.txt
  city.txt

  alasql 'select * into xlsx("city.xlsx")   Convert from txt to xlsx
  from txt("city.txt")'

  alasql --file file.sql France 1960        Run SQL from file with 2 parameters
```

## Steps to replicate pipe issue:

1. Run the below command:
``` cmd
echo "I am test data" >> test.txt
alasql "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM txt()" < test.txt
```

Expected output:
``` json
[
  {
    "COUNT(*)": 1
  }
]
```

Actual output:
``` json
{
  "error": {
    "stack": "SyntaxError: Parse error on line 1:\nI am test data\n--^\nExpecting 'EOF', 'COMMA', 'LPAR', 'RPAR', 'END', 'ELSE', 'COLONDASH', 'GO', 'SEMICOLON', got 'LITERAL'\n    at parser.pars...",
    "message": "Parse error on line 1:\nI am test data\n--^\nExpecting 'EOF', 'COMMA', 'LPAR', 'RPAR', 'END', 'ELSE', 'COLONDASH', 'GO', 'SEMICOLON', got 'LITERAL'"
  }
}
```
comments:
Sounds interesting with docker.

alasql-cli is old and probably needs a good amount of love. Looks like we broke the functionality documented in the readme. Not good. 

Im not strong in docker. Asked the AlaSQLbot to help me understand this and got info from the conversation. Let me know if it helps.

---
The core of the problem:

Context | process.argv[2] contains... | Why?
-- | -- | --
Mac Terminal | SELECT 1 + 1 | The shell processes and removes the quotes.
Docker ENTRYPOINT | "SELECT 1 + 1" | Docker passes the string literally, quotes included.

### Scenario 1: Running "Normally" on your Mac

When you type this into your Mac's command prompt (which uses a shell like `bash` or `zsh`):

```bash
alasql "SELECT 1 + 1"
```

1.  **The Shell Intervenes:** Your shell sees the command line. It recognizes the double quotes (`"`) as special characters. Its job is to process them.
2.  **Quote Removal:** The shell consumes the quotes, understands that they are there to group the words `SELECT`, `1`, `+`, and `1` into a **single argument token**.
3.  **Execution:** The shell then executes the `alasql` program, passing it that single argument.

Inside your Node.js script, `process.argv` will look like this:

```js
[
  '/usr/local/bin/node', // The node executable
  '/path/to/alasql-cli.js', // The script being run
  'SELECT 1 + 1' // The argument. Notice: NO QUOTES.
];
```

The third element, `process.argv[2]`, is the clean string `SELECT 1 + 1`.

---

### Scenario 2: Running via Docker's `ENTRYPOINT ["alasql"]`

When you run this command:

```bash
docker run alasql-test "SELECT 1 + 1"
```

1.  **NO Shell Intervenes:** Docker's "exec form" (`ENTRYPOINT ["executable"]`) does **not** use a shell. It performs a direct system call, which is much more literal. It has no concept of "processing" quotes.
2.  **Literal Passing:** It takes the string you provided, `"SELECT 1 + 1"`, and passes it *verbatim*, quotes and all, as a single argument to the entrypoint.

Inside your Node.js script running in the container, `process.argv` will look like this:

```js
[
  '/usr/local/bin/node', // The node executable
  '/alasql/bin/alasql-cli.js', // The script being run
  '"SELECT 1 + 1"' // The argument. Notice: IT INCLUDES THE QUOTES.
];
```

The third element, `process.argv[2]`, is the string `"SELECT 1 + 1"`.

---


The problem you're seeing is a classic and subtle issue with how command-line arguments are parsed, especially when dealing with Node.js scripts and Docker entrypoints. The `alasql` command-line tool, like many Node.js CLIs, is often executed via a shell script wrapper (the shebang line `#!/usr/bin/env node`).

The most reliable way to fix this is to use a script as your entrypoint that can properly handle the arguments passed from Docker.

### The Solution: Using an `entrypoint.sh` Script

1.  **Create an `entrypoint.sh` file:**
    In the same directory as your `Dockerfile` (the root of your `alasql` repo), create a new file named `entrypoint.sh`.

2.  **Add the following content to `entrypoint.sh`:**

    ```bash
    #!/bin/sh
    # This script acts as a wrapper for the alasql command.
    # The "$@" special variable expands to all the arguments passed to the script,
    # preserving quotes and spaces correctly.
    
    # Execute the alasql command with all provided arguments
    exec alasql "$@"
    ```

3.  **Make the script executable:**
    Since you're on a Mac, run this command in your terminal to set the correct permissions. This is crucial; Docker will copy these permissions into the image.

    ```bash
    chmod +x entrypoint.sh
    ```

4.  **Modify your `Dockerfile`:**
    Update your `Dockerfile` to copy and use this new script.

    ```dockerfile
    FROM node:25.0.0-slim
    RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y git && apt-get clean
    
    WORKDIR /alasql
    
    # Copy the entrypoint script first and set permissions
    COPY entrypoint.sh .
    RUN chmod +x ./entrypoint.sh
    
    # Copy the rest of the application code
    COPY . .
    
    RUN yarn install
    
    # not useing install-g as I am haveing issues with prettier.
    RUN yarn run build-only
    RUN npm uninstall alasql -g && npm install -g .
    
    # Use the script as the entrypoint
    ENTRYPOINT ["./entrypoint.sh"]
    ```
    *Note: I also adjusted the `COPY` order slightly. It's good practice to copy things that change less often (like the entrypoint script) before things that change frequently (your source code) to better leverage Docker's caching.*


### Explanation: `ENTRYPOINT ["executable"]` vs `ENTRYPOINT ["./script.sh"]`

*   **`ENTRYPOINT ["alasql"]` (Exec Form):** This form runs the executable directly, without a shell. Docker passes `"SELECT 1 + 1"` as a single argument. While this *should* work, some Node.js CLI tools can be finicky about how they receive and parse arguments when not run through a standard shell (`sh` or `bash`).

*   **`ENTRYPOINT ["./entrypoint.sh"]` (Wrapper Script):** This is the more robust pattern. Docker runs your script, passing `"SELECT 1 + 1"` as an argument to it. Inside the script, `"$@"` is a special shell variable that expands to all command-line arguments, preserving them exactly as they were received. The `exec alasql "$@"` line then replaces the shell process with the `alasql` process, passing the arguments along perfectly. This reliably mimics how you would run the command directly in your own terminal.

@mathiasrw Unfortunately, the suggestion from AlaSQLbot didn???t work for me..

I've had a look into the issue in more depth and I belive that my assumption about [alasql.utils.loadFile](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/0d5c9816659bde946c01a2d6ebb8d062161a1976/src/15utility.js#L306) function needing to read from the stdin rarther than the [alasql-cli.js](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/blob/develop/bin/alasql-cli.js) function is correct. Based on that I've raised a PR to resolve the pipe issue. While fixing the pipe issue I have also resolved my docker issue by removing the logic that depends on a TTY being attached to the terminal since we no longer expect piped data to be read at this point.

I've run the following commands in docker and on my local mashine against my change in the [PR](https://github.com/AlaSQL/alasql/pull/2159) and develop and documented them below.

| Command                                                           | Docker PR           | Docker Dev | Local PR            | Local Develop       |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------|------------|---------------------|---------------------|
| echo "test" \| alasql "SELECT COUNT(*) > 0 as Success FROM txt()" | [{"Success": true}] | TTY ERROR  | [{"Success": true}] | Pipe ERROR          |
| alasql "SELECT COUNT(*) > 0 as Success FROM txt()" < test.txt     | [{"Success": true}] | TTY ERROR  | [{"Success": true}] | Pipe ERROR          |
| alasql 'select 1 as Succes'                                       | [{"Success": true}] | TTY ERROR  | [{"Success": true}] | [{"Success": true}] |


I've also added some tests to cover the above cases along with some other bits of cli functionality.

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to make the Alasql cli work correctly in a Docker environment and to resolve the pipe issue. The author wants to understand why the Alasql cli is not working as expected in a Docker environment and how to fix the pipe issue.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirements for the issue are that the Alasql cli should work correctly in a Docker environment and that the pipe functionality should work as expected. The validation is that the commands should produce the expected output and that the tests should pass.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author tried updating the logic in alasql-cli.js, but it didn't work. The issue was also discussed with AlaSQLbot, but it didn't provide a solution. The author then looked into the issue in more depth and found that the assumption about alasql.utils.loadFile function needing to read from stdin rather than alasql-cli.js function is correct. A PR was raised to resolve the pipe issue and the docker issue was also resolved by removing the logic that depends on a TTY being attached to the terminal.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about Alasql cli docker/pipe issues. The problem is that Docker doesn't attach a TTY by default when running commands through ENTRYPOINT, which changes how the CLI behaves. Also, when piping data into a query, the input is being treated as a SQL statement rather than as data. The solution is to use an entrypoint script to handle the arguments passed from Docker and to remove the logic that depends on a TTY being attached to the terminal.

issueDTO.title: Add `height="stretch"` to `st.tabs`
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [x] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [x] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

In 1.48 AdvancedLayout features were added, but st.tabs was not updated to support it. Specially the "height" property.

### Why?

For completenes and make the new AdvanceLayouts works when you use st.tabs.

As of now, I have to add custom CSS with more or less complicated selectors to be able to change the height of the generated and intermediate containers.

### How?

@jrieke knows how :-)

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-12217)

@injeniero just to clarify, do you want something like `height = "stretch" | "content" | int` for the tab container. Then, when a height is provided, if the content overflows, the container will be scrolling similar to `st.container`. 

In the meantime, adding a fixed height container around the tabs might achieve something similar. But maybe I don't fully understand what you are trying to do.

The AdvancedLayout features allow you to configure how the container works. Tabs are also a container, so they should allow you to also select how the generated container(s) works. Without it, it just breaks the AdvanceLayout experience.

In the meantime, I'm just making it work with CSS, just as I had it working before 1.48, but now I wanted to drop my custom css and use streamlit native feature.
Fixed height doesnt work for me. I need it to adjust dynamically to the page height.

I see @injeniero , thank you for providing more detail. It sounds like you want something a bit different than what we are providing for `st.container` currently, where the container elements would stretch to the screen height. I will discuss with @jrieke .

@injeniero I'm not sure I really understand. Do you want:

1. All the parameters we have on `st.container` (such as `height`, `horizontal`, alignment etc) also on `st.tabs`? If yes, we probably won't do this since you can simply use an `st.container` inside of `st.tabs` to achieve all the layout things you want. I don't want to replicate all of these parameters for every single container. 
The only exception to this could be `height`, which might make sense to add to `st.tabs` as well. The reason we didn't do this so far is that on `st.container`, setting an explicit `height` also always makes the container have a border, but that would look awkward in `st.tabs`. Maybe something to rethink...

2. Have something like `height="screen"`? It's possible we'd support that at some point but probably first for `st.container` and then we might bring it to other elements as well.

First of all, thanks for following up! I see your logic here, and I agree with you. The main problem I'm currently facing is stTabs and internal div structure are setup with: "display: block". So they don't flow nicely inside an st.container that has `height="stretch". containers are using flex layout, so making stTabs to be flex compatible would make things a lot easier. ```python import streamlit as st st.markdown("# Example Container Tabs") with st.container(horizontal=True, height="stretch"): with st.container(border=True, height="stretch"): st.text_area("Document 1", height="stretch") with st.container(border=True, height="stretch"): t1, _= st.tabs(["Tab 1", "Tab 2"]) with t1: st.text_area("Document 2", height="stretch") st.markdown( """ """, unsafe_allow_html=True, ) ``` I would like for the content inside the tab to work just like the container on the left. Note: It would be great if we could set the height of the app as well from the API instead of hacking around with css.

Oooh gotcha!! Yeah ok I agree for this case we do need `height` on `st.tabs`, otherwise you can't make the tabs container on the right fill the parent container. Btw I think for the parent container above you set a fixed height, otherwise I get a different result than you. Fixed this and simplified the example a bit: ```python with st.container(horizontal=True, height=500): st.container(border=True, height="stretch") tab1, tab2 = st.tabs(["Tab 1", "Tab 2"]) # need to set `height="stretch"` here tab1.container(height="stretch", border=True) ``` Btw @sfc-gh-lwilby I guess that's related to the min width/flex basis stuff we anyway wanted to have another look at, but I'd also expect that both the container and the tabs container have the same width here.

summary.main: Add `height="stretch"` to `st.tabs` for completeness and make the new AdvanceLayouts work when using `st.tabs`.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The main problem I'm currently facing is stTabs and internal div structure are setup with: "display: block". So they don't flow nicely inside an st.container that has `height="stretch"`. containers are using flex layout, so making stTabs to be flex compatible would make things a lot easier.
summary.attemptedFixes: In the meantime, adding a fixed height container around the tabs might achieve something similar. But maybe I don't fully understand what you are trying to do.
summary.otherNotes: The AdvancedLayout features allow you to configure how the container works. Tabs are also a container, so they should allow you to also select how the generated container(s) works. Without it, it just breaks the AdvanceLayout experience.

issueDTO.title: Unify the distance between label and help for different widgets
issueDTO.description:
As an example, for `st.radio` this distance is minimal. But in `st.text_input` `help` is at the right edge of the canvas.

![Streamlit_help_distance](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25541767/200937693-0c269274-f2fa-4f95-b371-0845243a887a.png)

To find each `help`, the user needs to move his eyes around, which is inconvenient. I suggest for **all widgets** either to pin `help` to `label`, or to align the location of `help` on the entire canvas level. In the second variant, perhaps it would be a good idea to place `help` column slightly more right than the longest `label`.

---

Community voting on feature requests enables the Streamlit team to understand which features are most important to our users.

**If you'd like the Streamlit team to prioritize this feature request, please use the 👍 (thumbs up emoji) reaction in response to the initial post.**
comments: Oh yeah, that's been bugging me for a long time as well. Think I got so accustomed to it that I didn't even think about it anymore haha. I'll add it to our backlog but no promises on timeline yet.

issueDTO.title: Failing to run in Ubuntu 22.04 after make install because of libltfs.so.0 not being found
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

After a clean make / make-install in Ubuntu 22.04, LTFS fails to run because it seems to be looking for libltfs.so.0 in a different place than where it sits.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install all dependencies (apt install automake autoconf libtool fuse uuid libxml2 libxml2-dev libsnmp-dev pkg-config libfuse-dev uuid-dev icu-devtools)
2. Git clone https://github.com/LinearTapeFileSystem/ltfs
3. Execute ./autogen.sh, ./configure, make, make install
4. Run "ltfs" on the shell (sudo or not)

`ltfs: error while loading shared libraries: libltfs.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

Worth nothing that libltfs.so.0 was properly generated and exists:

```
sudo find / -name libltfs.so.0
/usr/local/lib/libltfs.so.0
/home/user/ltfs/src/libltfs/.libs/libltfs.so.0
```

**Expected behavior**
The application should run.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Ubuntu Linux 22.04 - 5.15.0-97-generic
comments:
This can be fixed with:
sudo ldconfig

Can this be included in the "make install" routine, or at least included in the Ubuntu install instructions?

It is really generic knowledge to refresh shard library cache when an error happens in dynamic link loader.

And I never know the project that `make install` make it at all in other OSS projects. I think it is good to describe something to README or another place.

Can you please write it up and open a PR for this project?
Am also currently having this problem.. sudo ldconfig did not work for me is there a way to manually link or another solution?

repository.description: Reference implementation of the LTFS format Spec for stand alone tape drive
repository.name: ltfs

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the error 'ltfs: error while loading shared libraries: libltfs.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory' when running 'ltfs' after a clean 'make' and 'make install' in Ubuntu 22.04.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue seems to be specific to Ubuntu 22.04 and the 'make install' process, requiring the libltfs.so.0 library to be found in a specific location.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests using sudo ldconfig to refresh the shard library cache. Another commenter mentions that they also had the issue and is looking for a way to manually link or another solution.
summary.otherNotes: Refreshing shard library cache with sudo ldconfig can resolve the issue. It's suggested to include this step in the 'make install' routine or Ubuntu install instructions. The author also mentions that this is a common issue in other OSS projects and recommends documenting it in the README or another place.

issueDTO.title: Add documentation (README) for Ray service
issueDTO.description:
## Description

Currently, the Ray service is missing basic documentation. A README should be added which includes the following:

- A description of what the Ray service is and how it is used in NDIF.
- Directory structure + explanation of main files.
- List all the main classes (Controller, Cluster, Node, etc) and give a brief description of what they are.
- A brief description of the main library dependencies and what they are used for (and remove any that are no longer being used from `environment.yml`)
- A list of any relevant environment variables and what they are used for (check`compose/dev/docker-compose.yml`, `compose/dev/.env`, and the source code).
- Add a section for spinning up the Ray service from the command line (I can help with providing content). Can mention that it can be spun up but won't work without the API.

And anything else you think would be useful to add.

Even if you don't have answers to most of these questions, feel free to kickstart a PR - one of the developers would be happy to work with you on it.
comments:
Hi @MichaelRipa , before seeing the description, I used sphinx/autoapi to autodoc ray service.  Sphinx complained about the directory structure and naming overshadowing standard lib.  So I created a experimental repo, copied ray service code over and made some directory structure and naming change to try to get sphinx/autoapi to work.  I just made it to work today and the repo is here: https://github.com/artemisep/sphinx-autoapi.   If you think we should move it over to the ndif repo, I'll do some cleanup and move it over.

I'll also take a look at the description above and start on some items, do a PR.  Thanks.

issueDTO.title: Typescript does not work with import alias
issueDTO.description:
By default Next.js apps come with import alias of `@/`. I find that when using sidequest, it's failing when the file imports something like `@/config`

Is it possible to add a configuration option to invoke the job with `tsx` instead of `node --experimental-strip-types`?
comments: Looks like it currently users worker threads under the hood? If `tsx` is enabled then can we just spawn a process? Less efficient but it will work

Currently, there is no way of forcing tsx. We use worker threads as you rightfully noticed, thus it's a node process that's spawned. Apparently Node won't look at the tsconfig file, thus it does not know what to do when it sees a `@/` import path.

Check this out: https://github.com/jonaskello/tsconfig-paths

Maybe that will solve your problem. You have to tell Node to use the paths specified in your tsconfig.
Well, I don't know exactly. We've never encountered this issue before. Perhaps indeed we need to add this in the fork of the main worker. Does BullMQ allow TypeScript path alias?
I think bullmq does not use worker threads by default. So when I run `tsx src/worker/start.ts`, it just works as tsx handles the aliases for that process and the jobs run within that process

I see. Then we have a limitation here. I will investigate how to include that lib in our main worker fork. This should fix the issue. Because we start a new fork process to run Sidequest in isolation, I suspect that if this fork uses that lib I mentioned, all the worker threads will have it by default.

I will have time next week to fix this.

@nahtnam take a look at my journey here https://github.com/sidequestjs/sidequest/issues/125

I suspect node sub-path imports is your answer

repository.description: Sidequest is a modern, scalable background job processor for Node.js applications.
repository.name: sidequest

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to make it possible to use typescript with import aliases in Next.js apps, specifically with the sidequest library.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to add a configuration option to invoke the job with `tsx` instead of `node --experimental-strip-types`.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author tried setting an env var `NODE_OPTIONS="-r tsconfig-paths/register"`, but it didn't work. The best solution found so far is to use vite to compile the typescript code and run it that way, but it's considered a worse experience than bullmq.
summary.otherNotes: The issue seems to be related to the use of worker threads under the hood and the inability of Node to look at the tsconfig file, which causes issues with import aliases. The author suspects that the issue might be related to node sub-path imports.

issueDTO.title: Inverted RTTI logic on Intel Compiler
issueDTO.description:
Looks like there's some inverted logic [here](https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/blob/master/mesonbuild/compilers/cpp.py#L736C9-L737C37) for the Intel compiler

```python3
if rtti:
    args.append('-fno-rtti')
```

In Clang and GNU compilers it appears correct:
```python3
if not rtti:
    args.append('-fno-rtti')
```

repository.description: The Meson Build System
repository.name: meson

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to fix the inverted RTTI logic for the Intel compiler.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The logic for Intel compiler appears to be inverted compared to Clang and GNU compilers.
summary.attemptedFixes: No attempts or blockers mentioned in the issue description.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the logic for Intel compiler in the mesonbuild/compilers/cpp.py file, specifically the lines L736C9-L737C37.

issueDTO.title: Support isLoading on buttons
issueDTO.description:
### Problem

Today, to inform a user that something is happening (and that we can't compute when it'll complete), we can put a st.spinner() somewhere on the page. We also would like to disable the button, so the user don't retrigger the behaviour by frustration (else we need to handle it in code). The most efficient way in the current architecture is to use a combination of session state and callback on buttons to handle these behaviours (click on button > disable button > show spinner in the same st.container() as button OR replace button > display result and restore button)

Whilst good in most cases, it is not as elegant as combining all this with the isLoading behaviour of base web. See : https://baseweb.design/components/button/ and toggle Primary.

### Solution

**MVP:** A new argument can be added to the `st.button()` api : `loading` or `is_loading`, set to `False` by default. Setting it to `True` would toggle the behaviour to show a spinner instead of the original label. Loading animation should display well on Primary, Secondary and ideally Tertiary (to cover all cases)  (see #6414) styles.

**Possible additions:** Adding a small text input next to the spinner would be great for customizability (🔥Computing, 🤞 Hang on...) , and added with another argument `loading_message`, put to the right of the spinner.


### Additional context

**Loading Primary**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97103608/229562599-664d2afe-1c72-4858-ac98-e477a1ddd06a.png)

**Loading Secondary**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97103608/229562684-ab887d54-83a3-4001-9154-5887ab47adfd.png)

**Loading Tertiary**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97103608/229563238-750d227b-6322-47e7-bb66-86df145dde4f.png)

---

Community voting on feature requests enables the Streamlit team to understand which features are most important to our users.

**If you'd like the Streamlit team to prioritize this feature request, please use the 👍 (thumbs up emoji) reaction in response to the initial post.**
comments: Thank you for sharing this idea and for the example images, @silverOrdeal! 🙏
We could also support this by allowing to configure `icon="spinner"`. The same could be done wherever we support `icon`. This already works with `st.expander`

repository.description: Streamlit ??? A faster way to build and share data apps.
repository.name: streamlit

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to add an isLoading feature to the st.button component, allowing users to display a spinner instead of the original label, and providing a more elegant solution for handling user interactions.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The feature should support all three styles: Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary. The solution should also include the ability to customize the loading message.
summary.attemptedFixes: The proposed solution is to add a new argument to the st.button() api: 'loading' or 'is_loading', set to False by default. This would toggle the behavior to show a spinner instead of the original label. Additionally, a small text input next to the spinner could be added for customizability, with another argument 'loading_message' to display the text.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to improving the st.button functionality by adding an isLoading feature, with the goal of providing a more elegant solution for handling user interactions. The current approach involves using a combination of session state and callback on buttons, but this can be improved by incorporating the isLoading behavior of base web.

issueDTO.title: space override properties on area2ds don't update.
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

Hello! I implemented rapier2d into my game, however i have found an issue. It might not be with the engine, and more the way I'm using it is wrong.
Here it is: I used a script to toggle on and off a gravity point area. The way I did this was by using the enum attribute "gravity_space_override." The problem I came across was that the bodies did not notice a change in the space override until they re-entered the area. This did work on the default physics, but I don't want to use them as the engine is so nice to use.

**To Reproduce**

Change a space override property (My example is gravity_space_override) with a body still inside
Any bodies will not reflect the changes.


**Expected behavior**

The bodies would update to reflect the changes to the space_override

**Environment:**
 - OS: Windows
 - Version: latest
 - Godot Version: 4.3
 - Type: simd single 2d, although there might be problems with other types

**Example project(zip)**

[space_override_error_test.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18933802/space_override_error_test.zip)

(How to use: Press space to change the override to disabled, and let go for it to re-enable, the body will not go back up)

summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the issue
summary.otherNotes: The issue might not be with the engine, and more the way the user is using it is wrong. The problem is that bodies do not notice a change in the space override until they re-enter the area.

issueDTO.title: data_editor: num_rows - option to allow for only adding or only deleting rows
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

I love that the new data_editor allows for num_rows = ???dynamic??? or ???fixed???. I???d like to suggest having another option that allows for adding but not deleting. 

### Why?

Deleting rows is often a scary thing. I like the ability to delete but I want to do it in a more controlled manner. I???m implementing an option that includes a column the user can check. If it???s checked then the process of deleting is done in the background where I save the row to a backup dataframe in case we need to retrieve it.

### How?

Allow for a new option for the num_rows parameter in data_editor, called "add" or something similar.

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-7091)

It would be a incredible feature. One addition:
In addition to "add" options, allowing only to add, the "delete" option, allowing only to delete.

It would be great also if there was the ability to delete indeed! I have a use case where I'm connecting a dataframe to a cloud database and I want to be able to quickly delete rows from the table, but not add rows (the row creation is a bit more complex)
I guess we could do this by adding `num_rows="add"` and `num_rows="delete"` as options. If anyone wants to work on this, feel free to make a PR!

summary.validationOrRequirement: Implement a controlled manner for deleting rows, with a column to check for background saving of the row to a backup dataframe.
summary.attemptedFixes: allow for a new option for the num_rows parameter in data_editor, called "add" or something similar. Adding num_rows="add" and num_rows="delete" as options.
summary.otherNotes: I have searched the existing issues for similar feature requests. I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue. To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post. It would be an incredible feature. One addition: In addition to "add" options, allowing only to add, the "delete" option, allowing only to delete. It would be great also if there was the ability to delete indeed!

issueDTO.title: Expose Target angle bounds and angle wrapping pass to the C API
issueDTO.description:
### What should we add?

In 2.2 we added the capability for a target to express angle bounds on a gate. At the time this was only exposed to the Python API for simplicity, since the initial transpiler support for C was being developed in parallel. This was paired with a new angle wrapper registry and a pass to lookup mechanisms for angle wrapping from the registry. Just like the target support those were exposed to Python but not to C. The internal implementation was designed assuming a generic callback interface that could eventually be exposed to C. Now that we have a working initial transpiler for C we should add these capabilities to to the C API so that users can work with this compilation constraints in C too.
comments: I'd be happy to work on this if you would like to assign it to me.

issueDTO.title: Support cost struct unit conversions
issueDTO.description:
`CostCurve` and `FuelCurve` keep track of `power_units::UnitSystem`. Also, `FuelCurve` has a `fuel_cost`, which is sometimes a scalar. It would be useful to have built-in support for

1. Conversion of `CostCurve`s and `FuelCurve`s from one `UnitSystem` to another
2. Conversion from `FuelCurve` to `CostCurve` if the `fuel_cost` is scalar

as we are currently doing both of these things manually _ad hoc_.

For 1, an easy approach would involve a function that takes the `CostCurve`/`FuelCurve`, the desired units, and a component reference or some other way to look up the relevant conversion factors. That might be a `good first issue`. Depending on how https://github.com/NREL-Sienna/PowerSystems.jl/issues/1134 is resolved, a cleaner solution might be possible later.

For 2, the converter function (or overloaded constructor ?????`CostCurve(fuel_curve)`) is trivial, also a `good first issue`.
comments:
To do this maximally flexibly, we want an interface to "multiply" any `ValueCurve` by a scalar. I'm tempted to implement scalar multiplication on `FunctionData` and bubble that up through the layers of abstraction.

In fact, it would be cool to have even more arithmetic operations defined on `FunctionData` ??? adding two `LinearFunctionData` together, etc.

> To do this maximally flexibly, we want an interface to "multiply" any `ValueCurve` by a scalar. I'm tempted to implement scalar multiplication on `FunctionData` and bubble that up through the layers of abstraction.
> 
> In fact, it would be cool to have even more arithmetic operations defined on `FunctionData` ??? adding two `LinearFunctionData` together, etc.

That is now done https://github.com/NREL-Sienna/InfrastructureSystems.jl/issues/459, paving the way for a nice implementation of this issue.

repository.description: Utility package for Sienna's simulation infrastructure
repository.name: InfrastructureSystems.jl

summary.main: Implement support for cost struct unit conversions by adding a function to convert `CostCurve`s and `FuelCurve`s from one `UnitSystem` to another, and a function to convert from `FuelCurve` to `CostCurve` if the `fuel_cost` is scalar.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires the implementation of a function that takes a `CostCurve`/`FuelCurve`, the desired units, and a component reference or some other way to look up the relevant conversion factors.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is already partially addressed by the implementation of scalar multiplication on `FunctionData`.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to implementing scalar multiplication on `FunctionData` and adding more arithmetic operations, which is already done in https://github.com/NREL-Sienna/InfrastructureSystems.jl/issues/459.

issueDTO.title: Edge case where moving layers between groups changes the location, rotation or scale on the canvas
issueDTO.description:
Recently I've spent more time working in Graphite and I want to make a point about one of the current design decisions.

Individual layers have their transforms set relative to parent node transforms. When such layer is moved outside of the parent into a different location in the nodegraph it changes its position on the canvas. It is really frustrating to work around this mechanic, and I believe many people will have similar opinion, especially those that come from other 2D apps.

Two solutions that might work here:
- make every layer have its transforms as absolute values relative to canvas origin (0,0)
- recalculate transforms when the layer is moved into a different place in the nodegraph so it's location, rotation and scale does not change
comments: Can you please check if this is still an issue in the [new release](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vl5BA4g3QXM)?

When I make a new project with Alpha 4, HEAD, commit f4a0f272 the problem seems to be gone. 
I have a project file made with dev.grapite.rs that has this issue - I checked it in both editor and dev versions.
So new documents don't have it, but old documents created in dev at some point in the past do have the problem?

It looks that I made a mistake. It's not layers but layers inside groups that are the problem. And it happens in both versions of Graphite. Sorry for this. With the example above if any group is moved inside the other one it's placement changes. I think this could be designed a little better. I would leave current behavior as it is in line with procedural workflow either as default or as a fallback. I'd add to this an option for recalculating transforms so layer/group that is moved inside another stays in the exact placement.

Are you talking about this occurring when re-plugging wires in the node graph? That would be expected behavior. The tooling (except in some complex edge cases involving shared data wires), however, should correctly compensate for this so if you're reordering things in the Layers panel, grouping or ungrouping with the keyboard shortcuts, etc., then it should keep the appearance by updating the transforms in the data. So to be clear, you aren't describing the latter, but the former?
Just moving layers in Layer panel does that. Without touching the nodegraph. Here are better screenshots. Moving GROUP_1 inside GROUP_2 changes its placement:
Returning to this now that the big end-of-September release came out, I'm not sure if I fully followed the discussion above but could you please re-check this to see if it's still an issue? Thanks.

I checked and it looks that I omitted one crucial step. Layer group needs to be transformed in some way - moved, scaled or rotated. When new layer is inserted the transforms are applied to it as well. With editor.graphite.rs:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d168bdd0-7f2f-400d-bc42-a46043ebcded
That's a clear reproduction video, thank you.

repository.description: An open source graphics editor for 2025: comprehensive 2D content creation tool suite for graphic design, digital art, and interactive real-time motion graphics ??? featuring node-based procedural editing
repository.name: Graphite

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to improve the behavior of layers inside groups when moved or transformed, to prevent changes to their location, rotation, or scale on the canvas.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is specific to layers inside groups and requires the group to be transformed in some way (moved, scaled, or rotated) before the problem occurs.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests two potential solutions: making every layer's transforms absolute relative to the canvas origin, or recalculating transforms when a layer is moved into a different location in the node graph.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is specific to layers inside groups and occurs in both versions of Graphite. It was initially thought to be a problem with moving layers between groups, but it's actually due to the transforms being applied to new layers when they're inserted into a group.

issueDTO.title: How to write a test for an empty body in a POST?
issueDTO.description:
Hi,

I'm trying to write some pytest tests for my falcon API. I'm using the following middleware for JSON translation:

```
class JSONTranslator(object):

    def process_request(self, req, resp):
        # req.stream corresponds to the WSGI wsgi.input environ variable,
        # and allows you to read bytes from the request body.
        #   
        # See also: PEP 3333

        # do nothing if content length is 0
        if req.content_length in (None, 0): 
            return

        body = req.stream.read()

        # ***** don't know how to write a test for this *****
        if not body:
            print('body was not present')
            raise falcon.HTTPBadRequest('Empty request body',
                                        'A valid JSON document is required.')

        print('got body')
        print(body)
        try:
            req.context['doc'] = json.loads(body.decode('utf-8'))

        except (ValueError, UnicodeDecodeError):
            raise falcon.HTTPError(falcon.HTTP_753,
                                   'Malformed JSON',
                                   'Could not decode the request body. The '
                                   'JSON was incorrect or not encoded as '
                                   'UTF-8.')

    def process_response(self, req, resp, resource):
        if 'result' not in req.context:
            print('result is not in req.context!')
            return

        print('FOUND result in req.context - json.dump-ing it')
        resp.body = json.dumps(req.context['result'])
```

I'm having difficulties figuring out how I can test the indicated block.  Does anyone have a suggestion/example?

What I have so far for testing this middleware is below, which sets up the resource and tests the first condition ("content length is 0")...

```
# extend TestResource to do more than just on_get()
class AllMethodResource(testing.TestResource):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()

    def before(self):
        self.api = falcon.API(media_type='application/json',
                              middleware=[ json.RequireJSON(), ])

    def on_get(self, req, resp, **kwargs):
        self.req, self.resp, self.kwargs = req, resp, kwargs

        self.called = True
        resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        resp.body = self.sample_body
        resp.set_headers(self.resp_headers)

    def on_post(self, req, resp, **kwargs):
        self.req, self.resp, self.kwargs = req, resp, kwargs

        self.called = True
        #resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        #resp.body = self.sample_body
        #resp.set_headers(self.resp_headers)

# make sure what we send and what we receive is well-formed json
class Test_json_json_translator(testing.TestBase):
    def before(self):
        self.api = falcon.API(media_type='application/json',
                              middleware=[ json.JSONTranslator(), ])

        self.resource = AllMethodResource()
        self.api.add_route('/', self.resource)

    def test_post_with_zero_content_does_nothing(self):
        hdrs = [('Accept', 'application/json'),
                ('Content-Type', 'application/json'),]
        self.simulate_request('', method='POST', body='', headers=hdrs)
        assert(self.srmock.status == falcon.HTTP_200)
```

Thanks!
comments:
Humm, but how would you have an empty post body with content_length!=0?

_BTW a suggestion that may help: switch to pytest and https://github.com/yohanboniface/pytest-falcon, that exposes a (imho) simpler and cleaner test API.
See for example https://github.com/etalab/ban/blob/master/ban/tests/http/_

Good point - I'm just using the falcon example (I think that's where I got the JSONTranslator middle) and was thinking about how to cover it well with tests.  But I think empty posts are acceptable HTTP.
I've found you can get an empty body by passing `body=bytearray()`.
@bcthomas To force content-length to be non-zero when setting body to an empty string, you can explicitly specify Content-Length in the `hdrs` list that is passed to `self.simulate_request(...)`.
Consider also adding such a test to our own test suite (although we probably already have stuff along the lines of this, check first).

Hi,
I am new to the contributor world. Can I take this one? 
Is this mainly to add some tests with empty body in Falcon?

Hi @ytsai43!
Yes, you're welcome!
This issue is mostly a documentation task; although as noted above, we might need to add a test covering the recipe we are going to recommend (unless such already exists).

Hello, this issue still appears to be open; I'd like to work on it if that's alright.
New to contributing on GitHub (though not to programming).

Hey @0xMattB! 
Sure, go ahead!

Great, thank you!

Can I get some clarification on the issue to make sure it is addressed correctly?

From my understanding: We want to document a special test case where a request body is empty, but `Content-Length` is non-zero.
And then check to see if this case is already handled in the tests, and if not, create one.

Is this correct?

Yes, that sounds right.

To be honest, I don't remember if I tried writing this specific test case.

If everything works as described by @kgriffs above, we could add a FAQ item on this.

I wrote a test using `pytest` to confirm functionality. I'm new to Falcon, but getting the hang of it.
I'll fit this concept into the FAQ and see if I can find any existing tests.

`post.py:`
```
# 'post.py': Simulate Issue #678
from wsgiref.simple_server import make_server
import falcon

class Resource:

    def on_post(self, req, resp):
        # 1. Empty body, content-length is 0
        if req.content_length in (None, 0):
            resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        else:
            body = req.stream.read(req.content_length or 0)

            # 2. Empty body, content-length is NOT 0 (branch of interest)
            if not body:
                resp.status = falcon.HTTP_400
            # 3. Body present, content-length is valid
            else:
                resp.status = falcon.HTTP_201


def create():
    app = falcon.App()
    resource = Resource()
    app.add_route('/resource', resource)

    return app

app = create()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    with make_server('', 8000, app) as httpd:
        print("Serving on port 8000...")
        httpd.serve_forever()
```

`test_post.py:`
```
# 'test_post.py': Simulate Issue #678
import falcon
from falcon import testing
import pytest

import post

@pytest.fixture()
def client():
    return testing.TestClient(post.create())

def test_post_body(client):
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='body')
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_201)

def test_post_no_body(client):
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='')
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_200)

# *** Test case of interest
def test_post_no_body_with_length(client):
    headers = [('Content-Length', '1'),]
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='', headers=headers)
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_400)
```

That looks good @0xMattB, just probably it would be practical to condense this to a short snippet as concise as possible for the FAQ.

If that is not possible, we also have the Recipes section for longer examples.
Will do. I'll also generalize the topic, and use this case as an example.

summary.attemptedFixes: Several suggestions were provided, including using pytest and pytest-falcon, and explicitly specifying Content-Length in the headers. A test was written using pytest to confirm the functionality.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about writing a test for an empty body in a POST request with a non-zero content length. The author is having difficulties figuring out how to test the indicated block in the JSONTranslator middleware.

issueDTO.title: [FEA]: Enable `__grid_constant__` parameters in CUB kernels
issueDTO.description:
### Is this a duplicate?

- [x] I confirmed there appear to be no [duplicate issues](https://github.com/NVIDIA/cccl/issues) for this request and that I agree to the [Code of Conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

### Area

CUB

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

`__grid_constant__` prevents the compiler from creating a per-thread copy of a parameter. Grid constant annotation allows threads to access the parameter through a single address, which can improve performance.

Considering CUB, I don't expect big performance improvements because most (if not all) functions are inlined. Still, some cases could benefit from it and it is considered a good practice.

see also, https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-c-programming-guide/index.html#grid-constant

### Describe the solution you'd like

Apply `const __grid_constant__` (`_CCCL_GRID_CONSTANT` for portability) to all non-mutable parameters in CUB kernels.

issueDTO.title: Minimal permissions for 'entra app role' commands
issueDTO.description:
We???re adding a new **Permissions** section to all commands. This section will document the minimal delegated and application permissions required to execute the command.

The goal is to:

* Make it easier to run the CLI with custom app registrations and application permissions.
* Ensure we only document the minimal set of permissions needed.
* Keep documentation consistent by placing the **Permissions** section right before the **Examples** section.
* If there are multiple resources, order them alphabetically
* If there are commands that only support one type of auth (like delegated or app-only), we have an example for that as well. E.g. [m365 planner tenant settings list - Permissions](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/tenant/tenant-settings-list)

### Resources

* [Writing the docs page](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/contribute/new-command/writing-the-docs/#permissions)
* [How to document minimal permissions](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/contribute/document-minimal-permissions)
* [Planner example 1](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/plan/plan-add#permissions)
* [Planner example 2](https://pnp.github.io/cli-microsoft365/cmd/planner/tenant/tenant-settings-list#permissions)


### Commands in scope

This issue covers the following commands:

* `m365 entra app role add`
* `m365 entra app role list`
* `m365 entra app role remove`

issueDTO.title: [otelcol docs] Copy edit the Collector installation page
issueDTO.description:
**What needs to be changed?**

Copy edit the Collector installation page, or if the page has already been [refactored](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry.io/issues/8353), the Collector installation section.

**What is the name + path of the page that needs changed?** 

https://opentelemetry.io/docs/collector/installation/, but this path will change if #8353 is complete.

**Additional context**: 

Conduct a general copy edit, looking for typos, missing words, and bad formatting. Also edit the section for the following things:

- [ ] Style guide compliance
  - [ ] Use sentence case subheadings. Only proper nouns should be capitalized after the first word of the heading.
  - [ ] Capitalize OpenTelemetry proper nouns and de-capitalize general nouns (for example, Collector is capitalized when referring to the OTel Collector, but signal names such as span or trace are not capitalized.
  - [ ] Use ???for example??? instead of e.g. and ???in other words??? (or similar) for i.e.
  - [ ] Substitute ???using???, ???with???, ???by???, etc. for "via"
  - [ ] Use short code admonitions instead of Markdown notes
- [ ] Clarity - rewrite if necessary
- [ ] Grammar
  - [ ] Unnecessary passive voice
  - [ ] Unnecessary adverbs and general wordiness
  - [ ] Future tense - should almost always be present tense
- [ ] Tone/voice continuity - look for any obvious shifts in tone or voice and correct them
- [ ] Request a review for accuracy from the Collector SIG.

<sub>**Tip**:
[React](https://github.blog/news-insights/product-news/add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/)
with 👍 to help prioritize this issue. Please use comments to provide useful
context, avoiding `+1` or `me too`, to help us triage it. Learn more
[here](https://opentelemetry.io/community/end-user/issue-participation/).</sub>

issueDTO.title: [agent-forge] Summary of Memory and A2A Task Store Discussion
issueDTO.description:
### Summary
The issue should summarize the conversation regarding memory management and A2A task store in CAIPE, including the need for persistent KV store for scalability and production readiness.

### Conversation Details
1. Memory is managed in CAIPE agents and propagated using contextId.
2. A2A client initiates requests and sets contextId to preserve message history.
3. Custom A2A status update task states are used for tool notifications.
4. Need for persistent KV store for agent state to handle restarts and updates.
5. Limitation in scaling pods due to lack of remote KV store.
6. Discussion on making CAIPE production-ready by adding persistent storage options.

### Acceptance Criteria
- The issue should summarize the conversation regarding memory management and A2A task store in CAIPE, including the need for persistent KV store for scalability and production readiness.

issueDTO.title: Create _repr method in src/hiero_sdk_python/tokens/custom_fee.py
issueDTO.description:
This issue is reserved for people who have never or only recently contributed to [Hiero](https://hiero.org) or any open source project in general.
We know that creating a pull request (PR) is a major barrier for new contributors.
The goal of this issue and all other issues labeled by [**'good first issue'**](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+org%3Ahiero-ledger+archived%3Afalse+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22+) is to help you make your first contribution to Hiero.

## 👾 Description of the issue
Debugging CustomFixedFee is difficult because there is no repr or str method so it will be a python object
There is no way to tell about specific fields


## 💡 Solution
Add a def __repr__(self) -> str:
method

it should state basic attributes such as
class name
fee_collector_account_id
all_collectors_are_exempt

We then need to unit and integration test this (see README.md)

### 👩???💻 Implementation
- add repr method in custom fee
- expand unit tests for custom_fee: tests/unit/test_custom_fee.py, tests/unit/test_custom_fee_limit.py
- expand examples/custom_fee.py

Best Practices:
- [ ] Keep your main an updated copy of the upstream main
- [ ] Create a branch to solve your issue
- [ ] Regularly fetch changes from the upstream main
- [ ] NEVER EVER GIT MERGE FROM MAIN, please use: git rebase main -S (see our docs/sdk_developers/rebasing.md) if you need to apply upstream changes. If you face conflicts, read docs/sdk_developers/merge_conflicts.md
- [ ] -s and -S sign each and every commit, you must use the terminal/CLI

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] as above
- [ ] All tests pass
- [ ] Nothing else changes
- [ ] /CHANGELOG.md has an entry under 'UNRELEASED' under a relevant section. (Read docs/sdk_developers/changelog_entry.md for guidance).
- [ ] ALL commits are DCO signed and marked as verified (see docs/sdk_developers/signing.md)

***IMPORTANT*** Your pull request CANNOT BE MERGED until you add a changelog entry AND sign your commits each with "git commit -S -s -m "chore: your commit message"" which is tied to a GPG key on github (read signing.md)***

### Next steps
  - [ ] Comment below that you???d like to work on this issue.
  - [ ] Wait to be assigned by a maintainer.
  - [ ] Read [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/hiero-ledger/hiero-sdk-python/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)
 to start forking and developing.


If you have never contributed to an open source project at GitHub, the following step-by-step guide will introduce you to the workflow.

For example if i added a restaurant,and then i needed to add another POI that is also a restaurant, it's right there without needing to type it again, thus making the workflow efficient. **Describe alternatives you have considered** Alternatively, have a dedicated tab for recently added types of POIs added so that it doesn't clutter up the type of POIs you can add. **Additional context** Here is a badly made mock up of what I'm asking for:

issueDTO.title: Add `dt` to `wupget:Update`

`wupget:Update` has no args, but basecontent widget handler passes `deltaTime = Spring.GetLastUpdateSeconds()` to individual widgets:
https://github.com/beyond-all-reason/RecoilEngine/blob/317735e1573779615c26a26a38d5bcd96f18c54e/cont/LuaUI/widgets.lua#L1096-L1101

I think it would be good (more elegant and more convenient) to have the engine itself pass `dt` as a parameter. I'm not sure why `Spring.GetLastUpdateSeconds()` exists instead but I expect the reason is that it's just ancient from before existing practices were established.

The direct prompt to suggest this change was https://github.com/beyond-all-reason/Beyond-All-Reason/pull/5958 where it was assumed that it is already in place.

issueDTO.title: Warning in angular-sass plugin
issueDTO.description:
Since the migration to the `@nx/angular:browser-esbuild` builder (see https://github.com/ghostfolio/ghostfolio/pull/5883), the following warning is logged in development mode:

```
[WARNING] 9 repetitive deprecation warnings omitted.
  Run in verbose mode to see all warnings. [plugin angular-sass]

      angular:styles/global:styles:3:8:
        3 ??? @import 'apps/client/src/styles.scss';
          ???         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                                                                                                                                                                    
    null
```

Investigate and correct the SASS `@import` to eliminate this warning.
comments: Hi @dtslvr, can I work on this?
Might be related to https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/40962

Little analysis: Root cause of this issue is because `@import` is deprecated and will be removed in Sass 3.0.0. The solution? - `@use` or `@forward` instead. The warnings in the project were from - styles.scss - bootstrap.scss I was able to use `@use` instead of import for the table, bootstrap & svgMap styles leaving bootstrap.scss with `@import`. This is a known issue as @KenTandrian mentioned and the fix is planned for their **v6** **release**. Permanent solution is to wait till Bootstrap fixes it and if we do want to silence those warnings, we might have to wait for the `@nx/angular:application` migration. I will keep on researching on this to find a better solution. References: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/pull/41236 https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/28627

repository.description: Open Source Wealth Management Software. Angular + NestJS + Prisma + Nx + TypeScript 🤍
repository.name: ghostfolio

summary.main: Investigate and correct the SASS @import to eliminate the warning.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a solution to eliminate the warning, and the requirement is to use @use or @forward instead of @import.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author was able to use @use instead of import for table, bootstrap, and svgMap styles, but bootstrap.scss still uses @import. The author is continuing to research for a better solution.
summary.otherNotes: The warnings are from styles.scss and bootstrap.scss, and the issue is related to the deprecation of @import in Sass 3.0.0. The solution is to use @use or @forward instead. The permanent solution is to wait for Bootstrap's v6 release, and if not, to wait for the @nx/angular:application migration.

issueDTO.title: Migrate trace unit tests to functional tests
issueDTO.description:
## Is your feature request related to a problem?

In #14499 I did this somewhat by accident.
After finding only one functional test for the builtin, I assume that was it, and later rediscovered these unit tests.
This caused a bunch of hassle and IMO a waste of contributor and reviewer time.

## Proposed solution

Switch to `lang` characterization tests for most error trace tests.

Error trace tests that test the actual trace-related types and such can be kept.
Tests for builtins and language errors should be migrated unless there's something very specific about the assertions that requires a unit test (unlikely)

## Alternative solutions

Keep as is. This would involve
- tolerating or fighting duplication
- a bunch of manual busywork adjusting annoying function calls to reconstruct messages
- not being able to see the end result unless we *also* have a functional characterization test.
Would not recommend.

## Additional context

Does this sound ok to @NixOS/nix-team?

## Checklist

<!-- make sure this issue is not redundant or obsolete -->

- [ ] checked [latest Nix manual] \([source])
- [ ] checked [open feature issues and pull requests] for possible duplicates

[latest Nix manual]: https://nix.dev/manual/nix/development/
[source]: https://github.com/NixOS/nix/tree/master/doc/manual/source
[open feature issues and pull requests]: https://github.com/NixOS/nix/labels/feature

---

Add :+1: to [issues you find important](https://github.com/NixOS/nix/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+sort%3Areactions-%2B1-desc).
comments: I'm in favor of this. Would reduce the manual churn by a lot.

I think it is fine to note that the language test suite could in fact be shelling out (functional test) or unit test based. It doesn't matter because the language tests are written in a declarative fashion --- the above is merely distinguishing how the language test *harness* could be written. 

The real point is that the error messages should use characterization test infra, and declarative, implementation-agnostic, language test interface, so they are

1. easy to regenerate, rather than hand-rolled careful grepping.
2. not unduely intertwined with the detail of this or any other implementation of the Nix language.

Two good wins for the price of one!
I'm marking this good first issue because while whoever does this might need some mentoring just to know the patterns, once they get going they can easily the pattern again and again.

repository.description: Nix, the purely functional package manager
repository.name: nix

summary.main: Migrate trace unit tests to functional tests to reduce manual churn and improve the ease of regenerating error messages.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a review by @NixOS/nix-team and a check for possible duplicates.
summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes mentioned in the issue description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to #14499, where the author accidentally migrated some unit tests to functional tests, causing hassle and waste of time. The proposed solution is to switch to `lang` characterization tests for most error trace tests, except for those that test actual trace-related types.

issueDTO.title: [Remove Vuetify from Studio] Convert Sign In page unit tests to Vue Testing Library
issueDTO.description: 🙂 Looking for an issue? Welcome! This issue is open for contribution. If this is the first time you???re requesting an issue, please: - **Read Contributing guidelines** carefully. **Pay extra attention to [Using generative AI](https://learningequality.org/contributing-to-our-open-code-base/#using-generative-ai)**. **Pull requests and comments that don???t follow the guidelines won???t be answered.** - **Confirm that you???ve read the guidelines** in your comment. Sub-issue of https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060. **Complexity: Low** ## Summary The test suite `accounts/pages/__tests__/accountsMain.spec.js` currently relies heavily on internal implementation details and uses Vue Test Utils in a way that couples tests tightly to component internals. This creates several issues: - Brittle and unreliable tests (break when implementation changes even if behavior remains correct, or incorrectly pass while actual user interactions fail) - Maintenance burden (refactoring component's internal code requires updating tests) **Refactor the test suite to use Vue Testing Library (VTL)**, which enforces testing components the way users interact with them. ## Value Add Prepares the test suite for easier and meaningful updates during the upcoming refactoring to remove Vuetify from this page. ## Guidance - Navigate to `/accounts` and familiarize yourself with the page functionality as a user | | | | - | - | | | | - Familiarize yourself with [Testing Library principles](https://testing-library.com/docs/guiding-principles) - Follow our [Unit testing](https://kolibri-dev.readthedocs.io/en/develop/frontend_architecture/unit_testing.html#unit-testing) guide and [Testing template](https://kolibri-dev.readthedocs.io/en/develop/frontend_architecture/testing_layout.html#testing-template), where you will also find how we mock router, store, composables, and more. - Follow [Testing Library query priority recommendation](https://testing-library.com/docs/queries/about/#priority) - Search for `from '@testing-library/vue'` to find existing VTL test suites ## Acceptance criteria - [ ] All major workflows are covered while avoiding excessive testing of details - [ ] Test descriptions are clear and document the behavior from the user perspective

issueDTO.title: [Comb] Fold comb.truth_table when truth table depends on a single operand
issueDTO.description:
```
  hw.module @Foo(in %c : i3, out out : i1) {
    %0 = comb.extract %c from 2 : (i3) -> i1
    %1 = comb.extract %c from 1 : (i3) -> i1
    %2 = comb.extract %c from 0 : (i3) -> i1
    %3 = comb.truth_table %2, %0, %1 -> [false, false, false, false, true, true, true, true]
    hw.output %3 : i1
  }
```
`%3` should be canonicalized to `%2` as the truth table depends on a single variable:
```
00001111
00110011
01010101
```

issueDTO.title: `executable-dynamic: True` should apply to `build-type: Custom` setup
issueDTO.description:
I have a Haskell installation with only shared libraries, and cabal's config contains:

```
library-vanilla: False
library-profiling: False
shared: True
executable-dynamic: True
```

This fails for packages with `build-type: Custom`, because cabal-install tries to link `setup` against non-existent static libraries.
comments:
I use `-dynamic` in `ghc-options` as a workaround (with a similar configuration). But yes it need to be fixed.

This workaround is problematic if you build static libraries in a sandbox (for example profiling libraries) , the ghc-options are propagated and can't be cleared.

Perhaps there should be an extra option like `ghc-options` just for building `Setup` executables. Note that this is related to cross-compilation as well: once it's possible to specify a host compiler (cf. #1493) it seems natural to have a way of specifying additional flags for it as well.
There is another facet of this issue: If ghc is built without static (aka vanilla) libraries, then even the default `Setup` executables for the `Simple` build type fail to build.
FWIW this does affect Arch Linux now, because the default packages don't come with static libs anymore.

JFYI `alex` is one of the widely known packages with `custom-setup` and without too many deps. It fails during configure step:

```
[foo@arch alex-test]$ cabal install alex
Resolving dependencies...
Notice: installing into a sandbox located at
/home/foo/dev/alex-test/.cabal-sandbox
Configuring alex-3.2.3...
Failed to install alex-3.2.3
Build log ( /home/foo/dev/alex-test/.cabal-sandbox/logs/alex-3.2.3.log ):
cabal: Entering directory '/tmp/cabal-tmp-21549/alex-3.2.3'
cabal: Leaving directory '/tmp/cabal-tmp-21549/alex-3.2.3'
cabal: Error: some packages failed to install:
alex-3.2.3 failed during the configure step. The exception was:
user error ('/usr/bin/ghc' exited with an error:
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSCabal-1.24.2.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSprocess-1.4.3.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSpretty-1.1.3.3
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSdirectory-1.3.0.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSunix-2.7.2.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHStime-1.6.0.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSfilepath-1.4.1.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSbinary-0.8.3.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHScontainers-0.5.7.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSbytestring-0.10.8.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSdeepseq-1.4.2.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSarray-0.5.1.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSbase-4.9.1.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSinteger-gmp-1.0.0.1
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSghc-prim-0.5.0.0
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lHSrts_thr
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
`gcc' failed in phase `Linker'. (Exit code: 1)
)
```

A more self-contained example fails with a different error, and it should also fail with "normal" GHC if vanilla is disabled:

Setup.hs
```hs
import Distribution.Simple
import Acme.Missiles
main = defaultMain
```
foo.cabal:
```yaml
name:                foo
version:             0.1.0.0
synopsis: foo
description: bar
homepage:            https://github.com/githubuser/foo#readme
license:             BSD3
license-file:        LICENSE
author:              Author name here
maintainer:          example@example.com
copyright:           2017 Author name here
category:            Web
build-type:          Custom
extra-source-files:  README.md
cabal-version:       >=1.24

custom-setup
  setup-depends: base <5, Cabal <2, acme-missiles <1

executable foo-exe
  hs-source-dirs:      app
  main-is:             Main.hs
  build-depends:       base <5
  default-language:    Haskell2010
```
The error is:
```
$ cabal sandbox init
Writing a default package environment file to
/home/foo/dev/alex-test/foo/cabal.sandbox.config
Creating a new sandbox at /home/foo/dev/alex-test/foo/.cabal-sandbox
$ cabal install
Resolving dependencies...
Notice: installing into a sandbox located at
/home/foo/dev/alex-test/foo/.cabal-sandbox
Configuring acme-missiles-0.3...
Building acme-missiles-0.3...
Installed acme-missiles-0.3
Configuring foo-0.1.0.0...
Failed to install foo-0.1.0.0
Build log ( /home/foo/dev/alex-test/foo/.cabal-sandbox/logs/foo-0.1.0.0.log ):
cabal: Entering directory '.'
cabal: Leaving directory '.'
cabal: Error: some packages failed to install:
foo-0.1.0.0 failed during the configure step. The exception was:
user error ('/usr/bin/ghc' exited with an error:

dist/dist-sandbox-aeee24c4/setup/setup.hs:2:1: error:
Failed to load interface for ???Acme.Missiles???
There are files missing in the ???acme-missiles-0.3??? package,
try running 'ghc-pkg check'.
Use -v to see a list of the files searched for.
)
```
Just to expand on @Piezoid's comment, using `cabal install --ghc-option=-dynamic foo`, or adding `ghc-options: -dynamic` in my `$HOME/.cabal/config` works for me as a workaround.

summary.otherNotes: Cabal's config contains executable-dynamic: True, but this fails for packages with build-type: Custom, because cabal-install tries to link setup against non-existent static libraries. Workarounds include using -dynamic in ghc-options or adding ghc-options: -dynamic in the cabal config. Related to cross-compilation and static libraries.

issueDTO.title: Support model_kwargs when launching jina-embedding-v3/v4 models with xinference launch
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request / ????????????

Enable passing model_kwargs to xinference launch for embedding models such as jina-embedding-v3 and jina-embedding-v4. This would allow users to configure model parameters (e.g., embedding dimensions, pooling strategies, or precision settings) at launch time, ensuring more flexibility and compatibility with downstream applications.

### Motivation / ??????

Currently, xinference launch does not provide a way to specify model_kwargs for embedding models. As a result, users cannot adjust important runtime parameters when deploying jina-embedding-v3/v4. This limitation prevents seamless integration with frameworks like RAGFlow, which require explicit control over model arguments in order to register and use these embeddings. Supporting model_kwargs would remove this blocker and make xinference more adaptable for real-world RAG and search pipelines.

### Your contribution / ????????????

no

issueDTO.title: Helm: Restructure Istio Provider
issueDTO.description:
Istio should be scoped within `provider` like other providers, ie.. gke:

[Current](https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/gateway-api-inference-extension/blob/main/config/charts/inferencepool/values.yaml#L88):

```yaml
# Options: ["gke", "istio", "none"]
provider:
  name: none

  # GKE-specific configuration.
  # This block is only used if name is "gke".
  gke:
    # Set to true if the cluster is an Autopilot cluster.
    autopilot: false

istio:
  destinationRule:
    # Provide a way to override the default calculated host
    host: "" 
    # Optional: Enables customization of the traffic policy
    trafficPolicy: {}
      # connectionPool:
      #   http:
      #     maxRequestsPerConnection: 256000
```

Suggested:
```yaml
# Options: ["gke", "istio", "none"]
provider:
  name: none

  # GKE-specific configuration.
  # This block is only used if name is "gke".
  gke:
    # Set to true if the cluster is an Autopilot cluster.
    autopilot: false
  # This block is only used if name is "istio".
  istio:
    destinationRule:
      # Provide a way to override the default calculated host
      host: "" 
      # Optional: Enables customization of the traffic policy
      trafficPolicy: {}
        # connectionPool:
        #   http:
        #     maxRequestsPerConnection: 256000
```

The change should be backwards compatible to support user migration.
